content:
Posted: September 16, 2013
												Spiral Knights is free to play cooperative dungeon crawler fantasy MMORPG.The player begins as a simple knight, and jump into action with an ever-changing, randomized world known as the Clockworks. Players can influence the areas they enter by depositing different minerals into the gates before they open. As players level up, they can upgrade their equipment or craft new items.Every Spiral Knight has two attacks: one primary attack with a melee weapon and one special attack. You start with a gun but can later gain access to bombs, and your arsenal is constantly changing as you defeat new enemies and learn to manufacture new weapons.One of Spiral Knights' greatest strengths is its art direction. Enemies are somehow a combination of threatening and adorable, armor upgrades make your Knight look both tough and huggable, and every environment you visit has tons of cool elements that make it interesting and distinct from the others in the game.Spiral Knights is a wonderful game. It is beautifully designed and fun to play and offers hours of interesting combat in a variety of environments.But there's one enormous catch: You have to pay real-life money to play Spiral Knights if you plan to play it for more than an hour at a time. Almost everything you do in Spiral Knights costs Energy. If you want to run a mission it costs 10 Energy, if you want to go to the second level of the dungeon it will be again 10 Energy. You start every day with 100 Energy, which you will quickly consume through normal gameplay.Overall, Spiral Knights is a fun, engaging, pretty game. So if you have nothing else to do, you can check it out.Sounds 6/10Graphics 7/10Gameplay 7/10Atmosphere 6/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 24 of 26 people (92%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
BackstoryObviously, spoilers are shaded. Mouse over them if you want to see them.The spiral knights, a group of aliens running away from the Morai(an antagonistic group that next to nothing is known about) on their space ship called "Skylark", are shot down by a mysterious force, and the civilization crashes on the planet "Cradle." 4 spiral knights, known as the alpha squad, dived into the mantle of the planet before anyone else could, but mysteriously disapeared as they approached the center of the planet,being chased by the "living shadows".Beneath the surface of the planet are many worlds, natural and artificial. In some of these worlds, there are notes left by the alpha squad, regarding their journey through that area. The core is a massive unnatural metal sphere at the center of the planet. It contains a massive amount of energy, but it's sealed off, with no known way to open it.At the end of the game, however, it is opened, and the "living shadows" are leeching off of its power.The purpose of the Spiral Order is to rescue the Alpha Squad, wherever they are, and to exploit the infinite energy of the core to restore their spaceship.GameplayAt the beginning of the game, you create your knight. You can choose their eye color, eye shape, height, name, and armor(all the armors at the start have the same stats). After this you are shown the basic controls.

In the game itself, you are running through levels, defeating enemies with swords, bombs, and handguns, and protecting yourself with your helmet, armor, and shield. There is also selectable missions you can do to advance in the game's story.

Also, when you aren't running through the clockworks(the areas beneath the surface of the planet), you can talk with your fellow knights in haven, a town on the surface. There, you can also buy items from the "strangers", or other knights selling them in the Auction House.

The game's currency is called crowns. Every time you kill a monster, they drop crowns. You can also gain crowns by selling some of your stuff.

You can make your gear stronger several different ways. The main way is through heat, which also drops off defeated monsters. Another way is to craft up your item. The last way is through Unique Variants(commonly abbreviated UV). These have a random chance of being generated when you make an item, and apply a permanent random boost to that item. There can be 3 UVs on one piece of equipment.

As you venture in the clockworks, you can fight by yourself, or with up to 3 other people in most cases. The only exception to this rule is the gamemasters, who can join even when your party is full.I love this game, but it has some SERIOUS drawbacks.This is a great game, even though some aspects of it make me want to curl up and die.Here is my list of pros and cons(don't worry, I'll explain these later).Pros:  GameplayStoryEasy to play(mostly)Shadow LairsNice first playthroughCons: GameplayCommunityRarityShadow Lairs2nd+ PlaythroughsThe gameplay is fun, especially if you like dungeon crawlers. I had never played a game like this before, and I loved it. The game is easy for new people to pick up, and you can make the game harder if you want to. The first time through the game is really fun, because unless you spoiled the story to yourself, the story is really deep and interesting. If you care nothing about Super-Endgame-Epic spoilers, read the hidden text following:The core is a prison designed by "The Architect"(presumably Tinkinzar) to contain the deity(the Sleeper) inside it, and to protect it from the ever-strengthening swarm(the "living shadows"), which it failed to do. The alpha squad is inside the core, fighting the swarm as it grows. The "Extra" modes, the Shadow Lairs, are freaky, fun, and offer awesome prizes...that is, if you can find actual good people to do them with, leading to my cons.These cons can drive me NUTS, as much as I hate to say it. Yes, I listed "Gameplay" in both categories. The gameplay is fun in most cases, but the thing I hate the most about it has to do mostly with the weapons in the game. Some of the weapons are obviously superior for stupid reasons than other weapons in their same star catagory, like how the cutter series(this is the actual set of weapons I use in the game because its fun, poses a challenge, and actually requires a strategy to use) is pointless simply due to that half of its attacks don't hit (which is supposed to be this weapon's main selling point), and some people would venture further to say that it's awful because all of its lines do pure normal damage, which means it won't do next-to-nothing against anything, but it won't do tons of damage against anything either. Moving on to the community. I have met a group of GREAT people on this game that I hang out with alot. However, the majority of the game community is stuck up, because the people greater than other people refuse to teach the newbs how to get better, and only tell them what they mess up in. They also judge people for their weapon choices. Like how I didn't choose the statistically best weapon cuz I don't want to feel too strong and make the game too easy to beat, thus killing fun.Becoming stronger in this game has been a pain since day one. My main problems come from all the types of rarity, for the same simple and annoying reasons. On crafting, the orbs are stupidly rare, and it's hard enough to get the specific type you are looking for. On forging, the problem mostly only applies to 5* items. The fire crystals are too rare, like before, and you need like 30 of the 5* ones to do anything with a large chance of failing, and if you can't find them, you're stuck with a weapon that is weaker than the one you had directly before it. Also, if your LUCKY, you might find 9 of those 30-90 fire crystals in ONE FSC run! YAY! SoLs are annoying also. Too rare, and too little benefit. The ones you get can literally be drained in one stratum, and the only benefit is the likely meh loot in that stratum.I also mentioned the S. Lairs twice, once in each catagory. I hate it because it costs a ton to get in it, and unless you do it on the hardest possible setting, your stuck doing it yourself, while paying about 150,000 crowns to do it for the slight chance of getting epic gear at the end. AND, you will probably pay another 30,000 crowns to revive yourself. Despite the monstrous costs, the most annoying part is the community again. As I stated before, most strong enough people won't join you unless you do it on elite, effectively slimming your chance of getting that gear your looking for. Even if you offer to let them in free on an easier difficulty level, they still mostly won't go with you. I know this from experience.Another thing I found out is that playing the game more than once is boring, because of the cons listed above.All In AllI love this game, but be warned that their is significant downsides to the game.The main way to overcome most of these issues is to get some nice friends to play with you, then spend the majority of the game working together. Or you can play by yourself and do what the stuck-up pros tell you to do: git gud(I HATE THAT).Also, kinda off topic, but when people ask you for money, help them ACQUIRE it so they can gain battle experience. It'll keep you wealthy, and they will become smarter with the game's mechanics.GAME RATINGStoryline: 10/10Unique and interesting.Gameplay: 5/10Fun for a while, but becomes monotonous.Graphics: WHO SHOULD CARE?I  love the graphics. Why does the gaming community judge games they play by the graphics? That's also stuck-up.OVERALL: 7.5/10

												The opening elements of this game have all that are required to get one started for the Free 2 Play MMO: a few tutorials and free items, and a bright colorful atmosphere and some playerbase. This is the hook for new players. The puzzle/combat atmosphere is artistically wonderful, but becomes second after a while. Eventually after 2/3's of the game is complete comes the end game grind wall. There is no true reliable way to level up gear without spending days searching for ennough material. The outlook of the game shifted 2 years ago in 2013 after the lead developer left the game, and has since become a stale promotional money grab for the developer with scarce new content, and only random chance boxes with the only new content weapons and gear at incredibly low percentages at around <5%. Recolored costumes every two weeks, and no attempts to keep long veteran players. Do not play this game unless you want to become addicted and subject to false advertisement that perpetuates dead shovelware.

content:
Posted: January 16
												Despite the significantly lower player base and also my recent inactivity on the game, I still feel that I'm obliged to provide my own insight into this game that I've invested quite a bit of time into.To start off, Spiral Knights is basically a hack-and-slash multiplayer RPG that enables players to explore the depths of the Clockworks, fight monsters, play through a story(-ish) mission mode and engage in player-versus-player minigames. Boss battles, swarms of enemies, hazardous environments, the like. However, there's more than just combat when it comes to player-player interactions as the game. The game's other features include:- Item trading between players, and an Auction House system that enables players to buy/sell their items for in-game currency.- Guilds and Guild Halls where players can get together, share items such as weapons and materials, access most shops within short distances from each other, and craft trophies using materials dropped from bosses. Guild halls have a required upkeep that guild members need to pay weekly. Teamwork!- Sword/Gun/Armour/Bomb crafting system which allows players to equip their arsenal to suit their battle needs.- Upgrades to gear called Unique Variants that add bonuses to the gear and have a chance of being obtained during crafting or can be randomly applied to gear for a fee.- Costumes/Accessories that players can use to add their own artistic touch to their armour, with the large number of items and colour schemes available, the possibilities are almost endless!- Events that go in rotations throughout the year, as well as annual holiday events that give players the chance to obtain items and gear that are related to the event's theme, some of which have special characteristics that no other items have!- An alternate currency (Energy) that can be purchased using real money and can be used to purchase items and gear directly from an in-game store (Supply Depot) or even converted to the regular in-game currency.I think there are more features but those are what I came up with off the top of my head. Personally, the game can be quite fun, especially for people who love slashing, smashing and blasting monsters in a cute, anime-style fashion. There are three weapon classes, swords, guns, and bombs, and none are necessarily better than the other. The game's battle mechanics may seem simple since most of the time since spamming attacks usually does the job. This makes the learning curve easy because learning to incorporate movement with one's attacks makes a pretty solid player, however the skill ceiling is a little higher due to techniques such as shield-canceling, shield-bashing, charge attacks and using status effects to one's advantage. Upgrading your gear up to 5-star isn't very difficult but it does need some time.I understand that some of the people reading this may be (or may have been at some point) regular SK players and might think that this combat stuff is a little pointless, but that's just because we do it so much that it just becomes a habit and that it's "easy peasy" and that makes it a little more difficult to look at these things objectively.The player base and community are mostly very laid back, very chill, and I've met some pretty awesome people on my journey (You know who you are :P). Most people would be more than happy to give you a hand on a mission or on a Clockworks raid, either for completion purposes or just to help you make some cash. Yes, there may be a couple of rude players or scammers here and there but I prefer to look at the big picture and say that they won't totally ruin your experience of the game itself.Summary:- The game looks neat and simple, it's not overdone for the most part, however when it comes to costumes and accessories it can be a little tiring to have the same items released but in a different colour scheme. The NPC artwork is cool. Overall quite pleasing to look at.- Combat mechanics are easy to learn, whether using swords, guns, or bombs. Weapons have different attack speeds and damage types. Monsters have resistances and weaknesses to certain damage types and makes weapon choice important. PvP has quite a high skill ceiling, but weapons with 'Attack Speed Increase' or 'Charge Time Reduction' Unique Variants, armour with 'Defense Increase' Unique Variants, and trinkets with health or attack speed boosts certainly do help. But I guess the main enemy in PvP is lag. :P- Helpful and nice player base, the game is more fun when played with others, also allows for coordinated gameplay (most of the time).

												I have a love hate relationship with this game, I love the artwork and content (even though some say it needs more and it does, it is slowly dying) I can 100% say there is no other game like this game and that is what makes it so special. Pros: Missions give you access to gear and items needed to play the game, they start from the beginning armor to end game gear (nothing thats 100% wanted but it gives you access to play end game content).There is an arcade side of the game, which was the original concept. 4 gates consisting of 29 floors, but only 24 floors that have monsters. The arcade gates change every 7 days and its random, so every arcade run you do will be different from the last. If you wanna merchant, there is plenty of promos you can sink your money into. Cons: There is a ton of promos, one every 2 weeks. They throw promos out like they are candy and are not working toward new content and game updates. If you have to submitted a support ticket then you should expect 2-48 hours of waiting for a reply. This is how they get money out of you, they force you into paying for in-game items with real money cause you cant contact support when you have issues of not getting back into a party. The Develops and Gm's are not dedicated to running this game, and their minds are only after $$$$, but you are thinking what gaming company is not only after $$$$? All of them are, for the most part, but this one is one of the worst ones because as I stated they refuse to help you if you need help. I've heard "sorry we couldnt help you out in time, maybe next time" after they expected the rest of my party to wait 2-3 hours for me to get back into the party. You need to see this game as it truely is, It is only about pretty costumes and accessories and thats it. This game is mainly used to see who looks the best and as a chat room. Just think of this game as a chat room version of Tinder with mini games to play like PvP and missions etc. So end point is no i wouldn't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 2
You might like if: You want a free-to-play without a catch and you enjoy cute hack-and-slash titles that are easy to get into but have sufficient depth of customisation to keep its content rich later on.One of the original 5 Steam Free-to-Plays. It was brilliant then and still quite formidable now. It's strength is that nothing is ultimately hidden behind a paywall and you're not bombarded with constant advertising. All of the content is (to my knowledge) available... you just have to work for it. You can spend real money to speed things up and get goodies more frequently - but it's entirely optional.The game itself is a simple Zelda-esque hack-and-slash where you take control of a knight, armed with a shield and 2 weapons of your choice from swords, pistols or bombs. It's elegantly simple but with sufficient skill required to master it. You navigate random, procedurally generated levels (or scripted missions) taking out a variety of foes - descending further into the game, where harder enemies, better loot and bosses lurk... All the while learning and crafting better kit (with plenty of room to really specialise later on). It's very easy to get into and is delightfully warm and charming; both in its cute aesthetics and fun music.You can play solo or form a team of up to 4 knights for an expedition - luckily, the enemies strengthen accordingly, so it doesn't necessarily make things easier  (i.e. you're not penalised if you want some solo runs).My only qualm is that, since its inception, some of the updates have made the game a tad overcomplicated. The crafting gets a bit puzzling where, in addition to normal recipe items, you now need fire to level up your kit (where before it levelled up as you played), alchemy orbs to craft new kit, special food to feed your pet and rare items to evolve them... All of which are found in different ways. You can get the hang of it - but it's a bit much upfront.But it's nice to see Spiral Knights still getting some love and updates since 2011. Whilst the new inability to revive teammates is a shame - the trade-off is that they've removed the previous limit on how many levels a player could enjoy in a day (without spending in-game currency) - so you can at least play a lot more now.... oh, and it's free which, all things considering, it's pretty phenomenal for the content.

number of helpful: 26 of 34 people (76%) found this review helpful19 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												tfl;dfr : A pretty good free 50 ~ 1337 hour game with good gameplay mechanics.This is a review of the actual game, not going to mentioning my unbelievable lag because of how far I lived from the servers. Not mentioning how much the community in pvp complains like no tomorrow or how the developers only updates the game with actual content once every 2 years. Nope, none of that, no where in this guide shall I write about any of that.Spiral knights is developed by three rings design ( also the developers of the popular online puzzle game, puzzle pirates ) and published by sega. Spiral knights ( SK ) is a Hack 'n slash MMORPG zelda type game. SK is a 2D imensional game in a 3D environment. It has a birdseye view, slightly tilted so that you can see a lot more going on at the top than in the bottom-- I don't need to go over this stuff, right?Gameplay : SK is a dungeon crawler based game, it's not sandbox/open world.WeaponsThere are a crap load of weapons. There are three main weapon typesGuns, Swords,Bombs.And then for each of these, there are 4 types of damage, normal, elemental, shadow and piercing. And then some of them have status effects, Stun, fire, freeze, etc.You basically hit stuff until they die. There's a shield button too, but it's better to kill things before they get a chance to even touch you.Swords are easier to use than guns. I can't speak for bombs as I have not used them much before.For swords, all you really need to do in PvE is the same thing as cookie clicker except that you click untill they die. You need to learn a few more 'advanced' gameplay mechanics for gunning in order to avoid the reload so that a lot more guns become viable to use. The mechanics don't take more than a day to learn and that's about as hard as the game gets. PvE wise, at least.There is a mission mode for PvE which help you get from one tier to the next. You do set levels and get the one-time rewards. However, they are repeatable and you can still get the dropped loot from monsters and treasure boxes.The (not so) main mode now for PvE is the arcade. Randomly generated levels that you can play through, getting progressively harder every 4 levels or depths, with a mini-town in between which we call strata's e.g. 'Strata 4' would be levels 13 ~ 17.There are 4 bosses in total, with 1 additional DLC boss.And many different variants / types of monsters to beat up.This game's gear is gained through crafting. ( which reminded me of dark cloud 2 / dark chronicle which I loved very much when I was younger )They are split into stars. 1*, 2*, 3*, 4* and 5 stars.Getting stronger as you go up, Duh.You purchase recipes from NPC's or other players and find the materials required for making the gear. And then you've got to get alchemy orbs. They are a fairly rare drop from treasure boxes and you need 3 of the same orb, that is the same star as the gear you want to make or upgrade to. Though these orbs can be found anywhere in PvE treasure boxes, you can also spend real money to get 'Energy' in order to buy these orbs. Though, unlike many other MMO's, you can buy energy from other players with in-game currency dropped by monsters. It acts like a stock market.From start to end ( 1* ~> 5* ) I'd say it would take about a good 100 ~ 150 hours if you're new to the game ( from personal experience ). 50 if you're buying your way through it although the game's a lot more fun when you take your time. SK is a lot of fun with friends too, up to a 4 man co-op party in PvE.Sprites:There are currently 3 sprites in-game. They give passive bonuses as well as 3 different skills for each pet.They're not much but they're there.PvP - The end-game stuff that's a lot harder than PvE. ( There's also a pvp mode called bomber ma-- I mean blast network )In SK, PvP ( Player vs Player ) is called Lockdown ( LD ). LD may look easy and cool at first and it's easy to pick up and get kil-- play* though You need to know ( a poop load ) more game mechanics to be good at PvP in SK. The learning curve is what kept me in the game after all these hours. In PvP, there is a huge skill leap from PvE and because of this, many players get discouraged and don't play it at all. But PvP is a wonderful thing in SK, you can kill people and win.There are 3 different classes for PvPGuardian, Striker and Recon.Guardian has a huge shield that protects team mates within a certain radius from enemy attacksRecon can cloak / go invisible and juke people to deathStriker(S) with two capital s' coz most people play strikers. Can walk prettay fast and dodge and run.They all give different stat boosts and debuffs ( unboosts? Disboost? Inboost? ) and play differently.And though a lot of people say there isn't much content, ( probably after playing for at least 200 hours, yes, if you don't pvp after or try new weapons/armour, there probably is a lack of content after 200, 200. Two hundred hours ) there is at least 100 hours of content with great gameplay mechanics and this is free. FREE . The game is still being updated and has events every few months.Thank-you for reading this painstakingly long review.Spiral knights is a good game with easy to grasp, hard to be good at, mechanics and I have enjoyed my time with it very, very much.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Spiral Knights had so much going for it, but now stands as a glorious monument to repeatedly poor developer decisions eating away at the core of a game like an infection. Money-grubbing Ubisoft you might expect this from, but it's a bit disheartening to see yet another misguided indie dev fall for the 'costume & cosmetics' trap at the expense of gameplay. Mind you, Hello Games just might've punctured that particular indie goodwill bubble once and for all.That being said! If you have no problems with eternal grinding, don't mind being stuck on the gear treadmill and like the look of the game world, then don't let this review stop you. There's plenty of good in Spiral Knights, and given the generous price of $0, you could do a lot worse than trying it out.Let's start with the good: Spiral Knights looks the business, with a cutesy blocky aesthetic that meshes well with the light tone of the game. The customisation options are plentiful, and it's satisfying the collect cool weapons, armour and gear while progressing through the story. The only problem is the immense, mountainous grind that infests everything in this game world. Even the early game is tainted somewhat, but the cracks split into crevasses before you even spot the endgame on the horizon. Every level will need to be rerun many, many times for currency and rare drops; in some games this isn't a problem at all, but Spiral Knights remains a relatively simple game at heart. It's an entry-level game in the genre, and so combat and exploration are highly simplistic...meaning that repetition follows, and no amount of customisation can salvage it.The OST is nice, no two ways about it; touching at times, intense at others. The story is a little light, quite whimsical but ultimately engaging enough. And the dungeon-running is pretty neat when you first emerge from your escape pod, particularly if you have a few friends to accompany you through the Clockworks. It's just that there's no longevity to the fun, and things get insanely repetitive very rapidly. Even the midgame content recycles assets to a significant degree, let alone the endgame where the majority of the grinding will be done. You have quite a few weaponry options in combat, but few moves to utilise - it gets dull pretty fast. Diminishing returns set in quickly.As I said before, if you don't mind a huge grind then don't let my review deter you - there are certainly far worse options out there. Quite a few of the complaints of long time players may not apply to new adventurers, and given that Spiral Knights is now FTP, it can't hurt to try it out. Just don't hesitate to bail out if it all wears a bit thin; it saddens me that for all the obvious charm therein, I don't see myself playing this one again.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Early game is pretty fun and fairly easy to advance through.  However, once you hit mid game (missions 5-1 and on), it starts to get increasingly grindy... or you can pay real money to expedite your advance.That said, I was going to go through just to finish the game and get all achievements.  But I found out one achievement requires buying 2 trinket slot upgrades and 2 weapon slot upgrades - things you can only buy with energy (combined cost of 800 energy).  To get energy you have to pay cash (750 energy for $2.5) or you can exchange your crowns (game currency) for energy (~10,000 crowns for 100 energy).  You can probably raise about 10,000 crowns every 1-2 hours.  Additionally, the trinket and weapon upgrade slots only last 30 days - if you want them after that time, you'd have to get them again...Another issue is you get to pick one of three pets as part of the 'story' progression.  Once you pick, you cannot change your mind - you are stuck with it.  However, it is possible to get other pets... at a cost of 2100 energy each.The third issue is upgrading gear - a requirement for 'story' progression.  To upgrade one piece, you need three orbs of the correct level, but all orbs are very rare drops.  Mission 4-1 requires a set of 2 star gear (gear set = helmet, armor, shield, weapon - 2 star, easy enough).  5-2 requires 3 star gear (I saved time grinding by using 20K crowns to trade for 200 energy to buy a pack of three advanced orbs to complete my set).  Mission 6-2 requires 4 star gear... I only have one elite orb right now and need at least 16.  I can get packs of 3 for 400 energy each (total of 1600 = 160,000 crowns) or spend a few hours at a time to get a chance for one orb to drop.  Not sure which mission requires lv 5 gear, but those orbs cost 800 energy for a pack of three...  Leveling gear is similarily frustrating for level 3 gear and up - fire crystals drop more frequently than orbs, but you need a lot more to level up 5 pieces of equipment to level 10.A few final notes: At times the game can lag a little - but if you are in a pack of baddies, you could find yourself dead without seeing yourself get hit (I died with full health due to internet connection lag four times in 50 hrs of gameplay.  Lastly, as you reach mid game the levels and baddies become a little redundant (especially with all the required grinding).Also note that my perspective is primarily from a solo vantage - played a little co-op with a friend.  So I cannot comment on PvP or guild play or the like.All considered, I cannot recommend this game as it gives you two options to progress once you reach mid game - grind tons of hours for little gain or pay chunks of cash.

number of helpful: 36 of 55 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Spiral Knights seems great, but lacks in plenty of placesSpiral Knights is an alright MMO, alright for free at least. It's definitely worth a try, seeing as how the initial pricetag is agreeable. For me, however, it's more of a social platform than a real kind of game. Allow me to explain as to why I see it as I do.Part 1: The GearSpiral Knight's selection of equippable gear is quite wide at first glance, there are plenty of different resistances and weaknesses to all kinds of armor, all of which can be interchanged at a moment's notice, but the variety is wasted upon especially superior gear that provides a kind of range that none other can provide. For example, if you were to choose between say, a Seraphic set or a Wolver set, the seraphic would give a damage buff equal to that of the wolver. However, the Wolver set gives a universal buff to swords, meaning that it does what the seraphic does, but can go beyond that, as well. It's armors like those that begin to break down the options available through common sense and unfair stats. Why anyone would go with an armor so selective versus an armor completely open-ended is beyond me, and most likely anyone else.An even better case is when it comes to early-game bombers and bombers overall. Bombs themselves are fairly underpowered items when working up, so it's more likely people go Gunner or Swordsman, for better attack and whatnot. Bombers overall that strictly follow the bomber line can choose the Mad Bomber Gear, giving them amazing stats for bombs, but horrible defense. There's another armor that does this, surprisingly, but, get this, it does it for EVERY WEAPON. Whoever decided that was a good idea must've thought pretty lowly of bombers, as it completely voids the Mad Bomber gear, allowing for sidearms and whatnot to be used in conjunction with bombs. All in all, the gear doesn't stop there, and most likely won't as the game progresses.Part 2: UpdatesYou'd think with the previously mentioned, they'd begin working on balancing armors and fixing things up, right? Hah, no. You want some costumes? Here's a few hundred. You want some reskins? Here's a box of 'em, have fun. Balancing the game is about as much of a lie as Santa. As while it's not real content, some people still love ripping open the new boxes and slapping whatever colorful paper that was inside right onto their character. I can understand dishing out some cash for a thing to make you look snazzy, but why feed a company more money when their game's pretty darn broken? I understand wanting to make the most out of the overpowered gear, but seeing one team of adventurers run into a dungeon all brandishing the same kind of gear is boring, stale, and just sad. There is no unique quality among players, no matter what little accessory they slap onto their armor, it's still the same cookie-cutter formula. I had more fun running into a dungeon with some close friends of whom we all chose oddjob gear, it was complex, it was different, it was confusing, and most of all, it was fun. Don't even begin on promised "updates" that hold new gear, as they delay for as long as they can. I'd get more in-depth with it, but I'll have to get back to you on that one. (Pun intended.)Part 3: The MonotonySo say you've finished the endgame, you've beat Vanaduke, heated your gear as far as you please, and have successfully reached the coveted rank of Vanguard. What's left? Apparently not much, if you don't have a guild, some good Spiral Knights friends, or anything immediately tying to it. The endgame leaves very little left, sure you have PvP, sure you have Blast Network, sure you might have guildruns, but why bother? PvP offers gear that has an alternative spin on some of your favorite (not-by-choice) weapons, with some stats made exceptionally worse, or some still a bit broken. But what's that to you? You've spent all this time grinding through repetitive missions for the things necessary to create your god-tier gear, so why bother struggling through all of that again? And don't try to play the card that PvP is interesting, it's usually the people with the broken gear using the broken swords. More often than not it's always Skolver wearing Strikers with the occasional Gunner or Snarbolax wearing Striker. Blast Network's just a bomberman port, playable by all skill levels no matter what, and to be fair, it's fairly fun. However, the lack of discrimination between skill levels can make it harsh on those who try it out, and more experienced players could potentially offset newcomers who'd like to begin playing as well.Part 3-2: The MonotonyDon't think it's just endgame, either, as the monotony can set in as immediately as when you first begin to start. The missions assigned to you to gain rank feel incredibly scripted and not as free as they could be. It feels more like a chore than anything else, and nowhere near as fun as the random generation of the Clockworks (Which seems to be, for the most part, swept under the rug.). The Clockworks now takes discovering on your own to find, which the game already doesn't reward, making it harder to want to do so. Missions are also more likely to have the boxes you need to find to use for the drop system to give you the main crafting materials that you need for better gear, so that's another hit against the Clockworks. If you find that grinding much to your distaste, don't worry, the online store will be happy to help, for the right price, of course. Online store not your cup of tea either? The Auction House sells them at prices only a "few" monotonous boss runs can pay for!I'm sure I could go on, but the review's already long enough as is.OverallSpiral Knights is an okay MMO, not great under any means, but it's not horrible. The only shining light that keeps this game from a true dark abyss would have to be it's community. The community has it's fair share of mean customers and nice folk. You can find some pretty good friends, and some truly cool people on this game. All it takes is a little bit of chatting, and you've found one heck of a pal. The missions and so are more tolerable with a fun group, as the dulling world can take on a new sense of rejuvenation with good talks, funny dialogue, and crazy moments. This game is saved by it's community, whether it be a good or bad thing. I only ever come back to Spiral Knights more for the people than the actual game, truth be told.All in all, Spiral Knights receives a 6/10 from me, for what it's worth. The game has alot to fix, and sadly, they haven't done much fixing. The experience can only really be fulfilled with friends, as going alone can dull the sense of wonderment you'll receive initially. I say you take some time out and find a little clique of sorts that you do things with, and you'll make it one great of an experience.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												In-game inventory shows in steam user arsenal, played this game about 4-5 years ago, got hit by nostalgia hammer and this is what I think...I often played this game solo. Sometimes my pal would join me in, but it was too much of a grind fest for them.My initial experience then was shock. An awe to the music, conept and art style. It really blew my mind how well made can a game be! It was era of Korean and Chinese grind-based mmo's which offered balance breaking p2w items or there were good, but p2p games. And there was Spiral Knights which had in-game transactions but overall, you, as a pleb poorfg player (like me), could actually catch up eventually with rich irl players.Game had simple but well thoght story and lore. Player, as a inhabitant of a cog-based planet, need to delve into the deeps to git gud items and kill mighty bosses. It's got retro rpg flair but you can use swords, guns or bombs, play up to 4 people and do ride-like dungeons and score good loot.Initially this made me soil my pants with excitement as it was trully a game I needed back then! It reminded me of Phantasy Star Online, which I spent countless hours playing on my Dreamcast console. Spiral Knights were great follow up to that at the time being.But then I started to realize this game was just amazingly successful indie project which somehow got greenlit to steam (back then it wasn't taht easy to join the platform) and eventually Three rings software were devoured by SEGA, which again, at the time, made many questionable decissions to make the company alive and on the market.Basically game was more and more becoming pointless grind. The key fun factor in games where you need to do the same thing over and over are: astonishing, super rare drops and challenging, sometimes very unfair bosses. Spiral Knight had none of these for me so, while still being rather scrub player, I left the game and quickly forget about it.5 years passed.So here I am. Still having those basic, in game items stocked up in my steam armory, flashing "Spiral Knights" logo everynoe and then it finally hit my soft spot and made me want to experience this game yet once more.The game is very light, it's under 700mb and patches in 2-3 minutes. Still had my account on so I jumped into elevator and went for some fightin'.Initial experience wasn't best to be honest. Game felt clumsy, control of the character wasn't that bad but I felt clearly this game is almost decade old.Enemy AI is noneexistent. Either, creeps charge their power-ups so long you can kill them or shot orbs which aren't threat. Boss fights are a bit more challenging but it's not that punishing bullet hell so any Ikaruga or Touhou player could play it with their elbows while focusing on crosswords.Inventory is old styled 30 or something bag so it gets full very fast. Same for the utility belt. They've added more NPC rtm sellers offering you actually decent items for ~5€ which could be grinded in one evening.Bombs are useless at my low level but doubt they are any better later on. Damage output might be ok in team fights but overall for solo play it's lowest dps, 1/10th of sword-gun combo or worse.Maps got few more objects on them and doesn't feel so empty now but fixed side camer is a bit annoying.Music aged badly. Mixture of chiptune and keyboard-programmed orchestrals aren't bad but the compression/low quality of sounds itself and limited number fo tracks makes it annoying.In the end, playing this game for about an hour made me realize how much it's just a shadow of much better, earlier mentioned PSO or any other mmo game actually.It's not bad game. it could be really great expecially since it might be a cross platform with much stronger handheld devices nowadays. Core concept is still worth exploring but it's clear that the developers or any creative team isn't there. This is now a money pit. There aren't any significant changes as it's still same game I've played 7(?) years ago, when it wasn't merged onto steam. In most cases, many would say it's great thing! Game not only lasted same for so long but you can just jump back to it after long period! -well I'd wish. You can pay up for items to grind faster or for not so impressive recolored hats with slightly better stats which again, would help you in grinding.Is the game dead?Well, my buddylist had players which didn't log for 4+ years. Elevator area in town had 2 other players and while setting up my party, there were a couple of open groups vs endless lists when I played it back then. With plenty players occupying elevators and chat going so fast, sometimes it was impossible to follow.In the end, nostalgia was beaten up by the reality check and as much as this game is appealing it's not near anything related to "fun". Sadly! It could be really great tittle but feels like burnt out star glowing with pale red dim light of the past bright and warm light.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Having played this game for around 8,000 Hours (3,800 on this account, and 4,200 on another account) from Late 2011- Mid 2014, I must say it's been a great 3.5 years in the game. So great for me that I wouldn't say it's exaggerating that it has changed my life in many ways. (< Extremely irrevelant to the review though)About the game:Spiral Knights is a fun MMORPG game to be playing with a group of friends, completing the missions from the Storyline, collecting all sorts of unique Gear, Costumes and Accessories to customize your character's looks, or even merchanting in the game. (Merchanting is completely optional, but it was something that I've done for over 2 years in the game at least, and it was a good experience, getting to know more players, etc.) Pros:-A Wide Selection of Accessories to choose from, making your own unique costume-Grinding (If you're into that sort of thing)-Chatting inside and outside of the game-Merchanting (If you want to include this from your perspective)-Challenges for beginners-It's Free!Cons:-Drops for specific items in-game is pretty rare, and players would sometimes just buy it directly from the Store, the Auction House or Players because they're not getting the drop.-Once you've cleared everything, incluiding the DLC, you have pretty much nothing left to do, asides from collecting new gear and so on.Spiral Knights from my Point of View:Back when Nick was still in OOO, Spiral Knights was updated with a lot of new events, challenges, costumes, etc. For PvE, My friends and I had a lot of fun clearing these challenges and grinding for the gears we so desperately want. Spiral Knights got a whole lot better when the Storyline was introduced, and the plot was interesting enough for us to keep playing, and we wouldn't get bored even though we're killing the same boss over and over again. (Well, that's what grinding in a MMO is about anyway...)As for PvP, being in a different region from the Game Server will affect your gameplay for this game mode. But there are  people who're in the same state as me, but can dominate others. (Kudos to them, and no offence intended to anyone in this comment)However, once Nick left, the amount of content for this game started to drop drastically, and I've only seen 1 or 2 major updates ever since he left. There are still updates to the game, but with just Accessories and Costumes, not much of content. This was the point where my friends and I had pretty much nothing left to do, after having almost everything we wanted. We came up with new ideas to entertain ourselves, such as time attacks for a certain lair, costume contests, etc. (I personally got so bored that I decided to design and make a whole ton of unique Costumes for my Character)But after a while, all these ideas started to die down slowly, and I see a lot of Veterans and my friends leaving the game, and I've followed suit, and cashed out from the game, with almost no intention of coming back to play again unless I see an update which can convince me to play again. (I still love the game though..) I do visit the game occasionally, just to see how the game is doing, and everyone who're still playing the game.The SK Community is one of the best Communities I've ever seen, and it probably would be. Players helping one another with problems, debates with just about anything related to the game, etc. As mentioned before, I'd hate to leave the game, but with almost no content, I see no reason of staying on.For any beginner(s) reading this Review, I welcome you to have a go at this game, but don't be expecting too much unless you're into a lot of grinding for your desired items. :) TL:DR-A lot of grinding required, and pray RNG is with you when it comes to obtaining something you want from Boxes, etc.-Intersting Storyline-Fun with friends-End Game is boringHave fun, and may the Energy be with you!-Revolutional

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I hadn't played Spiral Knights for over 2 years, so I decided to give it another go. Sadly, this game is mostly dead, and I am certain it will never become very active again. The developers pretty much abandoned it, the only thing that ever seems to be updated is adding new cosmetic items available as micro-transactions in-game, which is very sad, as well as repeats of events at Christmas and Halloween. SK's activity boomed during late 2012 and 2013, and I was lucky enough to play it at the time. It was such a good game, I always came back to playing it. Early 2014 was the last time I properly played it, departing as it was becoming less and less active, and my guild Aurora was in the decline (we were one of the 'big' guilds back then). When I came on SK for the first time in 2 years, I was so sad to see the state it was in. Haven used to be completely bustling with players, all shouting for trades. The marketplace used to be so full, and was constantly being updated by players with more gear available to buy, now Haven and the marketplace are pretty empty. Its also really hard to find any PvE games with other people unless you go out of your way to organise something with the few people that are still playing SK, so you really have to do any PvE solo, which for the most part sucks, because its very hard in the later levels and it takes a long time to do. The only thing that you will be able to play is Lockdown, which is just PvP. The only people who really play SK now are just 'hardcore' PvP players all using the same loadouts. Of course with only 450-600 people in game via Steam each day there are almost never new players, so the game is just steadily dying. Of course I still have to recommend this game, because if people ever started to play it even twice the amount of people playing now, then that would just be awesome.  This is so very enjoyable to play, and of course, I have so many expensive and rare old items, so if people ever start playing this again I can show off :3 being serious, please give this game another chance, it would be awesome af if the devs ever started to do anything with this again... I doubt it will ever happen, but still, I have to give this game a positive rating.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Its not F2P game anymore when you have to buy revives with ingame currency (energy).  Pros:  + Family friendly  + Controller support  + Elemental damage system  + well designed maps/platform  + There are 2 ways to play the game, simple one being going all normal dmg weapons which kids can understand easily, and other way is understanding elemental system + enemy elemental resistance/ vulnerability which could take some time to get used to.  + The game is not dead as people say, there are still enough people playing it, the game was released 2011, ofcourse it has to die sometime.Cons:  - Asian server not available  - Enemies are not balanced when playing solo (it is fixed on 4 player difficulty, it doesn't change when only 1 player is available). In short, you can't play this game solo.  - More grind = less fun, for example: Orbs of Alchemy droprate is horrible (I am not against the grind system, but in this game its not balanced).  - You have to buy revives with ingame currency. Thats a big no for a F2P game. Warframe used to have this system, they removed it and added xp loss + 4 revives system, which everybody liked. In spiral knights you loose ingame currency + xp/heat, so its just useless. Want to revive teammates? yeah you have to use the ingame currency for that.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												         Spiral Knights is a good idea of a game, however the execution of the game and the later installments made to said game make it not as recommended as most of the community might make you think. I will not be absoulutely negative in this review, frankly because I've played more than enough time on this game (200+ Hours) and I enjoyed a majority of said time spent. It was fun. But now, I honestly can never go back to this game, now that I've taken a long hard look at it after some experience playing it and taking a few years of a break away from it. I realized that this game is great sounding on paper, and the execution was probably spot on at the beginning, but as Sega bought the license and copyright to Spiral Knights, you could say it sort of went a little downhill. It became pay to win rather than a good experience for gamers, and to be honest, I fell into the trap and put a lot of money into the game, not an insane amount but still a lot.         When I was playing the game, if you didn't have money to speed up the process, you we're endlessly grinding for materials you needed to upgrade. Depending on your luck, it would last from 30 minutes to several hours just to get that ONE item you need for crafting. It's tedious and repetitive and overall, negative. Another negative is no real FUN minigames to play. The only side things you could do we're play PvP or play a rehashed version of Bomberman, which doesn't really handle all that well. Two important negatives are the gameplay and the soundtrack. I barely remember any tracks from this game, and some just sound like generic music, give or take. Also, the gameplay feels sluggish, and at it's worst, laggy. Also, there are some really annoying difficulty spikes in this game, such as the second boss where you are forced to use shadow weapons or else you lose ultimately.          There isn't that much you can do in terms of defense and dodging. For example, there isn't a stand-alone dodge that you can use on a basis. This makes bullet-hell bosses and levels incredibly frustrating to push through, especially in a group. You have a shield, sure, but that won't last long, especially since for me, it was always easy to bust through for enemies, even upgraded. Sometimes you even got shield-locked by enemies who constantly attack you. Enviornments are a little dull to an extent, and even sometimes there's too much stuff happening on screen, causing way too much lag which might get you booted from the game, like I did several times. Not like there really was much to do in this game anyway. In fact, as the months went on, I found myself at the end bored because there wasn't really that much content to keep me entertained for as long as I thought, roughly around a few maps and the occasional boss here and then. They have tried to supply us with updates with new content and the such, but even then, it just isn't enough to keep me around longer. Especially that ludicrous dlc or "packs" that they're giving out now, costing far too much than it's actual value. Basically, Capcom level dlc. Would you pay $40 for one armor set and a few items in the game? If you said yes, you really don't value your money as much as you should be.         Last but not least, the servers. How do the servers of Spiral Knights hold up? To be honest, they're kinda bad, especially when they are over-populated. If I wanted a lagless experience, I had to go on some of the barren servers. If you decide to join a populated server, prepare for everyone to lag walk, especially in the central district. This game cannot handle so many players at once if the servers are bad. If they manage to fix the servers and give us plenty of more content, I might look back for some revelations. But for now, that's all the negatives. Let's move on to the positives!          I had a lot of fun with this game with my friends. It was indeed fun to team up on missions together and leveling up your armor and weapons feels good. You can feel a difference in power between weapons and armor and their levels respectibly, regarding the shield. Once you have the materials and money for a new weapon, it feels rewarding to make it and use it. Busting up a monster is fun, especially a boss. The enemies have some variety to them and some are pretty challenging to beat, which is cool. The combat, although sluggish, is pretty solid, if it doesn't lag, ugh. Those are pretty much all the positive I can really think of. I'm not even going to mention the story, because let's be honest: Do any players of Spiral Knights really care for the story at all? Nope, because it's too boring for me to care about and so generic that if this story was in a bad triple AAA game these days, it would fit right in.----Final Verdict----5/10 [Average]There are far too many flaws and issues for me to consider this a great or good game. However, like I said before, I did have a lot of fun with it, so it's not that bad. If more thought and imagination was put into this game, as well as massive improvements to multiple things, this game woud score highly with me, honest. But as it stands now, this is a game I wouldn't necessarily recommend playing. If there are other people playing this game, why are you still playing this? What drives you to keep playing this game, knowing it's flaws? With that said, my name is Lucky Masterz and this was my first review on Steam.Let the silver be your guide! ~ Lucky ~

Posted: October 4, 2016
												This is one of the most magnificent and incredible game i have ever played in my life, a art style stylish and unique yet not repulsing. Action music that always got my body pumped just when it got difficult. the amazing community that accepts newcomers gracefully. This game is a masterpiece... At least it used to be... Let me tell a tell of when Spiral Knights was a shining jewel to all on the holy fields of steam. It was by no means the most popular game but everyone acknowledged that the game was something special and held a unique place in their heart. In the beggining days of Spiral Knights everything was bliss the developers rained free updates and were passionate, commited and even holy. I came to this game and SK speaked to me, it entranced me and sucked me into it twirls of fate. I loved that game so much, playing and being free with my friends that were like me and had dreams of progressing far in the game. For every gaping flaw in the game like the mist energy issue i still loved spiral knights and dreamed of secrets to still be discovered. I pictured myself reaching to the star on planet cradle and adventuring in the galaxy and saving the Knight race. I wanted to do so much for this game and my commitment was ultimate. Then it all came crashing down with a update that removed mist energy while making elevators free. Having had the difficulties with mist energy i, like many others applauded the update and were so happy to have finally been able to progress more and faster. Little did anyone know that the evil on Earth wanted to take this game and cut its destined glory and quench it in squelched potential. Under our watchful noses they coerced the power of Goodness that SK had with payment and promises that they would keep the game alive and great. All this time we were to busy meddling with the game to realise the horror of what would happen.. They slowly started corrupting SK by making money grabbing events that were intended to steal cash. Even then we should have armed our virtual armor and strod bravely and formidibly to defeat the greatest threat to Spiral Knights ever. But alas we did not stand up for the our source of love. As they twisted and turned this cherished title into a ruinous ruin of apathy and sadness. There is a place in SK where the realities come so close to these ruins. There was a great ruler of the aldmerian empire but his great evil burned and destroyed his own people... The hate twisted and killed untold innocents but in his blind hate he never stopped intill nothing could be done to save his people. SK has countinued to stutter and tremble in its later life until now. Where a new coven has come together to promise that they will keep this game alive and bring it into renewal. But alas those promises have been nothing but a attempt to once again break the loyal knights hearts and love of Spiral knights. Repeating the same crimes and betrayels of devotion again and again. I cannot say what spiral knights final fate is but as of now everything has been a ruin,  with the galiant guilds of knights shattered and broken never to be renewed again. The utter horror of realizing that this game was maimed like a newborn babe never to fully see its full potential. I was one of the great knights, undivided and devoted to SK utterly. but i have to     see with utter shame to see that we failed to save spiral knights when in its greatest time of need. We are *truly wretched..*Edit: lol i got banned from SK discussion. U know what they say... humans never change...

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												What happened to this game?After a long break, I came back to Spiral Knights hoping for the charming, cute and relaxing atmosphere it once had. A simple yet rewarding game. Go down the clockworks, level up your weapons, hope Basil has something awesome, kill some bosses, get deeper, trade at the auction house, buy energy through the market at the right time, and so on. The game was so fun yet simple that it lured me back over a year later without even being reminded of it.So what is this game now? A grindfest. The main reason for this is because you can no longer level up your equipment more than once in a single Clockworks run, you need to grind for (sometimes ridiculous amounts of) Fire Crystals, waste Heat (experience) and "forge" them even then with a chance of failure.Adding to this, the mission system feels completely detached from the game itself, in fact a lot of the modes are. Everything just doesn't meld together, it feels like a mix of gameplay ideas all accessed from a mess of a menu system. Zero immersion unlike before.I can overlook the poor performance because it's a game written in Java. Which in itself is huge feet. Optimising games in Java is hard, especially to look like Spiral Knights does.The music is relaxing and exilerating at the right times. The enemies, though lacking in variety, are well designed much like the rest of the characters and stages.It's just sad that Three Rings decided to take the game in this direction. Though, with the servers still being somewhat dodgy,  it's probably a choice of what we have now or nothing at all.

												been playing this for a while, then found it on steam and have been having a blast, it may seem simple, but it is definitely high quality F2P, met with regular updates it'd be a shame if you didn't at least try it!Its been overhauled as of late so if you are and old player it would be a good time to give it another spin Oct. 2013-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------In Spiral Knights, you play as a member of a race, the titular "knights", who has become stranded on a planet made entirely out of layers upon layers of clockwork dungeons made from pieces of other shattered planets. You descend down through the clockworks towards the planets core, working from a main social hub called Haven. While Haven is where you start, its most definitely not the only town in the clockworks. Throughout the game you will use a variety of bombs, guns, swords, and abilities to fight through the dungeons collecting loot and defeating monsters, traveling deeper and deeper on your way to discover the mysteries of the clockwork and eventually uncover the "core".- 12/5/15

Posted: December 12, 2013
												This game used to be good until the trade off by the company. The quality of their work dramatically dropped as they started passing off costumes as already existing armor and reskinned. The mechanics of the game are awesome as in for combat wise and stuff. The economy however is highly unstable and changes depending on the patch. The game really grabs you when you start off considering there are loads to do. After you complete your missions and stuff, it's mostly a vanity game like who has the coolest costume or best equips. The PVP system is a joke, there is no standard arena you can just hop into. It's team dependent besides for blast network. It's very hard to level your equipment now ever since the "heat drought". So it's much harder for low level players to get into the higher tiers. The events are pretty cool but most items released during events are just cheap reskinned knockoffs compared to the beginning. This game is only fun to play with friends, by itself its just a grindfest. Potential of the game I give it 5 stars, quality of the game I give it 2 stars.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												After spending lots of time playing Spiral Knights, I simply can't recommend this game to other gamers, especially players new to the game.  Instead of working on and releasing new playable content into the SK world, the team at OOO pours their time into making useless accessories, costumes and variant skins, none of which impact the actual gameplay.  It's great for those who enjoy peacocking in a digital world among mostly tweens, but otherwise it's rather unfortunate.  In the years I've played it, the game has simply lacked in progression.  Then, sadly, when new holiday or special event "limited-time" levels are introduced, the developers focus on making the level as difficult and un-fun as possible. These short-lived levels force you to grind for new collectables in order to attain the object of your desire, all the while getting killed over and over again, forcing you to, essentially, pay-to-play (and/or waste lots of hours grinding... but time is money, no?).I wish I had more positive things to say about SK... I really wish I could tell you that the story and levels keep getting better and better... that the gameplay is a ton of fun and that the majority of the people you meet won't beg you for your currency or items... that new bosses are being introduced and new strategies keep things interesting... that being in and/or owning a guild has any sort of point whatsoever... that the best update was better than 30-second speed boosts so you don't waste so much time running down long empty halls in each depth... ... but I can't... nope... not at this time at least... maybe in a few years... if it doesn't go the way of OOO's Dr. Who: World's in Time (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Who:_Worlds_in_Time)...

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Product received for free
												If you don't have many games to try or you want something new, how about Spiral Knights?It's a top-down action-adventure dungeon crawler, in which you fight monsters with swords (obvciously), bombs and guns.You level up your character as you play and obtain better equipment for your character.There are four boss raids and many hidden and rare content. Most of them are event-only items.If you like collecting rare stuff, this game has it all.The intro for the game is great and levels are really detailed. After that the game loses dynamizm and level are procedurally generated, so there are instances that you'll end up in the same corridor. That's the main thing about the levels. Most of them are made from patterns, so there are a lot of combinations, but in-game you feel that's the same level. The music is really memorable and atmospheric. I can't forget the Jigsaw Valley and the menu music.Because it's a F2P game, there are instances where packing money is useful, but the only gameplay changingelements are weapon slots. You can also buy weapons and armor, but that's only for quicker progress. And here is my issue with the game:Around Tier 3, you HAVE TO upgrade your equipment in order to continue the game. And the orbs required to craft them are really rare and can go for thousands of crowns. If you are lucky, you'll get there eventually. I had no luck and after two months of grinding, I finally got my FIRST 5-star weapon. Now I have to get my armor and a shield. That's another 8 months to spend, but I didn't had the patience to do this all. Soon, the game got boring.I played this game for around 2 years and I think it wasn't wasted in any bit.My most proud one is when I attempted the most difficult boss raid designed for 5-star sets. I only got 4 star equipment and I carried my whole 4 member team on my back. They called me the Gordon Freeman of Spiral Knights. That was epic. I died at the final boss, but it was worth it. Tier 3 is pretty challenging. The game gets relatively harder as you play and you can choose harder difficulty for more loot, which is fair.Get the game, play it for some time. If you like rogue-like games, you'll probably like it.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												The main reason I dislike this game is because it follows the very commonly done formula of many FTP/MMOs, that is to say, players who do not want to dish out cash will be forced to grind and grind until they meet the necessary requirements to go onto the next level (in which they must do the same thing again).At first, I thought Spiral Knights had a lot of promise. The art style is simply gorgeous, the playable characters, hell, EVERYTHING is adorable, the soundtrack was delightful and to top it all off it all had a huge Zelda influence. I thought this was going to be "Zelda: Four Swords The MMO", an aspect which got me very excited. Mostly because Nintendo didn't add online to the 3DS version of Four Swords. This is not Four Swords the MMO. It is not fun. Combat is dreadful, especially by yourself on higher difficulties. In a nutshell, combat can be described as "hit and run" and repeat. There is no strategy involved, it's just a matter of paying attention and hoping the lag doesn't screw you over (this game lags a lot, at least for me and always at the worst possible times. I can't count how many times I've died because of it.) What makes matters worse is that if you die, you will need a material called "Spark of Life" to revive yourself so you don't lose all your things and can continue the mission. However, this material is very hard to find, but of course the only reliable way to obtain it is buying it with money. The only times I can tell you I legitamentally had fun are when I played with friends but then again, anything is fun with friends. You're probably saying, "since you suck at the game why don't you lower the difficulty bro?", well that's where the FTP structure comes in. Spiral Knights prevents you from progressing until your armor meets the minimum rank. In order to accomplish this, the game has a crafting system and you must collect the necessary materials and crowns (game's currency) in order to build the armor you need.The problem is that the materials are extremely rare. These materials have a better chance of spawning on higher difficulties, but the drop rate is still low enough that you'll be forced to play the same mission again and again and again and again and again until you finally get what you need. This seems to get worse and worse as the more you progress, the better the armor the rarer the materials are. I assume this is how the FTP structure of this game works, to frustrate people enough to make them spend real money on these materials in order to progress. I can't really blame this, though, since a lot of free-to-play games do this sort of thing. Frankly, it's disgusting and makes for a bad videogame. I'd rather pay upfront for a game that won't give me BS than waste time doing something that's not fun and that I realize won't get me anywhere because the whole game will just be this.I love the idea of Spiral Knights. I like the lore and the universe and it's characters and it's graphics. But this is a videogame, not a movie or a show so gameplay is the most important thing these sorts of things have to offer. And Spiral Knights offers bad gameplay. Maybe it'd be better off as a retail game or something, but this is just basic MMO design.But, you can play this game without paying a single cent. Probably, I haven't finished it and I probably never will. You're just going to need to put up with repetitive, boring grinding to either find the materials or gather enough crowns to buy them off the market.Unless you have a bunch of friends wanting to play this with you, don't waste your time on this.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												EDIT: Lots of clean-up and stuff.I was looking for free-to-play stuff on Steam, and found this cute little Nintendo-ish MMO.Spiral Knights is an action MMO set in a world that feels like a cross between Legend of Zelda and Metroid. Alien knights fleeing a dying world crash-landed their starship on a strange planet called Cradle, which is a patchwork of places taken from other planets, with many rotating layers of mazelike levels within called the Clockworks. Granted sanctuary by the mysterious Strangers who run the surface town of Haven, they begin their search for the massive energy source that led them here in the first place. But they're not the only life on Cradle: Fiends, Slimes, Beasts, Undead, Gremlins, and Constructs all compete for territory here. An elite team of Spiral Knights reached the Core, and were never heard from again; the search for them forms the main quest.The game uses a "twin stick" control scheme; I used mouse and keyboard for this. WASD moves you around, and the mouse controls a pointer for aiming your attacks and thrown objects. Left Mouse Button attacks, Right Mouse Button blocks. Shift+ Left Mouse Button does a shield dash that bashes monsters out of your way and Stuns them, using up half your shield bar. Shift + Right Mouse Button does a quick hop in the direction you're moving, or in the direction you're facing if you're not moving; this helps you dodge area attacks, but has about a ten second cooldown.Up to four Knights can party together. It's drop-in/drop-out, unless the party is private or locked.You start with a Helm, Armor, and Shield slot, and two Weapon Slots. Two additional Weapon Slots can be purchased, as well as two Trinket Slots that let you equip some Trinkets for a slight stat boost, but these only last 30 days before expiring. You can equip any other Helm or Armor as a "Costume" over the Helm and Armor you're actually using, giving you some control over your Knight's appearance. There are also special Costume items which can be used just for this purpose, and decorative Accessories to attach to Helm, Armor, or Costume items. The in-game cash store sells Prize Boxes which contain random Costumes and Accessories. Many of these are just reskins of existing items in new color schemes, others are bizarre original creations.There are three kinds of weapons available: Swords, Guns, and Bombs. Holding the attack button begins charging your weapon's charge attack, which does more damage and has stronger effects than the normal attack. Bombs can only use the charge attack, but cover a wide area; you're all immune to your own weapons, so you can bomb away at close range.The game has four damage types, and every type of enemy is partly resistant to one type and vulnerable to another. There are also status effects that can be inflicted by some weapons, like Fire, Freeze, Shock, Poison, and Stun. Different kinds of Helm, Armor, and Shield give different status and damage protections; this is vital in the deepest Clockworks.After a few missions you get to pick a Battle Sprite from the three different types, each of which has various special powers on a cooldown. They're very difficult to level up to full power, but they can make some situations much easier.You have a Heath bar and a Shield bar. Any hits taken when not blocking come straight out of Health, which doesn't regenerate, so blocking with your Shield is absolutely essential to survival. Your shield bar recharges in a few seconds.Getting KO'd triggers your emergency revive, which gets replenished at the start of each level. Any KO after that requires a Spark of Life to revive you, or you can wait for your party to finish the level, but then you get no experience.Experience is tied to your gear instead of your character. In addition to collecting Crowns (coins) and crafting Materials, you collect Heat Crystals which are added to your gear at the end of the level. When an item has a full bar, you can then use Fire Crystals to "Forge" the item to a higher level. Gear also comes in different star ratings, from 0* to 5*, and crafting a 3* or higher item usually requires the previous version as a material. Crafting an item requires 3 Orbs of Alchemy of the appropriate star level, a small amount of Crowns, and you need to know the Recipe for it.This is where the game starts to run into problems. As you can see, there are at least five different resources involved in character progress. This was changed from the original system, which alienated a *lot* of players, and effectively paywalls most of the game's interesting content. The amount of grinding required to do this without paying soon gets utterly ludicrous.The part where free-to-play Knights usually "hit the wall" is the The Sovereign Slime, since it's very hard to finish the Royal Jelly Palace without either grinding for a lot of custom gear, or having a Guild or a more experienced Knight carry you through. If you can make it through that, you can probably muddle through the rest of the game eventually, but there are literal "gear checks" (the Hall of Heroes missions) which require you to have gear of a certain star level before you can attempt the next level of missions. This will take a while to save up for, since the Recipes you get as mission rewards are mostly for default normal damage gear that is not competitive past the middle of the game, and Orbs are rare drops and not cheap. Many crafting chains branch, but some underpowered branches are effectively dead ends.There is an Auction House which allows a player economy of sorts, you can buy or sell most unbound items for a small fee. There is a also a trade chat channel for people who would rather deal directly with other players through the trade system. However, any gear you have ever equipped (or crafted from something you have ever equipped) is "Bound" and can't be traded to other players. There's a way to Unbind equipment, but it costs more than an item of that star level would cost from the store, so it's pointless unless it's an item with rare Unique Variants (extra powers that you have a slim chance to gain from crafting) or an item from a long-gone Prize Box like the Overcharged Mixmaster.All of this adds up to leave the game in something of a typical "MMO death spiral" as new players hit the paywall and bounce off, and old players get burned out and move on to other games. PvP is also mostly dead for the same reasons.My recommendation is that you fight your way up to the Royal Jelly and see if you like it. There are packages available for purchase in-game, like the Deluxe Starter Pack or the Battle Pack, which can only be bought once but give some extra collectibles and/or costumes. You're probably better off spending the money on Energy (which can also be bought or sold for Crowns) instead, since the extras inflate the cost and are only useful to some players. The Krogmo Coin Boosters in the Battle Pack are only useful if you play a lot of PvP, for example. By this point, you should have a fair idea of what you need. Check the game's wiki to make sure you're on the right track."This sounds terrible, why are you giving it a thumbs up?" Partly because I feel ridiculous giving a thumbs down to something I've played for over 4,000 hours, it was my gaming comfort food in a very tough time in my life. Partly because, once you get past the grinding and get better gear, the gameplay is actually very challenging and pretty satisfying. The real game starts at high level, but most players won't tolerate the grinding long enough to get there.TL;DR: Get your Steam Wallet out, do an epic grind through the procedurally generated Arcade, or just hit it and quit it.PS: If you stay, go escort some noobs through their story missions, they could use the help.
