content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I began playing before they removed ME (Mist Energy). Wonderful little time. You had to wait for energy to recharge, and you didnt simply soak 24/7 of your time into it. A few runs a day, chores, other things, then other games. Grinding was bearable and you could revive teammates by giving them half of your life.  Then came the Forge. Grinding stones wasnt an absolute pain for the first 3 tiers, but then came the fact that T1 Gear can only be upgraded by heat & T1 Heat Stones. Another thing is that Gear takes to long to grind! And they made a new item and took away the life saving old revive system! Sparks of Life were the new reviving system, and they were SO RARE, that you only got them in dedicated grinding. VERY DEDICATED GRINDING. There are 5 Tiers of equipment, but you barely even get to own T4 items. I had 2-3 and then i quit. The Developer of this game left 000 (Three Rings) and SEGA took over. SEGA turned this into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ grindfest, which nobody likes. Fast progression to those who paid. This is why F2P games should follow Warframes principle and make everything obtainable with currency, but easily grindable. RIP Spiral Knights, you were once crafted with good intentions, now you are a quick cash grab...EDIT: Grey Havens (former OOO employes) have bought spiral knights and another OOO Game! Hope they fix everything SEGA destroyed.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Creative space survival story that is able to blend perfectly with the MMO genre. The game follows a survivor of a race of knights caught in a war as he/she crash lands on an unknown planet and has to craft gear such as weapons, armors, and shields to fend off predators and survive in this new world. The game has an ever-expanding story mode/campaign, a self-sustained economy that allows players to exchange in-game items with each other for in-game currency or for other items from other games,(which is why this game is so closely attached to the TF2 economy) guilds in which friends and strangers can commune and play together, events in which there are special missions and rewards, and even prize boxes that allow you to obtain cosmetics or branded gear for real-life money. Numerous weapons, armor, shields, and most importantly cosmetics and acessories such as costumes for your knight that conceal your not so good looking battle-armor. If you're looking for a game that has more than one way to advance, this is the game for you.However, developers have been having internal issues and the consequence of that is a severe lack of content and what feels like an incomplete game. Thos game has potential, but it needs support to get there.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Ever wanted to play a game for over a thousand hours just for the developers to one day realise they're raking it in and, not just give up on releasing any more proper updates whatsoever, but also modify the current game mechanics to cost the player as much as possible, trying as hard as they can to squeeze real-world money out of you before the game swallows itself whole? Well here's your chance!• Change the forge system in order to make it even more of a grind because you won't supply enough actual playable content to keep people occupied• Drastically lower the drop rates of essential upgrade components such that players can't even realistically level their 5* equipment anymore without paying real-world money• Occasionally taunt the players with the promise of new playable content, and then keep delaying it month after month, when in reality it hasn't even been started yet• Leave the players with *absolutely nothing* but seemingly endless weekly premium boxes containing re-colours of already-existing pieces of equipment which, just for laughs, you let your five year old son make after pointing him to the 'hue' toggle• If a player tries to mention it's immoral to do all this, delete his post on sight, remove him from the official group, remove his rights to post on the steam discussion board and hell, if possible track him down and exterminate him while you're at it. Petty things such as freedom of speech or having a personal opinion are not allowedThis is the loving touch that only Three Rings can provide!TL;DR - Avoid like the plague

												I really do love this game. The soundtrack is soft and arcade-like, the artistic design is *MWAH*, lore is nice and flexible,  and the gameplay is simple and easy to get used to. The economy, even in the early days, was nothing short of sucky. It's basically a 'im rich and have a few bundles of cash to burn' exclusive environment, making steady progression something more of an eternal endeavor.2. JJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJAVA.3. omg u like lag? i like lag yes yes give me more lag4. I swear this gets an update every X hours. I can never just OPEN THIS GAME AND PLAY IT.5. Community jumped ship because they were smart. I love this kid. I want to see it grow up happy and healthy. But sadly, as far as the state that it's in, it's not worth your time.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Spiral Knights is an all around good game. It's got stunning graphics, and the cartoony vibe fits it well. Combat is pretty solid, with loads of custimization and what not. Not that many microtranscations, and they're only for DLC or extra crowns (in game currency) or crystal energy (I believe crafting item). Colors are pretty nice too. Performance runs very well, with only a few chugs or hiccups here and there. Community is decent at kindness, but don't expect them to be throwing crowns at your face if you're begging (unless they're really nice). Guilds are also loads of fun. Storyline is probably interesting but I don't pay much mind to it. Spiral Knights, gets an 8/10.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												With the amount of time i put into this, i wish i could give it a positive review. But i cant.Pros: Original artstyle, arcade-inspired gameplay, and colorfulCons: The game feels like an absolute chore. The drop rates for items you need to progress are far too low, and its hard enough to find the boxes they're supposed to drop from. The textures bug out quite often, and its very unappealing. The worst part about this game, however, is the fact that its become a huge cash grab for the devs.Through your several days of trying to find the item you need, the game tries its best to remind you, "Hey, why not just buy this premium currency for your hard-earned money and buy it instead?" They constantly try to get you to sink too much of your time and money into this product,I started playing the game last year, and came back to it this month. It was still the same as it is now, and im immensely disappointed that it hasnt changed a bit.All i can say is that im deleting all my files for the game, and its very unlikely i'll be pciking this one up again.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												At first the game seems alright. It's heavily pay-to-win, but, that bit's rather negligible (so long as you never encounter any other players) As you get further in the game, it gets rather ridiculous. Rank-based missions start off simple. One unique/generic level, then advance two one generic and one unique level (if not two generic), and then two generic and one unique (or just three basic, unoriginal stages that you could find elsewhere). The tutorials are fine and dandy, but the lack of continuity in it is a little irritating. The game decides to explain certain monsters on certain difficulties *after* you've already encountered them, which is pretty hecked up in its own right, when they could've easily optimized the mission's levels to not contain something you haven't been taught to understand. Alas, it's straightforward genericstages.I haven't invested in it very much, but PvP seems to heavily rely less on survivability, and more on how much damage you can dish out in one life. Thick armor's given up for combat buffs, and a certain popular weapon-set seems to be one that you can't get without a ridiculous mass of crowns or persistence in a specific set of days.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Used to be a good game, but you get to a point where you NEED to pay to win (tier 4 stuff). At that point it is immposible to progress without spending  a dollar. I understand that the devs need money to run the game (I have bought the $7 DLC by the way), but this would be a  far better game if it was a flat fee of $10 to buy the game, with no grinding and overpriced stuff. number of helpful: 48 of 87 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Excellent game if you're into a casual MMORPG. It contains PvE features together with a VERY competitive PvP feature called "Lockdown." As a pro-league Dota 2 player, I felt that Lockdown was really enjoyable to play competitively.Gameplay:For short, it's a dungeon crawler. Nothing too shabby, with the birds-eye-view, you're pretty much aware of a decent radius around your character. The game consists of two default controls which focus on keyboard or mouse although fully customizable to your fitting especially if you have a gaming mouse or a gamepad. The game is full of innovative monsters which you're likely to enjoy and many levels which "rotate."Graphics:I have to say, I'm rather impressed with the vibrant atmosphere this game has. If you enjoy bright games, you'll love this. The chibi-style avatars are adorable enough to make you have to punch a wall to feel like a man again and the environment is surprisingly detailed. In terms of network-graphics, I'd say they did well enough to avoid graphical-lag - this, I can't explain through words so you'd have to play the game in order to get a feel of fluidity.Social:The player-base is small enough for you to socialize and gain deeper friends and wide enough to feel the game's population. Also, being recently implemented to Steam and Steam trading, it's a lot more convenient if you're a Steam gamer due to trade offers whilst offline and such convenient features - only way to get the feel for it is to actually play it and realize.Support:Their Spiral Knights Support is mainly based on actually mailing them. Their in-game support lacks and doesn't prioritize the most important aspects of so-called "support." So you can't really expect to get a hold of any "support" whilst in-game because it's not that convenient - only way is to contact them through email, which isn't so bad but could improve.Overall I give the game an 8/10 - which would've been better if it weren't for their bad tech "support" and I emphasize "SUPPORT," not "filter" team.

content:
Posted: February 10
												This is one of the games I played with a great community. Its unique concept is like none others. I'd definitely recommend this game. It has its "dying phase" but I'm really hoping that the Game Devs are still planning to update and put more content to the game. I'd purchase things that this game offer if it gets updated. ( SHOUT OUT: Paging Grey Havens, Please proceed to the Game Dev room now... )I know. It's boring if you're playing it alone. Make some friends, talk to strangers, don't be aloof. It's very addictive when you have people to share your moments with.Here's what I thought: > Artstyle - Its cute and very unique> Gameplay - Challenging. Well, not if you have good gears. Bottom line, its all about teamwork. Unless you like to play solo.> Music - Lovely music you got there bud. Its engaging.> Community - Its Great! That's why I love this game.> Players - I'd say 50 - 50. Some players are nice and friendly, some are not.> Concept - Can you name any game with the same concept? I can't. > Auction House - Oh my fudgy bars! Those are very expensive!> Supply Depot - Nooo! The trade market keeps on raising! Make it stahp! > Grinding - Aw man, this is a bad RNG. Need 'em orbs please!> Guilds - I don't know about you, but I love my guild. First and Last. > Wiki - Eh? Is the sidebar really down there? Hmm, care for a fix?> Steam Login - Why can't I login my Steam to Wiki page? That's crazy, man! > Servers - Oh my, why do I have a red dot? Mind if you guys put up some Asian servers? Please?> Patch Note - Oh come on!, Where the dang are the Patch Notes? I mean sure, you guys post updates on twitter... but....> DLC - I'd be fine if you make more of 'em DLC's too. Like maybe, a side story like OCH?> Price Boxes - Will you guys re-release Rageous Stuffs? I've been craving for them since I started playing...> Coliseum - Ah, no ones playing there anymore. Make some more PVP. Maybe like Capture the Ball? or Chess? or Maze?> Rank - Man, being a Vanguard ain't that good... What am I supposed to do now? Hoard stuffs? Collect gears?> Story - The stoy is incomplete. We all got stranded in Cradle. So, there's more content you can actually make here... Like maybe go to the moon? Well, why not?, Cradle has a moon right there in the Main Screen. And what about our homeplanet? our homeworld? What? they're just... gone? Still so many plot holes. And maybe you can have a story on why the Snabolax, Jelly King, Roarmulus twins, and Vanaduke keep on respawning each time we delve deep into the unknow parts of Cradle. Maybe because TIME is reseting? Cause why not, it is the Clockworks... get it? Here's hoping, like most of the Knights out there who still enjoys playing this game, that it'll live on for another 5 or more years. Because I know it's not abandoned yet. https://twitter.com/Cronus_GH/status/829819314475765760Good luck to the Devs - Grey Havens.Kudos for keeping this game alive at the moment!

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												This was one of my favorite games to play for a while and it got better once I put a little bit of money into it. However the sprite update ruined the game for me and I do not like the direction the game is heading.Pre Sprite Update 9/10It's very fun to explore and level up your weapons. The whole market and trading system was pretty good, especially if you're too lazy to get crafting materials yourself. To sum it up the whole thing was a fun experience for me. The only thing was the elevator costs. So if you run out of mist energy, you have to wait awhile for it to refill, but I guess that is the cost of it being "Free-to-Play" right?After Sprite Update 4/10The big problem of this update was the heat nerf. So now it's a pain in the a$$ to level up your weapons and armour. The actual sprites aren't so bad themselves, you get a little extra power against enemies. Before the update I bought a elevator pass, so when the update came they removed elevator costs so they traded in my pass for a bunch of crystal energy and other helpful things. But that does not make up for the fact that it will take a lot longer for a new player to level up higher. They added "The Forge", the new way of leveling up items, it is complete fụcking bụllshỉt. So now if you want to be strong and have high level armour, your going to have to pay money for fire crystals, otherwise it will take you a long fụcking time.Finishing comments:I've played this game for a few years and it was mostly worth it. But the devs fụcked up the game and my money I put towards it was a waste. So if you are a new player and/or if you are starting the game, it will take quite a while to get to a high level.(Note that the last time I played this game was about a year ago so things may have changed.)

number of helpful: 18 of 30 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Spiral Knights, whilst not a perfect experience is enjoyable if you're willing to ignore an assortment of problems it has. To start, the gameplay is pretty good, semi–top-down shooter/hack and slash geared closer towards co-optional play that can be a good challenge at times. What bothers me most is how the game is handled i.e. updates which are flagrant cash grabs for mostly sub-par cosmetics. Very few good updates have occurred during my time playing, in fact when it comes to real updates they can take way longer than expected with one notorious example being the gunner update which took over a year after it's projected release date to finally be added to the game.Other complaints I have include: A dwindling player base makes it hard to progress late game without searching long times to gather a party, especially on the European region; notable grinding present late game in order to obtain good gear without micro-transactions; usually I don't have problems with micro-transactions but they are notably egregious compared to other MMORPG models; and finally the most enjoyable/challenging missions are DLC only, further separating player base for these missions alone.I used to love Spiral Knights, it had a quirky aesthetic, the gameplay was enjoyable and I can't begin to tell you how much I love the music. But as the community gradually declined the issues the game had became more apparent. If you have a group of friends willing to play then by all means, go ahead, I really wouldn't recommend starting now by yourself.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2011
												This game was interesting at first, but it's game mechanics incorporate a shady "pay to play" system.The tutorial level of gameplay is engaging, but at the actual novice level the "Energy required to play" mechanic makes this game a complete waste to invest time into. The amount of "game money" you can aquire at low level is not enough to feed the "Energy required to play" mechanic. This forces you to pay real money for the energy at an online store, or wait 24 hours to "recharge". As a result, players are forced to logout, and play something else. No MMO should limit the amount of time and effort a player can invest in a game per 24-hour period.This game is for the very casual player that only occasionally logs in.  If you're going to be forced to logout and play something else, you might as well just play something else entirely.Skip this game, and look for a real game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I'll start with the pros and move to the cons, as optimism is a virtue.+Helpful, patient admins.+Ingame soundtrack that has its own peculiar flair. It can be somewhat of an acquired taste, but overall the soundtrack is gud.+Really neat skyboxes. Though said skyboxes will turn your computer into a toaster if you have a crap-tier AMD graphics card. +Chibi artstyle. I've never been really scared by any of the enemies due to this, though a few have their creepy side, such as the spectral felines you'll find in haunted zones.+The community (ingame and on the official Spiral Knights Forums) is generally welcoming and helpful, though there are a few loud complaints about various things at times. Can hold decent, respectable conversations with other players.+Smooth character control using the mouse.+Makes you not want to kill the rare enemies that can occasionally drop special loot. This is something I don't see often, as it turns the killing-things cash-grab into a "this thing doesn't hurt you; are you really gonna kill it?" scenario.+Wide variety of armor and weaponry to create, although you have to work for it. +Every single obtainable item save for armor accessories has its own peculiar flavor text. These can be fun for trivia enthusiasts.+The developers will occasionally take ideas from the official forums pages and incorporate them into the game, though this can be a rare occurrence.+Lots of alliteration and a few puns here and there. Mostly in the names of different dungeons and the flavor texts of certain items.+The storyline is fragmented, but the shards of its canon are dynamic. Spaceflight from a genocidal war, a mysterious crash-landing on a celestial body of machinery and nature, an oligarchal dictatorship bent to its rulers' own twisted design, a tortured, fiery Duke of a smoldering kingdom, forever believing his realm is under siege...all of this is part of the world the player characters live in.+Sentient jelly cubes with mustaches+helicopter birds+tree physics have yet to make any sense, as the leaves aren't attached to the trunk. good stuff.+demons throw office supplies at you. Only the disgruntled overtime-workers use pitchforks.+I'm pretty sure that putting a rocket engine on a war-hammer is the greatest achievement weaponry has to offer.Now for the cons.-Development of the game has slowed to a crawl. Although the major updates are impressive, they come few and far between, and as such there hasn't been much to accomplish once endgame is reached. This is a major contention with players who lack a certain amount of patience.-Promotional "costume" items are produced more often than game updates. This, too, leads to negative feelings toward the developers, as the costume items can only be acquired using real-world funds. Though it does lead to a huge variety of player costumes and personalized outfits. I haven't seen a single other player that dresses their character the same as mine.-Many of the weapons have a certain niche in the game, but there is a significant quality fluctuation when it comes to how well the small group of most-effective weapons function as opposed to the great variety of others.-Few money-making stages. There is one particular endgame dungeon that is the most effective way to earn ingame currency sans trading, but as there are no other stages to rival its payout, playing the dungeon can become increasingly repetitive.-The comment sections on Steam for most of the promotional costume updates are a veritable maelstrom of angry players. Being a repeatedly-returning player requires extraordinary patience.-PvP can be difficult unless you're extremely good at it.Overall, if you play the game without expecting much new content to be released in a set period of time, it's a good 8/10. For those of you with less patience with the dev team, probably not the game for you.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Spiral Knights is a different type of RPG. You are a small knight who has crash landed on a strange planet and must get to safety. Once that is done you go through certain missions and delve into the clockworks, a massive underground mix of levels that are ever-changing. I have almost 700 hours into Spiral Knights because it was extremely intriguing and I would play 12 hours without even realizing it. However, the lack of content being added is saddening, especially when we get constant "prize boxes" for every 10 dollars we spend with our hard-earned money. Besides that point it can be extremely hard to level up your gear.  Going from Tier 1 gear to Tier 5 took almost 400 hours alone. However, this was before the missions gave you a free set of recipes and crafting orbs. The crafting orbs were what replaced Energy in crafting. Energy was about 500x harder to get. This game is VERY good with a group of friends (4 preferably) since the drops chances are higher and everyone gets their own loot. I do recommend this game because besides all the weak points, it is still very fun to slash, shoot, and spam bombs all around the battlefield. 8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Spiral Knights is a top-down TLoZ inspired MMO, where you go floor to floor down the Clockworks, the source of the worlds power. There are many different presets for floors, where you will find several different species of monsters ranging from slimes, wolves, robots, and Gremlins to kill and take their Crowns (currency), Heat (used to upgrade your gear), and materials. There are 3 different Clockwork tiers, with the difficulty and loot increasing as you get deeper and deeper into it. At first, you will only be able to go to the first tier and be forced to go back as you reach small towns in the Clockworks, as they serve as gates for the different tiers. As you progress in the story and upgrade your gear you will be able to access these towns and move on, with there being vendors along the way to sell you useful upgrade blueprints you cant get anywhere else. There are 4 main bosses in the game, with each of them giving tokens once you beat them, and when you get enough you can trade them for very good and useful gear, which very well may make up your arsenal when you approach endgame.The PvP is a control point mode, where you fight off the other team to take hold of 3-7 points for the longest amount of time. There are 3 different "classes" in PvP, Striker, Stealth, and Shield. Striker removes your shield for a jet boost which can get you from area to area very quickly. Stealth makes you invisible when shielding, with a small radar around you when you get close to someone. Shield amplifies your shield, making it reach around you, shielding your teammates inside it. Unfortunately you are not given any kind of gear for it, and there are not restrictions on what gear you can and cannot use. This means that those who have an extreme amount of money will use items with ungodly stats, which most can only hope to get withing a few months. The PvP is split into 3 tiers like the Clockworks, with each tier corresponding to your gear. Good luck finding a match with anything less than tier 3 Gear however, as it is extremely rare to see anyone not in the tier 3 matchmaking. Technically, this mode is not P2W, as you can buy all these items with Crowns, but it will take so long you might as well not even try. The meta is also quite bad, with only a few specific items being good, mainly a few of the Boss items, and status inflicting mist bombs. While it is possible to do well without these items, without health boosting trinkets, and ungodly unique variant weapons, you will have a tough time.Unless you have a friend or two who are already well off and have played for a good amount of time and is willing to play with you, I wouldn't even bother with this game. The devs have stopped caring about it completely, with all new content being simple reskins of cosmetic items. If you want to play Spiral Knights by yourself, be prepared to do most of it solo, and whatever you do, do NOT pay any money for energy, the games higher tier currency. This is a F2P MMO, so it only makes sense that there will be grind walls inciting you to pay real money (which unfortunately I fell trap to). The community is decent, however 90% of everyone you're going to see is people who have spent hundreds, even thousands of hours on this game from years back, who still feel obligated to "play" (aka sit in Haven (the hub world), for hours on end stalking the auction house).  Do I regret putting so much time and energy into this game? I wouldn't say so, as it has brought me many hours of enjoyment and a few short term friends along the way. However, at the current state it is in, I can't recommend playing it right now. Even now, I only ever boot up the game (which can take up to HOURS as the game doesn't update on its own, and only starts updating when you run the game, something that should have been fixed years ago) to check up on any season events going on. If you are new to this game, the first time you boot up the see Haven at dusk, covered in Halloween garb, or in a snowy wonderland at Christmas time, it is quite magical, and I've had some of the most fun just fooling around in Haven during then. For now though, stay away from this game. The population is dying and any friends you make will most likely be gone in only a few days, never to be seen again. If you do wish to play however, I can only hope you have a fraction of the fun I've had in my early days, and I wish you luck.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												PROS: +Friendly and Helpful community. Playing with kids are quite enjoyable. It's a nice break from all the salty attitude in FPS games.+Abundance of good players who could carry you through harder dungeons (or, in the context of the game; Clockworks)+Friendly UI+You may conduct in-game trading for weapons and cosmetics. Steam supports it too.+Straight forward levels with challenges, puzzles, hidden secrets, etc.+Game offers annual events and daily extra missions for optimal varity in gaming experience+Free to play+Game admins will sometimes respond to player issues by hopping in-game with you. Very nice people.CONS:-The community may be friendly, but it is often hard to communicate with the occasional players who speaks a different language, due to the lack of region lock.-Although the game encourages variety in gameplay, the same events pop up every year with very minimal changes. This means that cosmetics are not as collectible as you think.-The game will try to steal money out of your pocket at every possible corner of the street: money to revive, money for fees for selling weapons at the Auction House, money to level up your gear, and etc. Not exactly Free to Play, is it?-The game allows trading, but never encouraged. You cannot trade away cosmetics which are worn, and you cannot trade away weapons you used without a ridiculous amount of "Unbinding" fee. -Game has variety in levels, but only a select few can earn you good profit without spending too much time. This forces some players to have a very narrow style of gameplay. These specific levels established the fundamental procedures to farm for money, and the lack of content overall bores the player easily.-Sometimes expected events are overhyped, which causes a general discontent amongst the players.So, is Sprial Knights a good game? Yes, but only borderline so. There may be a great deal of friendliness to the game, but the lack of player volume and the lack of new content only bores the player.After putting some extra time into this game, I can't help but feel that there's so much more that could be done to the game that may contribute to its possible success. It's been about 3-4 years since I've started playing this game, so please, don't get me wrong. I really enjoyed it while it was good to me. I felt alive. I felt energetic. I had friends and folks I could and want to play with. The community is quite friendly, the risk/reward system of levels are well balanced, and overall, I had fun. It was one of the most enjoyable and impactful games of my adolescence. The guild system was fantastic. You could always meet new people and play with them. There was a demand for companionship and sportsmanship everywhere. The User interface is fantastic. Things takes a while to get used to, but things are always there when you need then. The life I've lived in this game is the lovliest, and the love was the liveliest. But what happened? I don't know. I can't say for sure that this is a bad game, because it really isn't. I had loved it. Were my observations also my bigotry and prejudice? Did I grow up and move away from this game genre as a whole? Why don't you play it for a bit and tell me? I'm sure you'll love it just as much as I once had.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Spiral Knights: a game that has certian charms from an explorer to a competitive player's point of view. I for one, am a collector, though only about 1/5th of the time through the (almost) 2 years playing this game.Since the start, the game was sort of hard to grasp for FTPs who like to explore the depths and missions in the game, due to the mist limit going on. Nowadays though since August 8th, 2013, with the Battle Sprite release, more and more players could play without a toll limit. They have events and items on sale, sure, yet you won't need to participate in them if you don't want to. For those of you that are though, just remember you're very kind by helping them with developing more game features and helping out any problems that need to be fixed.There's plenty of features to go through in the game without events as it's going on: Player vs player with either team vs team capping with your own selected gear and weapons for the tier in Lockdown, or a 3D bomberman styled way to battle with bombs given out, either free-for-all or team vs team in Blast Network. There's also ways to hang around with friends and socializing with new ones as you play through the game. Lastly, the biggest feature of them all, is exploring and either helping out or solo throughout the depths of the Cradle. Many monsters currently, and eventually appearing along the way, will be a task to fight on normal, advanced, or elite mode (I personally almost ALWAYS do elite mode nowadays). You may overcome obstacles on the way, though if you need help it's not too bad to call for some friends or guildmates.By visual wise, I have to say: it's very artistic and charming in a way. The effects are very good and reminds me pretty much of Bomberman people with the players/NPCs (hence the mentioning of Blast network), who can dress up and wear gear that isn't just for bombing overall (You can use gear that goes along with being a swordsman, bomber, gunner, or a mix between).There's a community of knights to talk with, in game and out game, either meeting up or talking in the Forums on the website, which tells about what's going on lately. This MMORPG bases mostly around communication most of the time, either by a normal player or a Game Master. Don't take others opinions too personally (such as the biggest topics "using Auto-Target, or AT for short, in the game"): Do what you feel is right and play the game like you want; Just don't go too far though by being too rude with other people please. Fighting negatives with negatives won't result with the best result.www.spiralknights.comAnyways, thank you for spending time with reading my review. As you play the game, soar through the planet of Cradle and be your own character and player, knight of Skylark. :)

I'll definitely rate this game 10/10!

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Been playing this game for a very, very long time. I got it near when it just released, and I was very impressed and excited about it. However, since I can't give numeral or decimal ratings, I have to choose what I think of the game now: I just can't recommend it. I'll tell you why my love has been watered down as we go.You and many other robotic knights crashed on a mysterious planet. This is no ordinary planet; the massive underground is filled with massive machines and gears that are constantly shifting levels. It's sometimes gloomy, sometimes cheery. It is inhabited with many monsters and gremlins who don't want you to explore. This place is called the Clockworks. In its center is your only hope of escape: the energy from the core.GAMEPLAYNewbies get to customize their character with various cosmetic armors and ascessories. You can change your knight's color, which affects your eye color and any parts of armors that allow change. You can also change their height.By default you start with Proto gear, which includes an armor (this covers your body), a helmet, a shield, and two weapons: the Proto Sword and Proto Gun. You are taken through a tutorial that teaches you how to kill meanies and the beginning of your story. Following the tutorial are beginner missions with AI companions to give you a taste of the game and its story before you go on your own. These missions are pretty easy to do and reward you with more weapons to help you on your journey. At the end, you are taken to Haven and you get the Proto Bomb, which is the last type of weapon (swords, guns, and bombs). Haven is located at the surface and is where the knights research and train.More missions can be done later when you are ready. These too will give you rewards. Complete a set of missions to be ranked up and move on to the next set. Ranks allow you to use better gear. Gear is ranked in stars like a movie would be rated. Most weapons can be upgraded to higher levels. Some ranks require you to have a full set of gear of a certain rank for you to continue to the next and to allow you to go down more tiers. Tiers are chunks of depths with sharp difficulty turns. There are 3 tiers in all. Missions can be replayed again and again as much as you want. You can also independantly delve down the clockworks.There's two currencies in this game (I know what you're thinking): Crowns and energy. Crowns is earned in the Clockworks or by selling things. You use them to buy equipment from shops or you can trade them for energy. Energy is used mainly for reviving yourself if you die or for buying things in the Supply Depot. The Supply Depot is where you get to look at all the things you cannot get because you got no $$$ in your wallet. Energy can be traded for crowns and bought with real money (mhm, you see the picture now).You can delve the clockworks solo or with 4 player co-op. To beat each level, you have to reach the elevator at the end of each level, which you can use to either continue going down or go back up. There's many areas to explore each level, and you can find materials to "alchemize" new weapons or upgrade weapons. You only have one emergency revive, so be careful! You can buy sparks of life to revive you again if you need to with energy, which are available in the Supply Depot to buy. Sometimes you will run into a set of levels with a boss at the end. You will seldom run into the same level twice, as the levels change constantly at set times. The elevators give you a hint on the type of level it will be by the picture and color of the picture displayed on the screen on it. For example, a haunted fortress themed level would be a castle tower with either purple or red. Purple would be a little generic, and red will usually mean the Scarlet Fortress levels. Further information on the level ahead is given to you when you go down, such as the name of the "series" (I call more specific themed places like the Scarlet Fortress [a haunted, castle-like level] a series) and an area name (Firestorm Citadel: Smouldering Steps).Near the end of the game comes the Shadow Lairs. The Shadow Lairs require a Shadow Key to enter. One key grants access for everyone in the party. These are boss levels with massive difficulty changes that make even the beginner's boss a challenge for a full party of 5 star players. On top of that are more powerful monsters and enhanced bosses. There's one for each boss. Each Shadow Lair opens the core little by little.PvP is also a thing here. In the coliseum, you can pay 200 crowns (which is extremely cheap for most players) to play Lockdown or Blast Network. In Lockdown, you can be one of three classes with their own unique abilities that replace your shield (Guardian has a massive shield that protects allies) on two randomly colored teams. All your gear can be used they aside from your shield, but their level goes down to level 1 until you're done playing. You win by capturing and controlling control points. Blast Network is Bomberman. Nuff said.The game was really fun and the boss runs were wonderfully done, but there's two evil beasts: GRINDING FOR ALL ETERNITY AND DLC. Beginners will have a blast with the game until later in the game, where upgrades are harder and take longer to do. Your gear can level up and become stronger with "heat" which acts like experience points. However, you can't just breeze through and max out your gear because they can only actually go up a level when they're at full heat and you have enough fire crystals. This is magnificent part is called "forging". There's special fire crystals for each star gear, the better ones being harder to find. 4 and 5 star fire crystals are extremely hard to find, and you need frikkin tens of them depending on the level. Even then, you have the option to use less fire crystals for a lower chance of forging or using a crapton at once to confidently move up a level. Unless you have a massive horde of crystals, you'll probably want to go with the 100% chance option all the time. Even worse, 3 to 5 star gear *require* that you level up your gear to a certain level. 5 star gear requires you to max them out (level 10 is the max), and 5 star gear is *always* slightly less strong than their 4 star counterparts until you can level them up enough for them to actually be better aside from a good charge attack, which almost never changes. It takes me about ONE MONTH or more of collecting materials, leveling up gear, and grinding the same boss levels over and over for money and loot just for ONE 5 star piece of equipment. Guess what the Supply Depot has? 5 star weapons for sale for energy. Remember what I said about occasional gear requirements in missions? R.I.P. your wallet.Guess what else? Shadow Keys cost a lot of energy. That means you better find an efficient way to earn money or pull out your wallet just to beat the game with a couple of friends. When you have nothing else to do but the Shadow Lairs, you can enjoy grinding for 600 years or lose the roof over your head. Another thing: events. Events and prize boxes. I don't need to say anything else about these. It's a tiny bit like the vicious IAP that ruins almost every mobile game you love.GRAPHICS, UI, AND PERFORMANCEGraphically, the game looks great. The gear, environment, and overall art style is really neat. The UI has no problems. As for performance, the game runs perfectly on my 5 year old Dell laptop with no upgrades on low settings. It appears to be well optimized. If I had a newer computer, it would be perfect. No strikes off here.There you have it. A great game with painful grinding. I give this game a 6.8/10, and I don't recommend it because I don't like being enslaved in grinding for years or PC games + mobile IAP. I'd also like it if I could actually do some cool stuff aside from the Shadow Lairs and getting gear as a Tier 3 player.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												This game is great and free to play? That makes it good right, well yes the gameplay and artistic style is great but I would not consider it to be great when it comes to story and replayability. This game is an MMO and is updated quite often yet there are many things wrong with it. It's a grindfest and forces you to believe that the game is longer than it actually is, once you become a vangaurd there really is nothing interesting to do. Sure you can participate in events and aquire all the weapons. But what use will those have if you already completed everything the game has to offer. There is dlc sure but I was not satisfied by it, the only reason I finished it is to get the rewards.Let's be honest, the game is not bad and has very little wrong with it. But the biggest crime this game commited is that when you understand the games cycle you will find that this game. Is really boring, the game entertained me and kept me busy. But it didn't make me want to come back to it after I finished it. There was no reason for me to care, I would come back once in a while to find that nothing had changed. I do not think this game is bad but everything comes with flaws. Do not let this review stop you from playing the game, it truly is a fun backup game when you're bored and want something different. But do keep in mind that it is not perfect just like every other game. 6/10I am sorry if this review has bad grammar or is filled with spelling mistakes, I'm swedish and have always had problems with learning new languages, I think I got the point across though.

												   This game is amazing, trust me, I've played it since 2011. I've gone through hard times, and good times. This game is a bit harder on Veterans now, and rewards new players with many free things, which I don't find fair, but that's not my decision to make. If you don't have this game, you need it. If you love MMO's, get it, RPG's, get it. This game is a must have for a fan of either of those. There are many different armors to use, from using swords, to guns, to bombs, and even some event weapons. The costumes are amazingly designed, and playing with the right people can lead to domination.    The DLC, Operation Crimson Hammer, is also amazing. It provides a new boss, new missions, and exclusive weapons. I've played since 2011 and still haven't gotten all of the exclusive items from this. Because everything in the DLC is a challenge, or a cake walk.   Everything in this game depends on your gear, play your cards right, and you can win almost anything.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Let me start by saying steam needs to incorporate a sideways thumb for the "it's not that I don't like you, you're just not my type" games. I tried this game a few year ago (2011 maybe?) and decided to give it another go recently.  This game still hit me in a weird way with pros that could be seen as cons, and in my opinion the cons that maybe could be seen as pros.  For instance, it uses a slow replenishing energy system which is depleted with almost EVERY action you take from using items in the world to crafting to runining dungeons (con) but hey, maybe people won't spend their entire day inside playing games (pro)? Let us do the list thing.PROS--I love the zelda games, almost to the point of fighting for human/machine marriage equality, and this game's style reminds me a lot of earlier games.  This made me all warm and tingly inside.-There aren't any set roles in the game, the holy trio does not exist.  Everyone can do the dps thing, tank if needed and by the gods hopefully grab the insane amounts of health that drops to keep themself alive.-The graphics are bright and cartoony, which I'm not usually all for, but it seems too many games now are trying to see how dark and bleak they can make the environment, this seemed kinda refreshing.-The combat is fast paced and fun.  Being able to switch between a gun and a sword when ever I felt like gave me the ability to strategize. (Not that strategy is needed, the game is laughably easy)CONS- (some can be seen as pros depending on how you look at it)-Ingame voice chat.  My god i hate ingame voice chat. If i wanted to hear your whiney, prepubescent voice I would join a real  voice chat program and listen to you there.  I have a feeling it was implemented to help players organize and easily communicate a strategy (again haha strategy), not to bewail that every person in the randomly genterated group doesn't have the map memorized. (which was me sometimes... What? I like exploring damnit!)----actually had a kid during a dungeon yelling at this player to hurry up and run to the portal so we could continue. You could feel the anxiety of the lost player and the pure hatred of the player rushing other along, i mean his mom was going to be home from work in 8 minutes, he HAS to finish this dungeon before that!  The best part was his squeeling COOOME ON as the other player and I decided to go retrieve our lost dungeon brother.-----The energy system. the free to play version gives you a small pool of energy that is used for every single thing you do in the game, so it depletes pretty quickly and has a slloowww regen rate.  Of course, you can use real currency to pay for more energy or pay insane amounts of in-game currency for it.-Grinding. Once you get past the T2 dungeons, you will be grinding your way from there on out.  Which is a painful experience with the energy system inplace. "Well, there is my 20 min of grinding for the day, ill be back tomorrow."

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game is really great. Lots of fun, lots of weapons, lots of enemies, lots of different game styles to choose from.This games follows the rule of 3. There are 3 types of weapons (sword, gun, bomb) to choose from. 3 types of damage, 6 families of enemies. Each family deals a different kind of damage, each family has different damage weaknesses and resistances. There are also 3 tiers to the game, with the difficulty increasing with each tier.Spiral Knights also has some RPG mechanics with a twist: Instead of leveling up your character you level up your equipment. Once your stuff reach a certain level you can upgrade them to get better stuff.The game is free and never forces you to pay, but you can always buy one of the energy packs if you feel like you're advancing too slow.All armors and helmets can be customized with accessories earned throughout the game.With Halloween, Christmas and anniversary events every year the game still sees new content from time to time and keeps a fresh feeling.P.S.I've been playing this game for 2 years now and I don't intend to stop.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
This game has in my mind one of the best artstyles out of any game on SteamI adore it, just so gorgeous. That beautiful mix of low-poly models and crisp, contrasting colours that you only ever see when you emulate a DS game in HD or something. The environments, equipment, robots and creatures feel varied and incentivised my exploration with the intent of finding yet more for my eyes to gorge on. I can't stress enough how filled with charm the visuals are. I love the inflection to the sound design too, but that's a weird thing to say. The majestic music and the way sound effects sound when navigating the UI / attacking / picking up items or whatever. It is just, satisfying and comfy??The art and sound team did such a stellar job, I hope they're doing big things somewhere nowadays.Give her a listen 


YouTube™ Video: Spiral Knights OST - Cradle 

			Views: 67,019		

			This plays when you're logging on and when you're selecting what character to use. All rights reserved to Three Rings Design, Inc.		

Now, the game itself? It hasn't been updated with any real content in a long, long time. The cash store has the game by a chokehold and there is almost no way to play the game without spending money to alleviate crazy grind. The servers are becoming barren and the game is becoming less and less well optimised as time goes on. (Not to mention some really naff gameplay changes here and there for the worse)It isn't necessarily that the gameplay is bad, it's just that the game is absolutely dead. And that is a bitter pill to swallow. There's nothing worse in my mind than wasted potential, and this game had its A-game set up for everything besides longevity. This is a free to play MMO first and foremost, focussed on teamwork and equipment progression. By that nature, you'll need to grab some friends to help you power through the content, because you're not getting through it on your own or cheaply. Cute robots are my weakness and for that reason I'm giving the game a 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
-Quick Review-Spiral knights is an MMO-dungeon crawler, unlike most MMO's that I play, This game suggests you play public games (but I just found the option that lets me solo! Thank you for letting me play my own way Spiral Knights). Additionally it automatically activates your microphone (I found out to my dismay on my second run, after I had been idly chatting with a friend on skype… and hearing an echo of my voice.) -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  From the state of the game, you get to customize your Spiral Knight, change his/her helmet make adjustments to the color, and then maybe throw on a few accessories. Once you’re finished you perform various tasks around camp to get things running again.Game Play: You play the game like a dungeon crawler, you can also choose between three different control configurations. I chose to use the keyboard and mouse; the controls seem very straightforward and natural to me. You can switch between different weapons once you buy them later in the game; you start the game out with a pistol and a sword. No complaint I see no need for any other weapons.Hopefully I don’t need to spell it out more about how the combat works, you shoot from far away with the pistol, you hit them with your sword in melee range, you block stuff with your shield, and you also have bombs that you can drop. You can also unlock, buy, and make new weapons and armor.At rank 3 you start to be informed about the different types of gear you can wear. Since it’s an MMO, I assume this will play a larger role in the game further on. At the time that I am writing this review, I reached Shadow gear (which the game so kindly provided for me as I continued down the main story line. As long as the game doesn’t force me to spend real money, I’m okay with the gear based structure for this game.Achievements: A majority of the achievements require collection of X amount of gear. There are a lot of hidden achievements that I will need to research once I get to be a higher level. Although I suspect that the game will eventually force me to team up with other players… and then let the ugly pugging commence. (Sorry, for those who don’t know: I really hate playing with people I don’t know.) Basically, my impression is that the achievements reflect the amount of time you’ve spent playing the game. I was about a third of my way through the story, and I had about a third of the achievements in the game.Price: Ah ha! This game is a Free to play! You have no real excuse for not trying it at least once. Since the game can be soloed (at least to where I’m at, one third complete) I think you can get a decent amount of entertainment out of the game, if you like dungeon crawlers, and a really simple easy game to pick up. Conclusion: There really isn’t much reason to say “don’t get this game” especially since it’s free. I keep waiting for the point in the game where it says “HA! To be continued! Now pay us money just like you did the Arcade machine when you were little!” Nothing like that yet, so regardless, I feel I’ve gotten a fair amount of entertainment out of a game I didn’t buy.No complaints, I’m enjoying the game still. (but I will always grind before I ever spend real money inside a game of any kind.)

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												A great dungeon crawler game with tons of loot and adventurous levels.If you do not like to go down in the Clockworks, you can just hang around in Haven meeting friends, or what ever you feel like doing.There are a bunch of different branches of items you can have. You can have a sword that launches a way a fiery wall of explosions, or the same with ice instead. Why not grab a sword that incinerates everything around you? Or a bomb that spawns a rabid creature? Or a gun that shoots shadow orbs or razor sharp needles? It's up to you what way you want to go!Same thing goes for the armor. There are tons of different armors. Everything from Cat looking armors to big heavy looking armors. All comes with different attributes.You can change the armors' appearance by adding different accessories to it. Shadow bombs, shining tiaras, icy wings, fiery tails, you name it!Note: This game takes a lot of time after you reach 3(star) items. You will need to find Orbs of alchemy which can take for ever to find. Or you can just buy them with the money you find in the game. Or in real life money, which will be the fastest.Conclusion: If you like delving down in a huge world of adventure and loot, this is the game for you!

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Very simple and easy to learn game. However, I found this simplicity to give it a lack of depth which made it boring after a while, but I always tend to get bored with mmo's after a while. The later introduction of Battle Sprites somewhat emulates the class systems of traditional mmo's. This is a good thing, I think. Mmo veterans expect at least something resembling a class system. Newbies should be introduced to this as soon as possible, as mmo's that don't have it are the exceptions. And it was good for the game itself to add much-needed depth. The amount of grinding required to fully level your Sprite, unfortunately, is ridiculous. Feels like a Korean mmo in that respect. The problem of a free-to-play game economy was handled well by making the cash shop currency purchasable with ingame currency, and shop currency required for crafting and adventuring. Overall, however, I find the most attractive part of this game to be its visual style.

												-Spiral Knight is like old-series of top down Zelda arcade shooter/hack n slash genre, you get to slice or blast bushes with either your melees or guns!So you start your GAMEPLAY with many quest that keeps giving you gears and gears and gears until you reach a point of free-roam, where you see all these cool gears and shiets you get to craft and BRING THEM ALONG your whole journey as you upgrade them and level yourselves.Yes, levels/stats/powers/ranks are based of from your gears, and experience in combat but not too deep in aspect.ENEMIES DESIGNS are very creative, you get slimes that just refuses to go away, and lil midgets that dodges more smarter than a goblin in those normal ♥♥♥♥♥♥ MMOs, turrets that shoots heat-seeking rockets, when these things are stacked together and provoked, you'll see danmaku everywhere!And bosses! who just have high absurd amount of hp againts your dodgingXkiting skills while using their awesome graphical skills that makes you go tripping balls.CONTROLS allows hybrid maneuver where you can use WASD and your mouse in shooting/slashing, spacebar to switch your weapon. Many players have notice the [Backstrafe] speed which are slowed, and decided to use the <^>v arrow movement keys instead to make sure they never move backward, all in order to maintain their speed, with no mouse? you get auto-aiming system that assist in your gunning/slashing. but you could use BOTH controls system.Cons:Theres none really, market inflation are solely design on popular items cause they're rare drops in grinding dungeon stage runs, since GEAR is mostly everything in your pace for this game.Lag makes your progress harder in dodging element, npc AI have the upper hand on this matter so don't think about abusing it.Grind seems tiring still so don't go over-dedicated for this game, just play it with your friends once in a while to enjoy the eb of wind.-get carried by max gear players throughout the elevator to the end of an arcade.10/10 would go sightseeing for more again while spamming ressurection sparks.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I've played Spiral Knights on and off over the past 4 years, and unlike most other people who have a lot of time in it, like I do, I'm going to recommend Spiral Knights. Hear me out, for a bit, and I'll tell you why.Let me just give a few pros:+Amazing soundtrack+Great art style+Gameplay itself is really fun.Now let's list the cons.-Grindy. And when I say grindy, I mean REALLY grindy.-"P2W"You might be wondering to yourself, "Why did you put P2W in quotes?" I'll tell you exactly why: P2W stands for Pay to  Win, which implies you really can't progress unless you pay real money. You ABSOLUTELY can play without putting single cent it: Sure, it's gonna take forever, but you really don't have to pay. As for the grinding, grinding is a bit of a staple for f2p mmorpgs. I'm not saying it's in all of them, but it usually is. Sure, Spiral Knights has a ton of grinding: but the pay out of finally being able to upgrade your equipment is oh-so satisfying.Overall, I would totally recommend this game. Definitely worth a shot, if you're willing to put the time into it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												Hmm...Well, umm...I like Spiral Knights, To keep this as short as I can because I'm sure your busy, this is the one MMO that clicked. Mabinogi is nice and WoW is fine while DC Universe Online gives you too much too soon, Spiral Knights keeps be coming back. Firstly, I love the art style. It looks wonderful. Every weapon might seem a little 'fisher price' for others tastes but there's the extra details on them to give them a battle-worn feel. Plus, there's a clear progression in how each equipment changes as it upgrades. It's like Pokemon and it's satisfying. The world seems vast and enjoyable that I think Three Rings have barely scratched the surface of. The idea of a world that is an ever changing dungeon is a pleasing idea to me. Especially the idea of you being some combination of fighter and miner. Digdug would crap himself trying to get through some of the monsters in this game. The combat is a sort of top-down dungeon crawler. If you've ever played Alien Swam, it should be familiar. The interesting thing is the weapon choices. While you have to have a shield, you can choose to fill your two weapon slots with swords, pistols and bombs. Swords are the middle ground, offering a decent amount of damage but you need to be right up close to the baddies. Bombs take the longest to get up but offer the ability to drop and then run, keeping you out of the way of damage. Pistols are weaker but they allow for far more range with your attacks, keeping distance between you and your target. On top of that, each weapon has a special damage type that could either cause more or less damage depending on enemy weakenesses and resistances. While I don't consider myu self that great at it, the combat is pretty simple but fun in this random weirdos opinion. And then there's the Battle Sprites. These are virtual pets that offer extra attacks and abilities as they grow up like an omnipresent Pokemon. They don't break the game but they are useful with currently three types: damage, poison and healing. They don't get in the way and can actually be ignored if you want, which is fine by me but I like that the Battle Sprites give you boons to attacks or defence as they grow on top of boosting their own attacks.Now, it sounds great right? The issue is how Three Rings pays for all this...The Energy system demands money from you or you will go insane. Energy is an extra currency that works over the top of Crowns (Spiral Knight's money). Energy buys extra lives when you die, upgrades, various special weapons and more. Also, it's never really given to you for free. You either pay for it in Crowns, which is found within the game by simply playing, or with hard cash. Other free to play games are happy for you to just chip in a few coins their way occationally if you feel like it. Spiral Knights demands that you throw them cash in order to get the best equipment possible without grinding for half an eon to get enough Crowns. At lower levels of the game, this is harsh grinding if you don't have the cash to pay for Energy. To add to the issue, the levels are not that varied. They're not bad, they just repeat a lot. So, in order to get that cash, you have to run through the game over and over and over and over. If your gear isn't good enough, you'll die over and over, losing any heat (Experience, used for upgrading weapons) you've earned. You'll keep your Crowns but it's still no fun to be crushed into the dirt over and over just for some game essencials. To add to this, the game demands that you have a certain level in all of your equipment before going forwards. Yes, this shows that the game's difficulty is about to spike upwards and you'll need the ugrade across the board but the issues with grinding come to slap you right across the face. If you don't grind though the same 10 or 20 levels, you cannot continue. I cannot recomend this for casual or general players. It's enjoyable but I can imagine a lot of players just giving up at the first equipment check point. I would recomend giving it a go to see how else to make an MMO but I can't say that the Business Model for this game is the best compared to it's competitors. If your not afraid of some awful grinding, you can find some enjoyable gameplay here. Oh! Three Rings? Make a Single Player game based on this! It would be awesome! I want to see more of this world.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Spiral Knights.....what have you turned into. Spiral Knights is a top-down, 2.5D (Can you call it 2.5D? Maybe it's more 3D than anything...) P2P Er I mean *Cough* F2P MMORPG where you run around and kick some monster butt like you did back in the days of the SNES with Legend of Zelda...but with a much better combat system (you would think). Lets start with the basics.(Read farther if you please. Basic Synopsis- Casual gamer=SK is a good choice. Want more polish? Keep looking.1; Graphics 7.5/10 Not exactly the greatest but not the worst either. What really makes this game so inviting is it's art style which is btw AMAZING! Everything looks awesome even though textures, models, and shading aren't top notch.2; Community ?/?I never really had anything to do with the community...maybe played every once 'n a while with strangers but I never really traded with anyone and that crap. Maybe someone else could answer that for you Mr/Ms viewer of my review (Really? I had to break the 4th wall?) 3; Soundtrack/SoundEffects 8/10The sound track is really good. It has this feel of going on an adventure and discovering things like what a game like this should be. Every level has a nice theme that plays well with it, from volcanic forests to frozen devilite business offices to a ruin full of slimes. The sound effects are good too. Not much else to say for the sounds.4;Leveling system.... Doesn't even need a rating....First off, WHY DOES TAKE ME A YEAR JUST SO I CAN GO UP ONE GOD DARN RANK!?!?!? Before that I was zipping through the ranks like it was nothing! Then I got stuck trying to get to 4*, and I had to play for what like ages just so i could get my 5* armor.  I'm not saying that having to work to get to your rank is bad, but they way it has been implemented in this present edition of SK is ridiculous. Before (I'm sure most of you already know this who have been reading the reviews for hours now) the game had you collect heat (exp) that leveled up you're gear. What happened when it capped? IT LEVELED UP! WOW! IT CAN LEVEL UP! What happens now? You cap...and have to play for another 3 months just so you can get some stupid fire cyrstals to level up your gear BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE! NOT ONLY DO YOU HAVE TO GRIND FOREVER, YOU HAVE A CHANCE TO FAIL IN THE FORGE AND HAVE TO DO IT ALL OVER AGAIN! Isn't that just the sweetest thing ever.....NO! And the only thing you can do to make it work is have so much fire crystals for a 100% chance rate of working. I hate it so much. Oh and if you think I'm lying about spending months leveling up you just wait until you're Knight Elite...you just wait.  5; Gameplay 8/10The gameplay is pretty solid. Basic 123 slash with pistol and a choice of using an explosive (which are overpowered if used with the right loadout). You can dogde and shield bash and defend and is relativley solid. Now, don't get GAMEPLAY confused with "Difficulty." In reality, the game isn't that hard, and it functions well. Now...for the really negative stuff.6; "Difficulty" 2/10.....Where do I start...Hm...I know. You know those things called defenses on your armor, like elemental defense, pierce defense, shadow defense, those things? Yeah um...those don't matter at all. If you play the game on normal you "should" be fine, advanced you might need some help, and expert you're going to need a really good loadout with lightning reflexes and friends who have a ton of sparks (I'll get to sparks soon enough). Now, why did I say "should" for normal....well here's the thing.....All difficulties, have the same amount of enemies....and there are ALOT of enemies...and they do the SAME amount of damage no matter what difficulty...the difficulty just decides how much health they have. They do the same amount of damage because of the game's elevator and depths. The elevator is your level transition, and you're depths are you're "difficulty." That little slide bar does nothing except make a tier 1 gremlin take 3 hits instead of 2 and alter the spawn rate of certain drops. So you will constantly be having to fight what looks like 15 zombies at all times that do the same amount of damage at that specific depth. Forgot to mention why you're defenses don't matter...they don't matter because of what has just been stated and, you don't just face the enemies specified in the level, you fight ALTERED enemies as well. So instead of fighting a Elemental only Gremlin, you'll fight an Elemental Shadow Gremlin. O_o What? But...I have the armor? Nope. Doesn't matter. The only difference is instead of taking half a health bar they take like a quarter. The only thing I have to say is awesome is being able to live with 1% health. If you are MLG enough to play this game with 1% health I salute you! You can't get 1 shotted by enemies because of this, all you need is above 1% to land in that "Crisis mode."7; Enemyvariaty/Enemies  8/10-1/10 Lets just get this straight, there are alot of creative enemies with alot uniqueness to them. They are pretty darn cool. You fight little devils, zombies, ghost cats, horse statues, bats, slimes, wolfs, etc. This game has a cool list of enemies! Right? Right? RIGHT?!?! Yeah....the'yre cool till rank Knight Elite. Then they get kind of challenging....next rank...Forget about it. These enemies are so freaking annoying. And it wouldn't be a problem IF YOU COULD CONNECT YOUR 3RD STRIKE WITHOUT HAVING TO BACK THEM INTO A CORNER! BTW YOU CAN'T, CAUSE YOU'RE THE ONE IN THE CORNER! Devilites suck royally, I hate them, Gremlins suck aswell cause they can dodge and crap have sheilds on their back and stun you with every hit they can hit you, zombies just have really powerful strikes, ghost cats are annoying cause they fly all over the place, wolvers are the only one's free of scrutiny, good dogs, slimes are bull, bats are cheap shotting little jerks, robots are broken, and turrets will kill you more than any other enemy if you go farther than Knight Elite. Let me go in depth for you all... Zombies can do a pounce attack, that will literally♥♥♥♥♥♥you're health bar to 1% if you do not have the right armor (which you probably don't and they are all over the place), Ghost cats fly here there every where and can't hit for the life of you, and if you hit 4* area not only do they fly around and bite, but they shoot really slow pellets of death, and fake you out like you're playing some strange version of Street Fighter 4 Ultra Whose Gives A Crap 2.5D Top Down Edition! It's ridiculous! Oh wait, that title actually belongs to the robots! The robots, are you're bane. Everyone's bane. Why? They are the PVE equivilant to you'reself. Lockdown is PVP, this is PVE. And knowing what most people know is that the computer can READ YOU'RE VERY THOUGHTS THROUGH YOUR KEYBOARD/GAMEPAD/MOUSE! It's either the robots play smart, or they decide to go #YOLOSWAG (<----- is gay btw ;) ) and beat you to death. Another thing, Hit...Stun????? REALLY???!?!? Every time you get hit, you take hit stun. In the middle of an attack? Don't worry! We'll completley interupt you mid swing and take half your health! Seriously? I thought this was going to be like zelda where you open chests and go DUH DUH DDUUUUUHHH!!! I had no idea that this game would take things from fighting games!?!?! Granted hit stun is in games and they work. But why does it not work here? No invincibilty frames. None. Nodda. Zilch. Correction, you have what seems to be .5 seconds of Invulnerability before you can get whacked again. So in a sense....You have none! What's really funny is the standard enemies ARE HARDER THAN THE BOSSES THEMSELVES! The enemies are unpredictable, while the bosses have set patterns and can be memorized. I personally think this game should have been a game where you go on a boss run all the time. Basic synopsis- If you're a casual gamer, then this game is great for you. If you're a gamer who likes a little more polish, keep looking.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												PROS-It's a really cute game with a nice art style.-Worth playing for a while.-Not as P2W as when it first came out.CONS-The world is called Cradle and it has different layers to it, down to the core. The world and setting has potential, but the dungeon system gets repetative after a bit. It would be much better if it was like other MMORPGs, where there's a vast world to explore.-There's a microtrasaction item (usually a box and key) that comes out every so often. It unlocks an item that customizes your character. It's similar to gambling in CSGO and TF2. I've never bought it before. The only problem is that not much development is put into the game and seeing that that's the only thing that gets updated month after month is disappointing.-There's no way to move the camera and jump.FINAL NOTES-It's not for everyone though. I wanted to play it with multiple friends over the years and many of them immediately refused to play based off the pictures. -I hope this game gets remade because I'd love to see a better version of it. It has potential. Add in jumping, a moveable camera that's also not so far out, a vast world rather than dungeons, skills, classes, races, more towns, jetpacks, things to do other than fighting, etc., and I think a lot of people would enjoy it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Here's my opinion about SK: PROS:- Great intro, one of the best I've seen so far.- The art style in this game is really good and unique. It's like a combination between Legend of Zelda and Chibi.  - Great, atmospheric music.- Solid gameplay.- Friendly community.- Shadow Lairs.- Intriguing story. (Can't wait for the other rank missions!)- Can be really fun when playing with friends.- It is indeed a F2P. You can obtain most of the weapons and the equipment and even cosmetics by paying no money. But it'll get harder. Trust me, it will.  CONS:- After you become a Vanguard, things can get pretty dull.- Game encourages you to grind. And by that, I mean a LOT of grinding. - Connection problems. (Note: if you're from Australia or somewhere in Asia, expect a lot of trouble playing this game.)- Can sometimes get boring.- Not much activity when it comes to content.- Price boxes. A CRAP-TON of Costume price boxes.- SEGA. Crap.FINAL VERDICT:I'll give this game a 8.5/10.It's not a flawless gem, but it's a solid game that can bring you lots of joy.And while I don't really play SK that much nowadays like I once did before (problably it has to do with the lack of content and school, of course), I can say that Spiral Knights has a special place in my heart.Met lots of great people, had tons of fun, joined a great guild (League of Gunners) and so on.So yeah, that's pretty much my opinion about it.I know it's not really detailed, but whatever.Thank you for reading!Yours truly,Mordekai the Summoner (Siliuser in SK)P.S: To all of my friends I've met in SK and are reading this,        Thank you and love you all, fellas :3. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .UPDATE: 13th of April, 2016 (I know, a bit late announcing this news.)Spiral Knights has now been bought by Gray Havens (a company formed by former employers of OOO). Spiral Knights has been finally released from the greedy clutches of SEGA.Let's hope for the best for Gray Havens and may them bring this once fun game back to it's former glory.We are counting on you, Gray Havens!

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												It was a game that was fun at first. For maybe 3 or 4 hours. Back when it started it was much simpler, though had a lot of pay to play in it. only doing 10 levels a day for free wasn't enough to accomplish anything substantial. But when you start you think it's all good and fun. But after you get to say 3 star gear, you start to notice the game has nothing else. You basically did everything that is in the game. After that its just rinse and repeats, and an endless grind fest of doing the exact same thing over and over again. The only thing different after that is the boss battles. And even those add an amount of new content to the game that only lasts about 5 seconds. Once you beat Vanaduke all thats left is collecting costumes and accessories and playing a dress up game. And as a final note, the Dev team is absolutely god awful. By far one of the all time worst support teams I have ever seen in my entire life. They basically arent even a support team, they're just there to make you think you will get support only to tell you days or even weeks later that what you did is something they wont help you with, and basically give you the finger and say live with the mistake you made. -A once former player, who saw the horror of how terribly flawed this game is far too late.
