number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This is a torn decision for me, as I've played this game for quite some time. I've watched it grow and change with the addition of missions, guild halls, Hall of Heros, and of course...the bleeding heat system. More on that later though. For those who wanted a quick list of pros and cons here's my list.Pros  B-E-A-utiful world/Appearence. Honestly, the art style of everything from enemies to your sword is simply astounding.  Very unique soundtracks; Ominous in the dark woods and grave yard, cheery in treasure vaults, etc. This is my favorite part of the game acctually, to the point where I even bought the tracks on I-tunes. (Gloaming Wildwoods 4 life) Brilliant lore from history of the realm to the descriptions on items, small feature thats fun to look into.  Great community; come for the music, stay for the people, you guys rock. Easy to get into, not much of a learning curve, save a tricks that are hard to replicate. TF2 Hat included PVP is challenging and flows wellCons  Grindy: With the new heat system, you will have to replay levels to 'heat up' weapons, then replay them so you can get enough in game currency to buy (or just be lucky enough to find) the right crystals so that you can even continue to upgrade your things, just so that you can you guessed it Replay levels to do it again until you can finally afford to upgrade to better things.  Repeditive: While there is a plethera of enemies to fight, it isn't long before you can figure out how to deal with a certain faction very easily. And overlap (Or having two kinds of enemies such as Jellies and gremlins) is usually prescripted, so you can always know what you're facing. Not exactly bad for everyone, but the feeling of 'what could possibly be waiting for me next?!' is gone. You already know. Boss battles: Many of the boss battles are simply: (Wait for boss invincibility to wear off -> Hit boss -> Wait while he hides and a few bad guys appear ->  Repeat.) Though to their credit, most if not all of them have thier invincibility toggled by YOU with some sort of trick/gimmick.  Lack of content in updates: Most of the updates reccently have been a simple reskin behind a 5$ price tag of a "Prize box". They add very little into the game, aside from some more artistic things such as confetti, snowballs, alternate uniforms, cosmetic items, etc... They did add a few cool guns reccently though! ...After a year or so.  Little help for newer guys: With the way missions work, most of the mid and lower level missions are ever replayed after they are beaten, making it extremely hard to find a party and usually making new guys resort to acctually asking around for help.This game really is a artisitic experience that's AMAZING if you play it with friends. Though there is a point around3-4* where most players feel frustrated out of the tedious nature of replaying certain areas. It does take a small amount of paitience to play, but this game is breathtaking to me everytime I enter Haven. Give it a shot and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I'll have to say, this game is extremely easy to adapt to when playing, but I found it to be extremely grindy unless you have real money, and then its a serious piece of cakewalk.In recent updates, they have given more ways to stick you behind the passing line for things such as Tier 5 gear and even upgrading levels on your gear, by putting a new long and dreadful leveling system and forge (which are new features as of now from this game being out since June 14, 2011). Energy is mainly from purchasing with real money, which from that, energy is needed for crafting (and lots of it), and for leveling up gear (again, lots of it).Nothing really big has been additioned to the game, its all the same constant going down floors upon floors of adventuring, with nothing more than that (besides the PvP which is more like minigames).To be honest, im surprised it has so many people active on it, with all sorts of restrictions to those who dont have physical money to spend in this game, I have a spectacularly horrid time doing anything in the game now due to these new restrictions, since im forced to stay with the same leveled gear that I cannot actually level up without grinding for days, or spending real money.Key words, folks: Real money.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Kinda decent f2p mmorpg that has no class limitations(hooray!)(and that game where i drained too much hours...)Community: In PvE, you may encounter friendly ppl(i managed to even encounter person that i love :o), while in PvP mostly complainers(those who complain about AT&T releasing too much of 1st in battle xD) or persons that make you turn into complainer.(As always!)Main review part:Graphics: Everything looks kinda pretty, but performance is not what expected for java and openGL...(8/10)Gameplay: SK features huge choice of equipment, which adds variety to the gear and gameplay itself(like you can use guns, or bombs, or swords.. or 2 of those... or all 3 xD) But because this game features grinding in big quantities you may get bored(or may not if you do co-op with your friend(s))(8/10)Controls: In order to rekt m8s you need to change much(like binding weps to keys)(8/10)Setting: Kinda variable even if its supposed to be under ground.(10/10)Story: It's kinda interesting but begins to be rly interesting only when OOO decides to release new missions xD(like those new levels featuring herex 'n stuff)(8/10)Late game playability: This game features much equipment/accessories/stuff that will make you grind it to get it. Also getting last prestige badge which can take up to 5 months.(7/10)Overall rating: This game can be very good if you have friends and you're patient, but if not then it's not for ya... anyway this game doesn't cost a penny, so better try it out!Rank: A (8,2/10)P.S. review got updated at 30.10.15 and game's rank reduced.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a MMO that plays like Diablo on fast forward. But this hack-and-slash RPG action is tempered by a spiteful pricing system that seems determined to stop you playing just as you’re starting to have fun.The story of this game is that members of the Spiral Knights stranded on an alien planet, it’s our mission to hunt for the materials needed to get the Order’s spacecraft up and running so we can return home. That means fighting through The Clockworks: a series of layered dungeons leading to the core of the planet.The Clockworks are vast, and full of monsters that vary according to the theme of each level. Forest areas contain wolvers and other wild creatures, while electric zones will have more robotic foes. Of course levels can have combined family mosters and statuses. Each level is full of spike traps, turrets and "danger rooms"Each Knight can carry two weapons at a time (you can buy extra weapon slots at the NPC market in exchange for energy), melee or ranged, and switch between them at will. Controlling your knight couldn’t be easier. A quick click will swipe or fire your weapon, you can hold down the button for a charged attack or press X to trow up a shield who will protect you for any damage on any side, but the shield can break and it has to recharge and you have to wait some time. From the safe city of Haven, you can form a party of up to four knights, dive into a clockworks and immediately start your hunt for items. Every reward feeds back into the complex levelling system.Progression in Spiral Knights is all about crafting. The level of your armour determines the depth you are allowed to reach. Higher tier weapons can be bought at massive prices, but it’s much more sensible to make them. If you don't have the materials you need you have to go the to NPC who trades tokens for materials.In the past In Spiral Knights, everyday actions such as pressing a button on an elevator, crafting new items and reviving your knight all cost you energy but this has changed and now every player doesn't need to wait 24 hours for energy to regenerate or buy more of it.Spiral Knights is fast, accessible and fun until the spiteful pricing system pops up to punch you in the face.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Spiral Knights....well where should i begin...first, i was not sure if i UPvote it or DOWNvote it here coz there is nothing for "BETWEEN" here...Spiral Knights (in short now SK) is not a bad game at all, the grafic is pretty, the style like a good hack n slash game (unlike other online games, you attack by yourself and not Autoattacks). SK has a funny gameplay and also good style in gaming.But the big and really very MAIN bad thing about this game are the "lacks of usefull updates". The sample can you see by myself, let me explain:-Im a Gunslinger and use my stuff i own now over 2 years coz i still wait that new gear i COULD use comes in...and 2 years are a very very VERY long time where you get boring about this game...It gives updates but this ones are not very use full, mostly an "recolor update from the whatthehellknows-version of an gear it already gives" - and that only in a cosmetic way. Other updates are pretty much useless if you saw them for one day...So at the end: you -CAN- play SK, its a pretty GOOD game BUT if you finished ALL, its DONE - and there is no hope a good update will come fix this.So if you play MMOs like Guild Wars 2 or like, you should give up SK after you finished SKs "Last Mission" coz unlike other MMOs, there is nothing more to play for...-------------------------------------------------------------------------------EDIT (12.04.14 - Day of the Gunner Update):And they finally bought out the gunner update after over a year of waiting. But what is it? Its sadly to say but...even the Gunner update are just reskined WEAPONS with other kind of dmg output. Like the normal Blaster now with shadow/ele/pec dmg and other weapons like a shadow dmg-Autogun.They also brought out now new armors/helmets but you must get down in the dungeon to get the recieps for them (the guns too).For NEW players i say maybe nice thing, for the real OLD players its a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ OOO really wants that OLD players which plays this game over 3 years now, do all over again from as good as the beginnign to get the new stuff? No, honestly. I dont do all over again. I -AM- 5 star high-end gear gunslinger and i really DONT GO and SEARCH for the recieps down in the dungeon again to get a (maybe) better armor or like.I dont farm all the stuff again coz SK has a real farming problem, a real big one...Sorry OOO, you know how to disapoint people in the worst way you ever could...

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												This is going to be a short review.Spiral knights is 3rd person MMO.In it you go climb down one level at a time, clearing it.While it does get really repedative (Which is my main problem with the game) the community is really friendly and the game is pretty challenging. (Which I consider to be a good thing but some people might disagree)Lets cut to the chase, Spiral knights is a game for people who can grind for hours or just have the money to spend.The game is just your normal P2W MMO.Although you can get most items by grinding, it will most likely take you hours or days for a single item. While the difficulty spike does rise drastically, SK keeps it fair and is pretty managable if you can play well.While all the things above are true there is also a great deal of unique items and events each year.The comunity is a very pleasant one, although it doesent exactly make up for the game's problems.The game is appropriate for each audiance as it does moderate it's chat. I honestly find myself sighting heavily each time I need to make a new item. It takes so much time and effort to grind in this game.I do not recommend it unless you find yourself having too much money and not knowing what to do with them.

												Spiral knights is a great game for those of you that like games that you can get bored of and come back to easily, but sometimes it punishes you, because with every update that spiral knights gets it becomes harder to progress, and there is a  wall that you will encounter eventually in progression to where you either need to grind your heart out, (hence getting bored of and later coming back to) or pay to skip it. Posted: September 27, 2014
												On the outside, Spiral Knights comes across as some kind of childs Diablo. It starts out fun but soon becomes sadistic. The developers seem to have attempted to create an A-RPG that sticks out from others. Upon doing so though, they left out some important qaulities, whilst also ruining the ones they kept. The game is very unrewarding and requires more grinding than even the most hardcore of MMO's. I suspect they thought by doing so, it would encourage more microtransactions. Clearly that's not the case judging by the low player base. The game had a lot of potential but ultimately becomes a repetative chore early on. 55/100

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I've played a lot of this game, way more than I would have liked to in retrospect. And I sit here wonder only what could have been. My initial attraction to the game was through its gameplay reminicent of top-down zelda games and its art style because, I admit, im a sucker for cute♥♥♥♥♥♥ And while I frequently reminice of my days of old when the game was still fresh and new to me, I today am only disilusioned and disenfranchized to it all. I'll start by getting the good out of the way.As I said the gameplay is reminicent of earlier zeldas. There are a variety of damage and armor types as well as different enemy factions with strengths and weaknesses in acordance to these types. The enemy types are nicely varied and require different tactics to them. There are swords, guns, and bombs to use and equip. The arcade is essentially a sandbox element where you trek through different randomized levels. And there is good fun to be had when you take your first steps into Cradle. Then you hit it, the massive brick wall called "end game". A herculian task of overcoming frustrating RNG and tedium to get the 2nd highest level armor, then tripled that for the highest quality. Now that might not sound so bad, I mean reallly good gear should be worked for right? Well the thing is that its required to progress through the game. It's not fancy gear you can choose to get, you must get a full set of certian quality gear in order to progress through the story as there are missions that quite literally only serve as a gear check. And then you see the energy bar in the bottom corner taunting you to spend some cash to make the pain stop.After smashing your head against said brick wall for hours on end, or simply paying to make the pain stop, you are introduced into an end game world of freakishly overpriced fashion items and RNG prize boxes. This is a game where the endgame is cosmetic items, but due to the abhorent RNG and rarity of these items, they cost upwards of 20$-100$+ of real money. You can spend in game currency to buy premium currency (energy) which is whats often used for trading of these accessories, good luck getting anywhere if you dont plan to grind one single level and one single boss for all eternity. So unless you have enough money to smash your way into this impenetrable market, the accessory trade is strictly for veterans and no one else. By the time you have the end game gear, you have already done most of everything this game has to offer. That deceptive climb to the top was just padding. All but the shadow lairs which are the games only end game content that a regular player would probably enjoy. But those have an up front cost of 1800 (~20$) energy just to get a key to play one. And these lairs are just altered versions of already existing boss levels. The plot of the game is "intrigue" and thats it. You crash land on a random planet made of clockwork and machinery. Your goal is to get to the center of the planet, open up its core, and use its energy to get your space ship up and running again. Except years later, nothing has happened. Presumably all the knights were content opening prize boxes and killing giant jelly cubes to give any ♥♥♥♥♥ towards finding a way home. The plot doesnt move. At all. The core is just one giant carrot on a stick maguffin used to justify you even playing the game. The planet itself barely gets any expanded lore and when it does, its just there to justify new grindy content. Speaking of which, most if not all the content that gets added is a massive ♥♥♥♥ing chore after the first couple of playthroughs. But if you want the new weapon or armor that gets added with it, you will be redoing it nearly hundereds of times. When you dont get blessed with grind feasts, you get prize boxes attached to microtransactions so if you want the new fancy accesories, you gota pay up one way or another.PvP? Unless you plan on spending millions of crowns (in game currency) just for stat buffs on each of your weapons, then  you will be at a huge disadvantage. What I loved about this game is still very much there. The gameplay, the art style, the aesthetic, just the general feel. It's all there. But it could have been so, so much more. It could have progressed in really unique and interesting ways, it could have added meaningful content to the game to keep it fresh. But for now at least, OOO seem content to slapdashing prize boxes every so often to cash in while holding grindy content updates hostage despite being ready months ago. There is enjoyment to be had in the first moments of the game, but once you hit that wall, its pretty much that from there on. Thank god the community is still pretty awesome.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												For the most part, the game is ok. You go through dungeons, level up your gear and rank up into harder areas, allowing for better gear. But it soon becomes apparent that there is a massive paywall to advance. Although it can be avoided, this leads to IMMEASUREABLE amounts of grinding the same either bosses or Arcade levels constantly to either get enough of the currency, find any orbs required to ccraft new gear to advance to the higher ranks and finding the ridiculous amount of crystals needed to level up your current gear 10 times so you can buy new gear... and the droprates of all of these things is so low you can go through 10s of hours without actually having found a single one.Another turnoff is that unless you already have them, there are 5 now impossible to get achiements, meaning you can't begin this game and aim to get 100%.The final downfall of this game though... is there is pretty much no endgame content at all, which hasn't changed for years, and very likely won't change any time soon, or possibly even at all, so once finished it may just seem really pointless trying to continue.In all seriousness, this game... if you like this sort of genre and you are going in with some friends, or you are great at making online friends, this game can be a lot of fun regardless of the insane grinding as the community is actually very nice for the most part. Although it has a  redeeming feature of its friendly casual atmosphere;  it can get insanely boring and painful to even bother, ...so I can't recommend this game. Should you play Spiral Knights...? It's up to you... either try it out for yourself, or just leave it, If it doesn't look very good to you, you will not like it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Ultimately, I'd encourage you to give Spiral Knights a go as you'll know before you've expended your first 100 points of mist energy whether you want to keep playing. The question of whether you'll have the strength I lacked to grind your way out of the constrictions of the energy system is another question entirely. If you treat the game as a dip in/dip out sort of affair, then I think it's possible to really enjoy it.

It's up to you... either try it out for yourself, or just leave it, If it doesn't look very good to you, you will not like it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												A great F2P game, the game itself is great, with the storyline being where you can choose to pay attention to it, or just do the missions. The game itself is still in development with multiple updates having changed it from its original self, and I can only say that it's a good thing.There are 3 ways to fight, bomb, gun, and sword. Each one of these has its own perks. Guns can pack devastating status effects, fire several shots at once, and take enemies out at a distance (though with the way rooms are designed, pure gunning can be hard, but satisfying). Swords are just that, swords, they are the melee weapon of the game, some are your basic BFS (big fat sword), others are speed slicers, and others are status weapons for specific areas. The only downside to using a sword is that you have to usually be in the thick of the enemies to do the damage needed, and can put you at a disadvantage at times when needing to flip a switch, though the game itself provides jars to throw at the switches usually in case you pure-sword.Bombs are my personal favorite, while pure bombers are rare, they can be devastating when they are fully upgraded. Bombs come in a few different types, combat controlling, status inflicting, damage dealing, and shard. Combat controlling usually are the gravity bombs, which pull all enemies into the same spot for a bit before exploding, great for rooms with large amounts of monsters. Status inflicting bombs don't do a lot of damage, but the effect they do can greatly ease a fight, especially the frost bomb that freezes ALL enemies in their tracks. Damage bombs are just that, they focus on pure damage, they usually have quite a bit of knockback and are great for packed rooms. Shard bombs are multiple explosion bombs that come in a few different types that I won't go super in depth for. The downside of the bomb is that while other weapons have a basic attack and a charge, bombs only charge, so bombs can take an incredibly long time to charge without any perks, and you are vulnerable while charging.A great game overall, and its randomized floor system means you hardly ever do the same run twice.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												By all means I shouldn't be recommending this game.But here I am.I guess things are best seen from the beginning.I may bash Spiral Knights, but I love this game and have no idea what I'm going to say from here on.Please understand, I have trouble starting this review.  I've played this game for 4 years now, I've never put this kind of committment into a game until Spiral Knights.  I was in 8th grade and found this gem when browsing Steam.  Let's start here.My download speeds were horrid (and still are), every game I downloaded was a committment.  I was immediately graced with this bright, cheerful music.  The title page loaded in, and I signed in through Steam (can't forget my first login), and I began my trek.  I designed this cute little knight, or so I thought.  I gave him a nice dark blue color, and unknowingly selected the fancy color pallet, which sort of disgusts me now.  I had three options; Helment(3), Armor(3), and Color(not counting).  He was my little hero, and I fell in love with the aesthetics of the crash site.  I again was immursed with the soundtrack, and loved the bright and colorful environment.  It felt open, I was free.  Free to do what?  Hell if I knew, but this felt so good.That was 2011.I can't help but wonder what went so wrong with this little gem.  All I see now are costumes and reasons to invest realworld money in the game.  I want those days back.  That's our society, isn't it?  The constant wanting of our innocence, but nobody can grant these things.I was around 400 hours in and it was 2012.  I miss these days, Crimsonhammer was just released.  People complained of how OP the new weapons were.  Me?  Oh, I couldn't have cared less of which weapon was the best, I had my jolly little brigade, and we would delve into T2 of the clockworks, using the last of our Mist Energy on a single revive, as the living would desperately sprint from body to body, awakening our corpses to fight again.This is not to say I didn't care of Crimsonhammer, but I had my little brigade, and I was content.  The grind was beautiful, and I could play this game forever, fighting my favorite boss, Roarmulus.  I never understood why nobody seemed to like these two.  In my messed up head, they were so beautiful.  I couldn't help but grind them, not because I had built solid Elemental Damage, but because my Fireburst Brandish had an itching for cogs that I was too eager to fulfill.I specifically remember a conversation at the end of the T2 clockworks with some knight who had been a tremendous joy to delve with.  We would go back and forth for what must have been half an hour, discussing our experiences and dissapointments with Spiral Knight's blatant abandonment of F2P players (Crimsonhammer) (I was still F2P).I really don't want to continue, the more I type, the more I remember.  My point is that this game holds tremendous sentimental value, but nothing I can say will ever change its longevity.That little brigade and I went our seperate ways.  I only have contact with one, and he and I have become more distant with each passing week; I guess it really hurts that I never said goodbye to any of them.  I just dissapeared and my young mind was attracted to newer and better? games.This has been something looming over my head for around 2 years now, and I couldn't imagine a better time to look back and remember the past.  This is the season to be thankful.You know, with  Black Friday    ...err Turkey Day on the horizon.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												This is the best free to play MMORPG I've ever played.  I play this game direct from the website itself (www.spiralknights.com/play), that's why it looks like I haven't played much.  This game incorporates a number of themes smoothly into a fun adventure for gamers of all types.  This is a cooperative game that allows you to make friends and help them out, has a puzzle aspect in the levels, and the arcade portion of the clockworks is a genuine different adventure every day.  As new updates come out the game gets even better.  Updates aren't too far spaced and the new content is usually great.In conclusion:  This is a great game that is really free to play if one puts in the effort.  Don't take for granted the cartoony/cute graphics, this is a genuine challenge that is worthy of even advanced gamers.  Try it.  See if you like it.  From an achievement you even get a nice TF2 hat.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												I'm still surprised I'm on the verge of sinking 200 hours into what must be nothing more than "the game that places the spiral sallet helmet into your TF2 backpack." Spiral Knights is one of the most enjoyable "MMO" experiences I've ever had. I have a list of complaints about this game- the biggest being that Three Rings has been alienating the guild feature for so long with a small roster of recolored furniture and not even a ♥♥♥♥ing bulletin board to communicate a single message outside of the guild announcement. Also the fact that the game, despite appearing in our Steam inventories, somehow does not boast the ability to place a ♥♥♥♥ing single item in our Steam showcase (for a game that relies heavily on cosmetics, this is unacceptable).But I'm going to give you the most unbiased, quickest review I can give this game. I can absolutely see why people don't enjoy it, but the idea of a top-down "Zelda" (although it would help to have more puzzles and hazards) MMO is so appealing to me, I can't resist. The crafting system is fair and allows for a lot of replay value in the fact that you are pretty much never done "needing" equipment (or costumes, for pea♥♥♥♥♥). Not sure how I feel about the fact that an alternate currency, "crystal energy," can be bought for such a significant amount of crowns and a low amount of cash. I love having a guild, decorating it, and inviting users to enjoy the game alongside us- even though the guild feature is seriously lacking in some departments and the people at Three Rings need to take a ♥♥♥♥ing clue but I'm willing to forego this for the sake of bringing you what you need to know. The game updates once a month (sometimes twice), and these are actually pretty significant updates by the way (they tend to bring back "events" here and there for the users to enjoy). The music is alright, not a huge hangup of mine. Gameplay might seem redundant to some people, but there are lots of ways to keep it fresh (I recommend playing with your friends or randoms at all times in order to do this), but a little detour by yourself doesn't hurt.I haven't dabbled in the arena or anything like that very much it all (it really doesn't interest me at the moment). From what I can tell, a lot of the lategame is spent doing old missions or playing the arcade mode in order to secure crowns and crafting "orbs" which appear randomly in the dungeon chests- and allow you to upgrade your equipment. If you're going to play this game, you need to look at the wiki at some point and decide your armor early. Despite the fact that the game draws a lot of attention to the wiki, I believe there should be some kind of projection ingame that tells you what you need to expect pursuing each armor path (but the hall of heroes does help (they don't neglect this idea as much as I spin my yarn)).I see a lot of enjoyment in this game and I believe there is a lot of potential as well. If you're on my friend's list or see me booting it up at any point, I encourage you to do the same. Three Rings manages to still pay attention to their fans- despite what you may think for a game of this background-prestige, and, from what I've seen, create polls to decide on what changes should be made in the longterm. A big reason I play this game is because of the aesthetic of it- it's a very cute game. Reminds me of circa 80s RPGs like Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest in the fact that you play as tiny armored creatures of some kind. Give the game a chance, though. If you see this, hit me up: my username is Pode (same as here), and I'm the guild master of "The Trojan Express."

content:
Posted: May 20, 2012
												20/05/2012 C.E.This is a game for all people. Its main aim is teamwork, as you can do anything alone in this game, but it would take MUCH longer. For example, doing a level by yourself would take 30minutes, but with others helping, it would take 10 minutes instead. I really recommend this game, except for the part where elevators charge you to use them.20/07/2014 C.E.This game now sucks. Ever since the main developer (Nick) left, the events have all been recycled constantly. With no new ideas, the game is stagnating faster than ever before. The only new updates are purely cosmetic modifications. (Quite less recently, a new system was introduced to make heating gear a little more complicated, but it was still mostly straightforward, until 5* crystals were made impossible to farm, forcing players to rely on energy more and more.)Also, OOO refuses to port to Steam for Linux, cutting off many of its own players. The game's suckiness has reached an all-time low.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												This is a great game for anyone who's never played it before. It's casual so everyone can enjoy it, but offers a sense of progression. It's an absolute blast if you have friends to play with. If you like the idea of a 4-player Legend of Zelda, give this game a shot. It's truly free-to-play now, and you don't need to spend money to progress. PvP can be insanely fun but does require a big time investment. The game mechanics are very simple but offer a lot of room for skill growth (reactions, etc.)That said, I've played this game since it came out on beta in early 2010 and there have been zero progression updates to the game ever since SEGA acquired them in late 2011. The same final boss that appeared in 2010 is still the same final boss in 2014. The "final gate" that was locked to players in 2010 is still locked. The "hardcore" content is simply recycled dungeons and locked behind a bad paywall, but luckily you never have to touch it. The game has basically devolved into a cycle of minor updates with no progression content, and a bunch of cosmetic items. Hats. And more hats.The fact that it's coded in Java is also a huge problem, as there are some fundamental issues with the code that make the game poorly optimized. The biggest problem is Java having to dump its memory every time it reaches the memory cap, causing the game to occasionally stutter as Java does this, even on beast computers. See these threads: 1. http://forums.spiralknights.com/en/node/128492. http://forums.spiralknights.com/en/node/2188I recommend this game especially if you have friends to play with. It'll offer a solid hundred hours of enjoyable, challenging fun. But if/when you get to the end, don't expect them to add any more progression content... because they won't, and haven't since 2010.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Don't be fooled. This game might have a cute and coloful look but what makes it a true gem is that it requires skill to master and plenty to keep the challange going while the COOP aspect adds infinite replayability. This is a true action game with one of the best combat systems I've come across. It feels balanced with enough variety to keep it interesting and engaging, but with enough simplicity to keep it from being unnecessarly bloated like many other games with weapon/armor upgrades end up feeling. Every enemy is fought differently and certain weapons work best against them. With all the different specialization routes like buffing up on armor, gunning, bombing, slow swords, fast swords, knockback techniques, precise shielding and dozens of different enemies on screen, it is truly rewarding to master.Although this game can be played exclusivly solo, the thing that really makes this game never-ending is the COOP. Technically it is a MMO but parties are limited to 4 players that must work together with different strategies to complete levels. Like any other game, it does have shortcomings, most notably the steep learning curve pertaning to making and using the variety of gear that is available, However, if you enjoy challanging action games with plenty of upgrading and COOP, you should absolutely must give this a try.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												What is up with me and mindless grindfest games? Yes, Spiral Knights is uh, an old-school RPG for both casual and hardcore players? You might be able to see the part where the entire audience gets alienated by just reading that sentence. Regardless, After spending year on the game, I am willing to say that I immensely enjoyed the experience at the very least. Progression has significantly slowed since I started out, so grinding ahoy is abundant. Newbies grind so that they can get to 5*. The Vanguards grind because they have run out of things to do. It's rather clear that Three Rings is trying to do something about it, but their major game-adding updates are even less frequent than OVERKILL Software- And that's before we get into the mudpool that is what is a "major game-adding update". Some people think cosmetic boxes are. Others claim that chapeaus and tabards are not adding anything of value to the game. It's kinda tiring to listen to, so the gist of it is- Three Rings is kinda slow in development. Nothing any of us can do other than sit and play other games.So why play this game? Did you enjoy Legend of Zelda? Are you one of those modern day children who seem to have their minds in the wrong era? Well, Spiral Knights seems to be targeting people like you. The difficulty at first is easy enough for even elementary students. Midway through, the game ramps up in difficulty rather quickly. By the end, either you'll know how to fight, or you'll be stuck in Haven wondering how to beat the monster of the week. Back to the point, it's clearly not hardcore enough for veterans- Complaints of how easy the game is even on Elite difficulty are abound. It's definitely not for little kids as their first game- Unless they stick around the beginning forever, they'll start getting mulched when they start fighting in Tier 2. So that leaves you, odd precocious children of the future. You are probably a better match for this game than any many other people. Cmon, it's free.Well that's the bad, and the reason to play it. What's so fun about Spiral Knights? You get to run around and beat things up. In return, you get shiny coins, and materials to make better stuff to beat things up with. Oh, and feed your pet. Rinse and repeat. Explore the randomly-generated dungeon crawl. Find your favorite weapon, and when you become a reasonably good fighter, start using unfamiliar weapons because why not. Stare. Staaare. Oh, and there's beauty contests. I think. The last one I visited nearly got blown up by a hell raven, so I don't think there's any organized anymore. Oh well, you can dress nicely and people will wonder how you thought it up. That's something, right?Overall, Spiral Knights is a pretty fun game for a Free to Play title. The only problem is- It feels like it's definitely not for everyone. Or, it is for everyone, but if anyone tries to move from their selected space, they find themselves in a vice, unless they are part of a group that I hope is bigger than what my experience tells me. Either way, it's free. Go give it a whirl, try to be friendly to everyone online, and if you stick around, congrats. You might be the next generation of sour veterans who wish for new content.

												In short, if you liked Alien Swarm, you'll definitely like this. It has more focus on melee weapon combat than guns, though. At least, melee weapons tend to be more effective at killing.It's quite fun; all free, except you can only play 1.5-2 hours per a day for free (not including mist tank gifts). Well, 1.5-2 hours of being in a dungeon fighting monsters. You can be in the game buying/selling/chatting as much as you want.You can get over the time limit by going through dungeons and getting crowns (the ingame currency) and trading them for energy (which lets you go into dungeons to get more crowns).Anyway, you should at least try it!

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												This is one of my first and the best MMO I've ever played. You start out as a knight who just crash-landed onto a mysterious planet called Cradle. On the quest to return home, you delve into the unknown depths of Cradle, meet new friends, fight against darkness. Sometimes,  a jerk scams you, that hammer spam crushes you, the frustrations of others discourage you. But don't give up just yet. My friends and I came accross each other as strangers, in the end we become family. One day, you'll realize that home is not that far away, home is where the heart is.This game is truly a F2P game. So don't hesitate to give it a try. Sometimes you'll hear about a place called Lockdown, just stay away from that place till you're ready (to hear people whine, brag, flame, etc.) Let the spirit of adventure guide you to the very end.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												It's free to play, but that doesn't automatically makes it a bad game. Instead, it's actually a pretty enjoyable game RPG style with a kind of dungeon crawler gameplay, with awesome soundtracks from the good old SEGA and neaty graphics.Why am i not recommending it then?Simply this game has been left in its state for years. Yes, there are some "events" for various holidays, with the same contents repeated every year, and always, ALWAYS new costumes/accessories/cosmetic armors, which are actually the only things being updated in the game. Stuff that must be bought with real money (like every free to play has to live with) that don't really give the game that replayability or wish to continue on in the game, because, we can also say, that there's also a cool simple story behind the game itself, but its simply half-done and the last gameplay-wise update has been done 3 years ago as a paid DLC.Now i don't want to blame the fact that, if you want more dungeons, you'll have to pay a classic DLC to unlock it, but after that you have the story of the game still left at half, because the game itself has not been updated nowadays, and you have basically wasted money by buying a piece of puzzle to your puzzle set that is missing many more pieces.Technically there are still some issues and bugs related to the internet of the player, since you need a stable connection to play and possibly decent one, even if you want to play by yourself in a kind of "singleplayer".Same goes for little graphical glitches, but i'd be surprised if there weren't any.Of course there is also like almost any free to play game something you can have to help you in the game, if you spend real money on it. Or at least you can buy stronger gear and weapons needed to progress in the game with cash, instead of in-game currency. Or some services to further improve them.Overall this was a pretty good game, but i personally feel this game is slowly dying as it seems the developers have left the game in its state, just adding some cosmetics to milk some more cash whenever it's possible.It had such potentials, wasted in lots of microtransactions.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I thought this game would be fun for my husband and I to play together.  Turns out, to play together you must be guild-mates.  To create a guild, you have to have crowns and energy.  The ONLY way to get energy?  Buy it with real money.Energy will also buy you items to make your in-game weapons and armor better.  I hate pay to win games!{ I added this next paragraph a month or so later.}The Spiral Knights developers told us it may have been a glitch that day but we haven't tried again because we're playing the hell out of AirMech and Alien Swarm.  Thank you to the players that commented on my review without calling me names.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a highly unique action based MMORPG unlike any other. It draws heavily from the top down Zeldas but throws a lot of other things into the mix, such as Bomberman. With a good progression system, lots of unique weapons, interesting pets, and simple systems, it's a plain great game. Sadly, there's little balance to be found in the game and the developers aren't quite in touch with the community. The community is pretty friggin' great, however. The devs wouild gain a lot from listening a bit more to it.The game used to be much more pay to play but since half a year ago (summer 2013), it's truly free to play. The great majority of pay to play content comes in the form of promotions that cost Energy. Energy can be bought for real life money or the in game currency, "crowns". Thus, there's no real life money barrier between any player and pay to play content, which mostly consists of purely cosmetic items directed to end game players.Another thing I truly like about this game is the art style. The characters are space marine knights with colourful armours and really cool weapons. There's also no sex-appeal involved. Characters don't even have anything that tells you whether they are men or women and that is probably one of the things that contribute to a community with so very little sexism.Spiral Knights is truly a beautiful piece of art so stop reading this review and go play it.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												This is your basic Pay to Win crap.  I couldn't even play a mission with my wife because I didn't want to spend money on anything yet.  Which means yes, if you're planning on downloading this to play with a friend, you need to spend real money to be able to do so.  Or you could grind for 7,800 'crowns' just to trade for 100 'energy'.  Energy is the bane of this game's existence.  If you haven't figured out yet, energy is what you buy with real life money. The game mechanics themselves are fun, but the Pay 2 Win (in this case, pay to even play with a friend) aspect really killed the game for me.Grade: D This game had much potential, but the P2W aspect ruins it.  Not to mention the trolls and spammers.  One person was walking around just begging my friend and I to trade and spamming requests...I traded once with him, my friend didn't...but this guy didn't relent.  He just kept on trollin': running around us, spamming chat and trade requests.  This and one other person were in the Arcade.  I don't kknow about you, but I don't like games with $h!tty communities!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2011
												UPDATE. (I had wrote a very simple Biased review as I was younger so this is a complete rework)Spiral Knights, It's a very visually colourful and cheerful "Entry Level" Action RPG MMO, you could say it's Entry Level but some of the later Endgame content can make you tear your hair out. This game has changed so much throughout the years and I've been there the entire way to see it in it's prime and decline to what it is now.This game used to be fair to the player, you could grind to earn practically everything without spending a cent, but it changed over time and the Devs focus on things you could spend your IRL Currency on grew.Many good things were added to this like the Quest/Storymode missions, the Capture the Flag and Battle Arena modes. The combat in this game is actually pretty satisfying, as different monsters are affected by different element or attack types it just makes the combat that bit more detailed, it also requires you to look ahead at what is coming and you can prepare your loadout for it.SUMMARY: Pros:+ Awesome Visuals, Very Colourful. + Combat is Satisfying and Fair, alot more indepth than it looks.+ Friendly Community (Back when I played) + Fun Boss fights and the Story is pretty neat (Could do with more)+ So many Variations of Armour and Weapons from Guns, Swords, Bombs. Along with Costume Slots to further customize your Knights look.Cons:- Devs are only adding Cash Grab Cosmetics and not actual game content- If you play outside of the server Region you are going to have a hard time with the combat (Trust me, being Australian on a Constant red bar was hell in late game levels but I still maxed my character out during my time)- Crafting is better than what it used to bed, but it's still trying to lure you into the temptation of spending IRL money. I could never hate this game, so I will recommend it. It's definetly not what it used too be as much as I wish this game got updates and content with an active community, but it seems it's past it's time now. It is still very fun playing with a friend from the beginning, it holds a very special place in my heart.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												Personally, I can't say much of this game. I quit the game almost early, because there was a broad storyline I could almost not follow, and the layout of the screen almost confused me at times. When I did understand what I was supposed to do, and (rarely) why, I would enjoy the heck out of myself. The graphics are still amazing for the game, but for myself ( who doesn't like when my UI is cramped) the game got boring quick. It quickly reminded me of my first days of WoW, and how I quit after a week of trying to get used to the cramped screen. Would not reccomend for anyone who is not used to the RPG feel of a cramped screen, but if you like a cramped screen, but would enjoy a more smooth and sci-fi graphical scene, this game is for you.

												After spending enough time to get a feel for the game, this game feels like it belongs on a mobile platform. Definitely has a generic, hollow feeling. Sort of feels like a Pay to Win type game, but others might have a different opinion. Not a "bad" game, per se. Just a little dull and monotonous. Perhaps something like the criticisms of Destiny. Yeah. I went there.Positives are that I sometimes got vibes of Phantasy Star Online, but those moments were very, very rare, and probably based soley on the fact it is a sci-fi shooter associated with Sega.I'd recommend this game if you want to play Mobile tier games on a computer, via Steam. If you don't want that, I'd defnitely not reccomend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2011
												Never, EVER go near this game. IT has caused me an unbeleavable ammount of pain. STAY AWAY!!!!It is very much pay2win oriented, since resurrecting in the dungeons uses up energy and you only get roughly 100 per day (and each time you revive, it's cost doubles, so first it's 10, then 20 then 40, etc.).It is absolutely imperative that you live a maximum of 7 feet away from their servers, otherwise you'll have to predict enemy movement before they even telegraph it. Same goes for your own actions as you'll see your own sword pass through enemies unless you time it juuuuust right.If you DO decide to play this, remember: your shield is TOOL to be used often. Use it's pushing ability to scatter surrounding enemies away before they strike (again, have to time it right or you'll get hit despite having your shield up).Not recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This was a good game.As most other reviews mention, yes, this used to be a fun game.Now? It's plain bad. VERY bad. Think as bad as Runescape and you aren't far.(On a side note, are all MMO games programmed in Java cursed to be bad?)Sure, you may be thinking "This is an angry rant, not a review". Well, let's see...In the past, there was a thing called Mist Energy (Mist = Free, Crystal = In-Game or Real Money), up to a max of 100 at a time. If you don't play the game and didn't come across the concept in the reviews, Energy is used for the main aspects in the game. While it restricted daily playtime for free players, it encouraged cooperative gameplay, which, in turn made the community overall a nice bunch.Nowadays, you get to play as much as you want (there was a 10 Energy fee for entering levels),but everything else is slow and tedious to do. Take crafting for instance; Previously, you crafted things with Energy. It took a chunk of time, but it was pretty doable until higher levels. Today, you have to get "Crystals" to craft items.They are paid with energy or found, but are: If playing levels, as rare as a cold glass of soda in a desert If buying with in-game currency, a 3-weeks-average grindfest to craft an item If buying with real money, an "I am rich" showcase of your many 5-star itemsAnd then comes the forge system. You see, you need heat (too!) to improve your weapons, and there are up to 10 levels of heat. Previously, heat level raised automatically (ala level up when you have enough exp).Currently, heat levels are increased when you provide "Embers" to a forge. The main flaws of this system are: They suffer from the same problems of Crystals Forges are only found outside missionsTherefore, you lose many potential heat levels while searching for Embers.And now, *drumroll*...UPDATES!The updates are many, but few can be actually called updates. You may be wondering what do I mean by this. Well, most updates are cosmetics which have little to no effect on gameplay. 99.99% of those are silly recolors of 5 star items or costumes, which cost either a zillon coins or $100 of your local currency. The major updates are seldom released (the most recent having been released 4 months ago), with the majority of them being missions or equipment, with gameplay changes being perjudicial (well, only making elevators free helped players).Not to mention that none of them added to the main storyline. That's right, folks! When the main storyline is over, you have little or nothing left to do.Let's talk about the miscellania of content here: PvP and Shadow Lairs.PvP? Craft a 5 star weapon with attack speed and damage UVs (read: modifiers), suit yourself in an armor with similar modifiers (now you know why everyone runs around in wolf costumes) and you are ready to go. Enough said.Shadow Lairs? I have to admit, now that looks like something fun to do. Problem is, you need Shadow Keys to enter and a lot of Sparks of Life (used to revive) for this, both being ridiculously expensive. And, except the Shadow Key, that goes for all your fellow party members (you'll definitely want to have a full party before entering). This is the ultimate challenge in the game, but as such, it is the ultimate money sink (aside from crafting, that is).Now, if you want to play the game anyways, I won't stop you. But remember this: There are many better games out there, don't waste your time on this one unless you like seeing knights in shiny armor and impressive weapons while having a crappy semi-automatic laser pistol and that armor you managed to craft after 2 months of grinding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I am just going to throw in my 2 cents.I played this game before and was pretty hardcore about it back in that time. Tried multi-box farming and other "non-normal" way to make money before the patch that removes energy requirement on elevator. So you know I am not those casual players with less than 20 hours game time who will be shouting "omg this game is so fun so cute, play it and you will never regret".The gameplay was fun, but grind wall hits me hard after about 20 hours of gameplay--just like almost every other free-to-play game out there.For example, in order to do higher level content, you can:1. play this game everyday for an hour for 2 weeks so that you accumulates enough mats which could upgrade your gears2. forget about life, forget about work, grind countinously and get those gears in a single day3. swipe your card and purchase gears directly from the in-game auction houseI quited playing seriously simply because the game was not rewarding enough based on the time I invested in this game. But I still log back in once in awhile just to listen to the music and slash some enemies.Recent patches are always cash-oriented, which, for sure, increase the grind level of this game in general.In conclusion, Spiral Knights is a medicore F2P game. Gameplay is interesting and unique, but it requires serious grinding to get anything you want. I would recommend playing it casually--explore the world, try out new things, and log off. If you want to play this game hardcore, it will be very repetitive, frustrating, and time-consuming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Graphics - 8/10 - Shockingly Stunning - The game has a lot of equipment that draws a different look here and there, and lots of outfits and pieces to deck you out... But there's a feel, something about the game manages to pull out a cartoony, fun, adventurous look that just makes you want to play more and explore despite it's instance system.Gameplay - 8/10* - Spectacular~! Note*: Simplistic at best, hack and slash, kite and run, reminds me of a MOBA but an adventurous and rpg'like form. Kinda lacks in a sense for auto-combos which isn't customizable (Assign'ed based on the item).Community - 5/10 - Lacking~!? The community is lacking; I try to communicate, ask for help and furthermore and rarely if anyone ever communicates.Customization - 8.25/10 - Just play and you'll understand, You can change nearly anything to really own your "Spiral Knight", however sometimes forced to wear certain items due to stat limitations. A lot of the custom pieces to add to equipments cost a penny, or hard to get. Colors are there, only thing I see lacking is patterns that can be added (They have patterns, but locked on specific items/labeled items).Replayability 7.25/10 - The game got me hooked pretty well, but some reason I cannot find a reason to come back. After playing 3 hours straight, and 2 more sessions of an hour and a half.. I stopped playing, I assume it's cause at one point or another it feels too "Starter RPG-Game" to me, but nonetheless it's a notable game and I'd recommend it to all ages of my family and friends.Overall 7.3/10- "Great Game" - I feel what dropped it's rating is the sole-fact it's so simple to pick up, it's so easy to play, and accomodates everything you'd expect in a RPG.. However, it lacks a open-world, the discovery factor; Or something else such as a unique system of any sort to bring something new to the table to truly "Cling onto you".However the game does what it's supposed too- Very fun as it does, and can drag you on for endless of time if you don't watch that timer. Over and out,-V.

												Spiral knights is (for me) a very enjoyable game. Before you dive into it though, I must warn you it might be addicting for some. The game has graphics which make the game look cute but amazing at the same time, and the soundtrack always fits prefectly with it. Some people might argue there might be no point in playing once you get full 5* gear and all the stuff. Lately (about a month ago) I found that was wrong. So I recommend this game, but not too much so you won't get addicted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												While the game is old, with updates over the past year the game has become much more free-to-play friendly than it use to be. Elevators are now free and there is no longer a Mist bar, meaning endless dungeon crawling for everyone. Leveling weapons is different, now requiring a specific item depending on the * of weapon. While hard to find at times, it is still possible to find the required item in Prize Boxes in through the dungeon. The newer updates the game have put the focus back on exploration and spending time in the Clockworks and learning the game at your own pace, not buying everything with real world money and just spending time in pvp. I have sunk easily 1000+ hours over the course of my time playing Spiral Knights and it will always be one of my most favorite games ever because of all of the memories I have made through the 3 years I have been playing.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a great game. Great story mode and I adore the graphics. Not many games have 3D cartoon-ish graphics to them, but there is one problem. . . Spiral Knights is dying and I don't want this game to die. My cousins told me that once you finish the story mode there is nothing else to do. So what I suggest is that you should expand the story mode and add new items. Back in  2012 Spiral Knights was popular, but now the population has decreased to 500-300 players. I'm begging the developers to please expand the story mode. Make an update that adds an more to the story mode. I really want to experience that feeling again when my cousins would call over Skype and we'd all play Spiral Knights, but because we finished the story there was no point in playing Spiral Knights anymore. Please expand the story mode and maybe add new items to the game. It's a big thing that I'm asking for, but there are many games out there that expand their story and keeping it fresh. The community is dying and I don't want this game to die yet. Please expand the story and add new items to the game. Keep things fresh and new.

												I've been playing this game, on and off, long before it was released on Steam, since beta.  I played opening release weekend, late March 2011.  One of my characters has over 85 1/2 days of play time on it, thats 2000+ hours.Great casual game:  +s, cute graphics, good music, great if you liked the Legend of Zelda games from NES, SNES, very simple combat style relative to most games.-s, little content; especially end-game, no raiding (more than 4 player, player versus AI content), limited pvp options.  Story is weak.If you're a casual player that can only log on for less than an hour to two hours a day to play, you'll find lots to do in this game without it feeling too grindy.  If you have more time to play than that per day, you'll get bored of this game relatively fast.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Spiral knights is a game that I never thought would be this good. It's set up in a very interesting artificial world whose characteristics blend perfectly with the game features. The spiral knights (players), are newcomers to this world and are so far limited to a small section of the surface. Because of this, they need to explore its depths in to improve the toehold they have on it.  There are two main resources in spiral knights: crowns, which are the game's form of currency, and energy which is needed to activate the elevators and doors which allow the player to explore the world, as well as crafting all kinds of gear. While crowns are dropped by defeated enemies, energy can only gained by the pass of time (called mist energy and limited to 100 per account), purchased from other players using crowns (in the form of energy crystals), or purchased using real money. Access to energy is the main difference between paying and free customers, but thanks to the inclusion of an energy market in the game's currency, free players can enjoy all the features the game has to offer though more slowly than paying customers.  So far I have been playing the game for free, and I'm having a blast. I also appreciate that the game is so friendly towards free customers (specially those who are too busy and cannot spend more than a couple of hours playing every day). Most likely I will start spending real money as I go further down the game, but for the moment I'm perfectly fine with the free version. This is a game I would definitely recommend you give it a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Spiral Knights is a hack 'n' slash style MMORPG that feels much like a top-down Zelda game, complete with pots.The paid content, which is obtained through the game's premium currency, energy, is completely optional and for the most part, out of the way. You don't have to get it but it feels nicer to have it, especially in times where it's tough.However, do not expect to get through the game with owning one set of armor and weapons at a time. Certainplaces contain certain enemies and hazards that may make you weaker or stronger depending on your gear, and playing with friends is often a must.It may seem at first that you don't have to put much effort into fighing, but you have to pay attention to your enemies and their projectiles. Glowing areas on the ground indicate where an enemy is going to attack, but you need to act quickly to dodge it. Projectiles need to be watched for, and may sometimes come to you a-la bullet hell games.My only complaints are that you cannot equip many weapons at one time and to do that you have to rent, let me repeat myself, RENT, extra slots to equip more items. Often you have to resort to getting things from the community marketplace because getting them from stages can be a chore and often shops won't have what you need, thus having to deal with the sometimes ludicrous prices of greedy players.And on a final note you will have these things called Sparks of Life. You can use them when you die more than once or use them on fallen teammates who also died more than once. However as a word of caution, use them sparingly, as they're hard to come by through normal gameplay, but can be bought with energy, which in my opinion, sparks are the stuff you should buy the most, because, if you're struggling on a level and you don't have them, you're screwed.

												Spiral Knights is a fun game, it's best playing coop because it's always better with friends! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												SK is a pretty fun game, especially to play with your friends (many of my friends absolutely adore this game, long after I stopped playing it). I quite enjoyed going through it alone as well. The graphics are cartoony and nice and the game is definitely worth trying since it's free-to-play: the music is ambient and airy and suitable for the overall techy atmosphere. As for customization, I really like the "main color" feature - where your character stays primarily one color that you choose at the beginning, kind of like a permanent identifier for them - and especially the equip-as-costume feature - where you can keep a piece of equipment as your visible headgear while using the stats of a better item (this way your character doesn't end up looking stupid because of mismatched gear unless you want them to). My biggest disappointment was having to go through endless grinding of the Jelly King in order to get 30 Jelly Tokens to trade for an item I needed. This is when I stopped playing, and I don't plan on picking up the game again, though it was extremely enjoyable while it lasted. Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Play this game.It's a dungeon crawler MMORPG with a dash of zelda inserted for good measure. The old 'free' mist energy may have been scrapped, but so have energy costs for elevators and alchemy. In short, buying energy with real money is now a shortcut, not a necessity. It's perfectly possible to play through the entire main game (i.e. the 'rank' missions) completely free.There are no 'character levels', but your equipment gains 'heat' (basically exp), and after a certain amount is collected, you can level it up via the forge. Weapons 'evolve' through alchemy, and new weapons can be crafted via alchemy.The main game has you play as a knight who completes various missions which revolve around exploring what is known as the clockworks and fighting various monsters there. Rank missions involve you exploring 2-3 levels of the clockworks each time, whereas using the arcade lets you explore more freely - once you've done enough rank missions, you can go from 'depth 0' to 'depth 29' in a single run.The levels within the clockworks get progressively harder as you go deeper, and there are four main bosses to kill (as many times as you want) - and that's not including the difficult 'shadow lairs'. I feel that there's an emphasis on teamwork throughout the game (working as a team to complete missions makes it easier and you still get the same drops) and somewhat on player skill later on (even with excellent equipment, you'll still die if you're bad with a shield).It should be said, however, that if you don't wish to fork out any cash for energy, then you may find that the grinding required to advance throughout the game may prove too repetitive and boring - experienced MMO players probably won't suffer from this issue, however.Overall, I'd say this is a great game for those who enjoy MMOs, exploration and adventure. Me gusta.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Background ethos: I have a playtime of 55:07:28:52, linked is an alt account. I've been a customer of OOO since 2007. I 'jumped ship' from Y!PP to this game in 2012.This game is a hard sell. It is fun, vibrant and is both simple enough to pick up, and compelling enough to not put down. 2 years ago, I would say that once you get over the mist system, it's an excellent game I hope to see grow to be even better. 2 years later, I cannot reccommend this game wholeheartily due to the missteps it has taken. There is no getting past the top-heavy 'first act' of the game, restricting leveling system, redundancy-by-proxy mission system, and lack of an endgame.These decisions and the overall lack of content to explore being added in any fashion sour the game experience for me. While the game remains something I come back to, I can no longer tell my friends to try it out, and I won't tell you, reader, either.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
Yeah ok, first things first. It's not dead. It's a small but alive population so don't go around saying it's a dead game.Now that's out of the way, I just want to say: It's a really good game but it's corrupted with the whole P2W aspectSure there are some frusfrations like grinding and the overly done crafting system but the gameplay, atmosphere and visual is just so appealing. The crafting system is kinda annoying what with you having to go to dungeons over and over and over so you can get that one material you know need but the dungeons themselves are kinda cool and each has their own themes. Oh and when I say dungeon? I mean underground depths.You descend deeper and deeper into the earth's core as you progress through the dungeons and you will need to get better gear as things proceed but it's decently balanced. Thing is the P2W thing is just really tempting. You need that one more material? One more coin? One more whatever to do whatever it is you are doing? HERE'S SOME OFFER IN YOUR FACE JUST TO TEMPT YOU. If you resist it though, it's really irrelevant tbh. It's not like you use the P2W money to revive yourself when you are dead and if you are not skilled enough to stay alive for a long time, especially with the lag it has due to the lack of servers and maintenance, you have to restart from the beginning or anythingI love this game and I do recommend you to download and give this game a try. It's free and it's good, what's the harm really? Except the cancerous P2W system

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Oh how far we've fallen... I've been playing this since 2010 and while there have been massive improvements, there have been massive failures.  Every update ends up requiring multiple shutdowns and restarts, latency has gone from annoying to game runing in several places, and once you've done everything once there really isn't anything more.  There have been no new levels, monsters, bosses, or anything for almost 2 years.  When this was new it was absolutely amazing and for new players it will be very fun.  But for those who have been around for a while it just doesn't do it anymore.  New weapons are great but if you're shooting at the same monsters over and over again in the same levels, it gets pretty boring after a while.  To be sure, you'll get hundreds of hours out of it, especially if you minimally pay and do it through old fashioned work.  But don't expect to stick around for years at near the same level of excitement.

content:

												A "Free to Play" sca--- I mean... game. You get 100 Energy per day, energy is required to play the game and go through dungeons. You can only store 100 energy, so no going afk for a week. Items require energy to make, at the second teir about 400. Which means in order to progress you have to spend real money or buy energy from the AH as theres no way to gain energy any other way. Also the gameplay is terrible, 90% of the time you'll have enemies that hide on spikes in corners and you just have to wait for them to come out. Bosses are impossible to tell what the hell is going on, and I still have no idea how the level selection works.

												This is game now just a conveiluded mess. At one time I would rememend it but as it stands now I can't in all good fith recommend this game. The damn thing used to be simple but then they added accessories the game had begun to lean towards the way of ingame currency being worth something since it the igc could buy Crystal energy something of a premium. content:
Posted: December 19, 2011
												Never, EVER go near this game. IT has caused me an unbeleavable ammount of pain. STAY AWAY!!!!It is very much pay2win oriented, since resurrecting in the dungeons uses up energy and you only get roughly 100 per day (and each time you revive, it's cost doubles, so first it's 10, then 20 then 40, etc.).It is absolutely imperative that you live a maximum of 7 feet away from their servers, otherwise you'll have to predict enemy movement before they even telegraph it. Same goes for your own actions as you'll see your own sword pass through enemies unless you time it juuuuust right.If you DO decide to play this, remember: your shield is TOOL to be used often. Use it's pushing ability to scatter surrounding enemies away before they strike (again, have to time it right or you'll get hit despite having your shield up).Not recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

content:

												In regards to Spiral Knights, I feel a heavy bit of nostalgia for Phantasy Star Online for the Dreamcast from this; be it the music, art style, or overall Sega feel. It's a candy coated, charming, and light action-rpg that I get an itch for when I'm away from it for a few months. However It's a grind for gear, and there's not much in the way of customization or variety unless you play everyday in copy-cat grind-y dungeons, or shell out real money. Which, I believe, the game deserves.  The paywall feels like it hits as soon I as get in a groove, and snaps like a rubber band. I eventually come back, though, for the tight gameplay and charming design. So yah, play it.
