number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This was a good game.As most other reviews mention, yes, this used to be a fun game.Now? It's plain bad. VERY bad. Think as bad as Runescape and you aren't far.(On a side note, are all MMO games programmed in Java cursed to be bad?)Sure, you may be thinking "This is an angry rant, not a review". Well, let's see...In the past, there was a thing called Mist Energy (Mist = Free, Crystal = In-Game or Real Money), up to a max of 100 at a time. If you don't play the game and didn't come across the concept in the reviews, Energy is used for the main aspects in the game. While it restricted daily playtime for free players, it encouraged cooperative gameplay, which, in turn made the community overall a nice bunch.Nowadays, you get to play as much as you want (there was a 10 Energy fee for entering levels),but everything else is slow and tedious to do. Take crafting for instance; Previously, you crafted things with Energy. It took a chunk of time, but it was pretty doable until higher levels. Today, you have to get "Crystals" to craft items.They are paid with energy or found, but are: If playing levels, as rare as a cold glass of soda in a desert If buying with in-game currency, a 3-weeks-average grindfest to craft an item If buying with real money, an "I am rich" showcase of your many 5-star itemsAnd then comes the forge system. You see, you need heat (too!) to improve your weapons, and there are up to 10 levels of heat. Previously, heat level raised automatically (ala level up when you have enough exp).Currently, heat levels are increased when you provide "Embers" to a forge. The main flaws of this system are: They suffer from the same problems of Crystals Forges are only found outside missionsTherefore, you lose many potential heat levels while searching for Embers.And now, *drumroll*...UPDATES!The updates are many, but few can be actually called updates. You may be wondering what do I mean by this. Well, most updates are cosmetics which have little to no effect on gameplay. 99.99% of those are silly recolors of 5 star items or costumes, which cost either a zillon coins or $100 of your local currency. The major updates are seldom released (the most recent having been released 4 months ago), with the majority of them being missions or equipment, with gameplay changes being perjudicial (well, only making elevators free helped players).Not to mention that none of them added to the main storyline. That's right, folks! When the main storyline is over, you have little or nothing left to do.Let's talk about the miscellania of content here: PvP and Shadow Lairs.PvP? Craft a 5 star weapon with attack speed and damage UVs (read: modifiers), suit yourself in an armor with similar modifiers (now you know why everyone runs around in wolf costumes) and you are ready to go. Enough said.Shadow Lairs? I have to admit, now that looks like something fun to do. Problem is, you need Shadow Keys to enter and a lot of Sparks of Life (used to revive) for this, both being ridiculously expensive. And, except the Shadow Key, that goes for all your fellow party members (you'll definitely want to have a full party before entering). This is the ultimate challenge in the game, but as such, it is the ultimate money sink (aside from crafting, that is).Now, if you want to play the game anyways, I won't stop you. But remember this: There are many better games out there, don't waste your time on this one unless you like seeing knights in shiny armor and impressive weapons while having a crappy semi-automatic laser pistol and that armor you managed to craft after 2 months of grinding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I am just going to throw in my 2 cents.I played this game before and was pretty hardcore about it back in that time. Tried multi-box farming and other "non-normal" way to make money before the patch that removes energy requirement on elevator. So you know I am not those casual players with less than 20 hours game time who will be shouting "omg this game is so fun so cute, play it and you will never regret".The gameplay was fun, but grind wall hits me hard after about 20 hours of gameplay--just like almost every other free-to-play game out there.For example, in order to do higher level content, you can:1. play this game everyday for an hour for 2 weeks so that you accumulates enough mats which could upgrade your gears2. forget about life, forget about work, grind countinously and get those gears in a single day3. swipe your card and purchase gears directly from the in-game auction houseI quited playing seriously simply because the game was not rewarding enough based on the time I invested in this game. But I still log back in once in awhile just to listen to the music and slash some enemies.Recent patches are always cash-oriented, which, for sure, increase the grind level of this game in general.In conclusion, Spiral Knights is a medicore F2P game. Gameplay is interesting and unique, but it requires serious grinding to get anything you want. I would recommend playing it casually--explore the world, try out new things, and log off. If you want to play this game hardcore, it will be very repetitive, frustrating, and time-consuming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												Spiral Knights! A "F2P" (Free To Play) Game released by Three Rings and SEGA back in April 2010.Plot: The mystery of the story unfolds as you follow your quests down into the depths of Cradle (The planet setting) to know why the Spiral Knights have crashed down onto this mysterious planet. To get out, they will have to harness the energy from "The Core" which lies in the deepest parts of the planet, but with the mysterious machine and world called the "Clockworks" that lies below, the dangers of delving into the planet and the knight's fate will remain unknown... In this ever-changing world. As the game's main storyline is still incomplete, the developers still keeps updating the game. We are surely all thrilled to see what will unfold when "The Core" patch finally releases in the upcoming future.Gameplay and Multiplayer: Spiral Knights is a very interesting co-op dungeon crawler, as it is a face paced gameplay through many diverse environments in the clockworks. As the players will be able to play together to 4 player, it is also a drop-in/drop-out multiplayer which does not affect how you play but make the hostile enemies get a little tougher. It is a top-down third-person real-time action/adventure game which could be compared to some old games for example The Legend of Zelda and so. As for this style, some hardcore gamers that play games like Diablo and so might find this very boring and a little too "old school" for what they call "games" nowadays. Visuals: The game runs with the Java engine, which restricted them to do anything much with higher-level graphics, however the game again really does resent old games as mentioned which could also be a reason why they kept the graphics the way it is, but compared to modern games and what you can really do with visuals, this would be medium rated. There are a few cut scenes in the game which still used fully the game mechanics, however with switched over and close-up angle directed camera, although with this being the visuals it is suitable for any age group of audiences.Audio: The OST is made by Harry Mack, which did a truly amazing job of making the game sound really old-school, keeping the styles of 8-bit music from the time, but using newer technology and sound systems such as the strings, and so on. The soundtrack of this game is very diverse when comparing to any other RPG game, since this is a cartoon/fantasy type. With the game being free to play, Three Rings did not invest too much in putting 'voices' into the game, so therefore there was no voice acting, but even without it-- The game plays itself with all the dialogues coming up as comicified themed speech bubbles that do not disturb the player's gameplay. You probably wouldn't find any other game's soundtrack feeling "old school" style of the original 8-bit gaming music that sounds really modern as Spiral Knights'.Reception: As the reception goes, there are many awards and positive comments on it from communities such as "Ars Technica", "Wired" and "PC Gamer". In 2011, the Game Developers Choice Online Awards has nominated Spiral Knights as "Best Visual Online Arts, Best Online Game Design, Best Audio for an Online Game, and Best New Online Game". It was awarded for the "Best" Online Game Design. Most of the reception and comments also really do find the game really addicting as far as the community goes, 2 year after its initial release-- Over 3 million accounts were registered and having near a million active per day.

Posted: August 11, 2011
												UPDATE. (I had wrote a very simple Biased review as I was younger so this is a complete rework)Spiral Knights, It's a very visually colourful and cheerful "Entry Level" Action RPG MMO, you could say it's Entry Level but some of the later Endgame content can make you tear your hair out. This game has changed so much throughout the years and I've been there the entire way to see it in it's prime and decline to what it is now.This game used to be fair to the player, you could grind to earn practically everything without spending a cent, but it changed over time and the Devs focus on things you could spend your IRL Currency on grew.Many good things were added to this like the Quest/Storymode missions, the Capture the Flag and Battle Arena modes. The combat in this game is actually pretty satisfying, as different monsters are affected by different element or attack types it just makes the combat that bit more detailed, it also requires you to look ahead at what is coming and you can prepare your loadout for it.SUMMARY: Pros:+ Awesome Visuals, Very Colourful. + Combat is Satisfying and Fair, alot more indepth than it looks.+ Friendly Community (Back when I played) + Fun Boss fights and the Story is pretty neat (Could do with more)+ So many Variations of Armour and Weapons from Guns, Swords, Bombs. Along with Costume Slots to further customize your Knights look.Cons:- Devs are only adding Cash Grab Cosmetics and not actual game content- If you play outside of the server Region you are going to have a hard time with the combat (Trust me, being Australian on a Constant red bar was hell in late game levels but I still maxed my character out during my time)- Crafting is better than what it used to bed, but it's still trying to lure you into the temptation of spending IRL money. I could never hate this game, so I will recommend it. It's definetly not what it used too be as much as I wish this game got updates and content with an active community, but it seems it's past it's time now. It is still very fun playing with a friend from the beginning, it holds a very special place in my heart.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												SK is a pretty fun game, especially to play with your friends (many of my friends absolutely adore this game, long after I stopped playing it). I quite enjoyed going through it alone as well. The graphics are cartoony and nice and the game is definitely worth trying since it's free-to-play: the music is ambient and airy and suitable for the overall techy atmosphere. As for customization, I really like the "main color" feature - where your character stays primarily one color that you choose at the beginning, kind of like a permanent identifier for them - and especially the equip-as-costume feature - where you can keep a piece of equipment as your visible headgear while using the stats of a better item (this way your character doesn't end up looking stupid because of mismatched gear unless you want them to). My biggest disappointment was having to go through endless grinding of the Jelly King in order to get 30 Jelly Tokens to trade for an item I needed. This is when I stopped playing, and I don't plan on picking up the game again, though it was extremely enjoyable while it lasted. Recommended.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2011
												Spiral Knights is a throw back to old school action rpg platformers, and in my opinion is most similar to the Zelda franchise (Zelda 4 swords adventure in particular). The core gameplay is casual but also fun and addictive. The graphics, while certainly nothing to brag about, are more than adequate to provide a smooth gaming experience while not looking too outdated. The music is both melodic and reminiscent of the good old 8bit days. There are some minor lag problems due to the games use of UDP protocols and because of the limmited server size, however, the game is still in ongoing development and there's no reason to think these issues won't be rectified in the future. All in all I'd recommend Spiral Knights to anyone and give it a 4/5 rating.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I have only recently linked my Spiral Knights account to steam, this is why it says i have played very little. I have played 200+ hours off steam.Spiral Knights is a very well designed and addictive mmo, not exactly the most complex one ever, but a excellent game never the less. It has had many changes during the time i have played this game that can change elements of the game completley, some good, some bad, but not bad enough to stop me playing.PROSA Great Variety of EnemiesCustomisation optionsLevels (depths)WeaponsAreasCharacters (Npcs)Players (online)MissionsOther FeaturesCrafting systemGame modes (Lockdown, etc)Guilds (clans, groups)Great bosses and boss battles (Snarbloax, Vanaduke)(Fairly new) Sprites (Pets that can fight with you)Beautifully designed Stages and areasAmazing soundtrack (availible on Itunes and Spotify)Runs pretty well on non-powerfull PC's and LaptopsAnd much more i have probably missedCONSMay take a while to get/craft/upgrade items (not so much now after a big update)Levels may get repetetive (not in my opinion)Some missions can be very difficult (but optional)Probably a few points i have missed but this game hardly has any bad points.One of if not my fave game (ever)9/10

content:
Posted: April 23, 2012
												I do not play MMORPGs, so it's special when I say I play Spiral Knights. It's kept extremely simple, which makes it a great casual game that I can pick up and drop off without intense involvement. This is a good pizza-and-mouse game, meaning you can play one-handed due to the simplicity of the controls. It's a nice, calm, relaxing game, with stretches of tension and frustration. It's FtP, so there's limits on how much you can do in a 24 hour span, which kind of helps keeps me from seeing the limitations of the campaign missions. The skirmish missions are always different, but to clear a campaign, you must fight the same enemies on the same map. It has a difficulty spike in some areas. I love the visual design, and the music is an awesome combination of eight-bit and chill. Some of the collecting and trading aspects are difficult, as it isn't always easy to find someone who will buy what you want, even though it is extremely easy to buy items from others at the sub-ten tiers.  8.5/10.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
Yeah ok, first things first. It's not dead. It's a small but alive population so don't go around saying it's a dead game.Now that's out of the way, I just want to say: It's a really good game but it's corrupted with the whole P2W aspectSure there are some frusfrations like grinding and the overly done crafting system but the gameplay, atmosphere and visual is just so appealing. The crafting system is kinda annoying what with you having to go to dungeons over and over and over so you can get that one material you know need but the dungeons themselves are kinda cool and each has their own themes. Oh and when I say dungeon? I mean underground depths.You descend deeper and deeper into the earth's core as you progress through the dungeons and you will need to get better gear as things proceed but it's decently balanced. Thing is the P2W thing is just really tempting. You need that one more material? One more coin? One more whatever to do whatever it is you are doing? HERE'S SOME OFFER IN YOUR FACE JUST TO TEMPT YOU. If you resist it though, it's really irrelevant tbh. It's not like you use the P2W money to revive yourself when you are dead and if you are not skilled enough to stay alive for a long time, especially with the lag it has due to the lack of servers and maintenance, you have to restart from the beginning or anythingI love this game and I do recommend you to download and give this game a try. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												A charming, Zelda-inspired, online RPG. Beautiful art style, great soundtrack, good progression, with fun PvE and PvP. This is a great game in my opinion, and while it might not be for everyone, it is definitely a 'must-try'.There is quite a grind mid-game, but it's just enough grind to make you WANT to spend some money, but not so bad you HAVE to spend. There are not as many end-game dungeons as there should be, but you can go back to previous missions with scaled down stats (with slighty less payout). The developer (Three Rings) constantly creates new events, with new levels, and usually new costumes armor sets. These incremental updates provide new stuff to do while you wait for the next big level update.Customization in this game is HUGE, with 'costume armor' sets, and accessories to put on your armor (though you can only afford them towards end-game). It's insane how many different armor combinations you can make. I've played over 1000 hours, and even I can't remember every one!PvP will provide hours of fun, but at times can be overrun with PvP elitists (trust me, that's no fun). The "FreeToPlay" system is set up really well, and has greatly improved in a recent update (so if you played it a while ago and hated it, try it again). Currency earned by play is called "Crowns", and currency that you pay real money for is called "Energy". At any time, Crowns can be traded for Energy via the in-game energy market (thus paying real money is completely optional). Of course Energy is more desirable, but when trading with other players, they usually don't mind if you pay in Crowns. You can buy energy to speed up your progression, but is by no means neccessary to reach end-game. I have bought Energy a few times myself, but they were mostly to buy costumes or to pimp out a costume with accessories.I think my hours spent playing this game tell how fun it is. I love this game, and I would play it at the slightest mention of a new update or event.It's free, it's fun, and truly FreeToPlay, what more do I need to say? Play it NOW...!    (and if you don't like it you are a heartless scrublord)

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												This game is one of my very favourites. Essentially you are a Knight. With a sword, sheild and armour. And a gun and a bomb. This game is all about going through levels, trying to reach the centre of the planet, and as you do, the enemies become harder to beat and the levels take more skill and better geat to survive. There are some reused levels but that makes it feel familiar and it makes it easier to navigate. (though there would be different enemies and in different places) This game also has some puzzle elements too. there is also a PvP mode called Lockdown, which is fun, but I personally don't like it, as you have to have really good geat to even stand a chance. There is another PvP mode called Blast Network, which is just like bomberman and doesn't require good gear or weapons, as it doesn't affect gameplay. There is a bunch of character customization and HEAPS of weapons and armour, and a bunch of other stuff I couldn't think of straight off the top of my head... so give it a go!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 9
												Before we begin, I have a bunch more hours into this game, but just played off of steam. (400-something)Bragging about my low amount of hours ingame aside, this game is kind of like TF2. Not in the sense of gameplay, but in the sense of new content. That is, there isn't much new stuff happening. The last new weapons were added in 2014. Since the players control energy prices, energy has gone up to around 11K crowns, which is very difficult for newer players to obtain. Heck, the original developers of the game aren't even there anymore. That being said, I sincerely enjoy and recommend this game. Why? Read on...Graphics are good, especially for a 2011 700MB game.  The enemies are designed to have clearly choreographed attacks, not to make it easy, but so you can learn how to dodge, time, and intercept attacks. The enemies get harder the farther you go, so learning those moves early on can save you a bunch of sparks of life later on. The point is that this game isn't just a point-and-click fiesta, but has decent amount of skill involved. I have never encountered a cheater or hacker, and the community, in my biased opinion, is one of the better ones out there. Grinding is a large part of the game, but the arcade levels are random and always different. (Unless you replay the same one 6 times because the treasure vault is right th-oops) This grinding does take a long time, and if you go to the recipie vendor, and he doesn't have your recipie, tough luck. gotta do the levels again. But you obtain loot and shinies along the way, so at least you get those should your recipie not be there. Another thing this game has is character. The weapons are cool, there's a ton of different armors, shields, and weapons, AND HATS. The levels are fun, and not too repetitive, and finally finding that Sacred Grizzly Pathfinder helm recipie is... well, I don't know. I'm still looking for that one. :) But crafting weapons after finding the recipie and leveling it up makes you feel pretty good, and getting that new sprite perk is always cool.Remember how I said new content was slow? It is. not gonna lie. However, it has been inproving. Grey Havens, the new guys, have been doing a pretty good job fixing stuff and adding small new things into the game. (I spent far too many crowns at the Slime Casino) Now would be the time to try the game out rather than 2 years ago, in terms of content. They have yet to add new levels, or anything big to the game yet, but I think they're gonna do fine. Once you complete the campaign (which is fairly long, including required grinding for stuff) you still have guilds, acades, and more to do. In summary, Spiral Knights is a fun 3rd person MMO that's free to play, has a good community, and will certainly keep you busy for a while. While there isn't an incredible amount of new stuff to the game, it's slowly getting there, and Grey Havens does care about the game. AND THERE'S HATS!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I love this game. I really do. I've called it 4-swords the mmorpg, because that's what the gameplay feels like. The variety of weapons is fun, and I like how your character doesn't level up- it's all in the gear. The visuals are beautiful and it's not the dreaded "standard fantasy world" setting that so many mmorpgs fall into. the music, too, is fun, and the game presents a decent challenge.However, this game has gone downhill. The grind for items is downright awful, and the economy is tanking fast. The playbase is dwindling, and the devs clearly do not care about this game anymore. I wish it was different, because this game was so fantastic and so fun, but the extreme amounts of grinding on repetitive levels has killed all the fun. With a heavy heart I cannot recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2011
												I, like many reviewers, played this game for the first time back in 2012, when updates were common, parties were full, and Mist Energy was a thing.  Due to various circumstances however, I stopped playing for quite some time.  It wasn't until recently that I got back into the game, and I haven't really gotten much farther in the story.As I mentioned in my review previously, I think battle sprites are a welcome addition, much like the removal of Crystal Energy.  The big points in my previous review still stand.However, that's not to say I don't have any issues with the game.  I think more levels and more weapons are necessary.  Perhaps a new weapon class?  No idea.  I am also of the opinion that Heat Crystals are a problem.  There are two solutions I can see.  Either drop them entirely, or at least make them more common.  My helm has been sitting at level 7 for at least a month of near-solid play.  I don't mind Alchemy Orbs, but Heat Crystals need some work.The game needs some tweaks, but it's still pretty good.  It's worth a try at least, and hey, it's free.  Why not?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2011
												So much potential. Spiral Knights, in its early days, was a great MMORPG-ish thing with sensical mechanics and easy-to-learn gameplay. It was a great time-burner, trying to get all 5 star gear, running the Firestorm Citadel over and over. Unfortunately, as time passed, things took a turn for the worse. As OOO (or sega or whoever makes updates for this thing now) became more and more ambitious, the updates spiraled off and off into a sense of bleh. Missions were cool. Crimson Hammer was cool. Battle Sprites were cool. Mist energy being removed was passable. Being forced most of the time to spend $20 to upgrade a single piece of gear is not cool. At the advent of the Forge update, the game, while always being sort of a cash grab, became impossible to play. To get decently tiered gear now, you must slave away in T3, because the drops needed almost never actually drop. This has caused many of my friends who I knew to be seasoned veterans of the game to quit. The guild I was in, which had over 50 active players, went inactive a month after the update. Before the update with the Forge, pretty cool. After, not so much.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Love this game!It has pretty cool vibrant and almost surreal like scenery, the robot characters are also a different but fun aspect. Personally I really having the option of completing quests solo or with others and on different difficulties. The quests can be repetitive at times, yet there will always be something that will make them fun. Tutorials explain everything well and controls are really simple. If not for anything else, just check it out for the chubby little bird/chicken hybrids which are everywhere. Seriously, they're super cute. Would totally recommend this game to anyone!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Long ago. 3 years ago, on Aug 27, 2011. I was but a young lad. young, naive, perhaps innocent. In the new world of Spiral Knights. Spiraling down a chasm of confusion and curiosity, I was finally brought up with a recommendation to Spiral Knights. Filled with swords, pistols, shields, parties, dungeons, and list of items The game Spiral knights(SK) from recollection memories during my first journey through it's dungeons and game-play nearly three years ago. Was enjoyable to say the least.If you for one second can imagine an down graphics to appeal to the ages of 7-13 then probably this game is for you. If your into friendship and co-op through dungeons facing monsters with your trusty pistol or sword and shield, then perhaps this game is for you. However, I digress. S.K. proved to be something that is beyond the average you normally see. Imagine yourself a kid, after the game boy era, the ps1 era, the xbox era, and you have an era of mmo games. Granted, mmo's have existed since probably before the age of 2001 with WoW at its center. The mmo S.K. is to be honest short lived game, pulling your slightest attention for the smallest of seconds through promotions with Team Fortress 2. Such was the case for me when I ashamedly downloaded this game for another TF2 hat promo from S.K. Enjoyable in the sense, that I alone played by myself seeking for riches and glory. I didn't expect much, and that is proven by my hours spent on this game. Later on, I played with my friends together in a typical fashion of dungeon crawling and killing bosses. I'd compare SK to Torchlight, however both games are entirely different and this review isn't about a comparison.It's about telling you my experience. As long as you have friends that back you up in this free to play game. You can literally have a good time. There is a grinding system, but only if you devote many of your efforts to getting the best equipment or the best item for you as soon as possible. Though, in my case. I tried to go for higher quality items, but found it too troublesome to do so. Instead I focused on having fun delving into dungeons with friends in co-op. Laughing so hard when we die because of a stupid mistake like getting stuck in a trap. Or perhaps giving cheers for everyone when we all completed an item set or finished a boss. If you like playing short-to-play games for free, and having fun with friends I would definetly reccomend this game for you.After-all it's not often a studio would go so far to diversify itself for Triple A-A-A games in a Free-2-Play manner. Or would they?(Original Post, Aug 27, 2011) Old score 7.29/10 (Re-edited Post Feb. 6, 2014) New score 7.3/10(Score is based off how much I enjoyed playing the game)

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												While this game has been recieved rathe negatively by the general public, if you like dodgy space shiz and an overall rather random experience, then this game is quite a good choice for you. I found that while the backstory was very well supported throughout the early game, it could have been used more frequently throughout the later parts of the game as the "bosses" of the tiers seemed to have little relevane to the game itself. So if you're a tickler for hardcore RPGs and intense storylines, maybe disregard this game as a viable option.However, the charming thing about Spiral Knights is the deep multiplayer capabilities. While there is a rather small 250 friend limit (which I easily capped within a few days), the ability to join a guild and "chillax" in your guild hall is rather fun part of this game. Personally, I am crap at the game's actual gameplay but continue to play it for the simple reason to connect with randoms across the globe.Overall, as a gamer I would rate this game a 2/10.However, as a human being I would give it an 8 for my love of the Spiral Knights community.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												First off: This is honestly the best free-to-play game you will find on Steam.The graphics are intuitive and maintain the perfect balance between realism and cartoonishness. The community is incredibly nice and supportive (hello, Dota 2?) and the possibilities to play with others are endless.One of the best things about this game is that even if you replay a mission over and over again, the scenario and map you are put into is never the same. There's an infinite number of possible map layouts for every mission, and the missions always have something different that makes that certain mission special and unique. Another major plus is that it requires no grinding/farming to achieve the highest level, and even once you have the best gear and have completed all of the regular missions, there's still so much you can do. There's room to have up to three games on one account so you can always start anew, and if you really think you've accomplished everything there is to accomplish on one game, you can always delete it and start again, opening up another new world of possibilities and game-changing decisions to experiment with.Being a Youtuber (PeaceOfMined), the guild and party options are incredibly useful and fun to record on, especially with the voice-sync (although it is kind of slow). The armor and sword combinations are endless, and with the battle sprites and all the different skills and compositions in one party comes a feeling that you're playing the perfect blend of Spiral Knights and League of Legends, where you have all the abilities and attack possibilities of League, and along with it have the intuitive control system, open-world feeling, and extra attacking options of Spiral Knights, as well as the manual team composition and chatting system.One last thing is the addictiveness of the game itself. I'm a full time student as well as a musician, Youtuber and athlete. What you may notice is I seem to have more hours on record than would seem possible with a schedule like that. I agree. Spiral Knights is a very addicting game. If you have a steady job, be prepared to leave Spiral Knights for a week, as you won't like it one bit.Me: Mom can I take a short break from my homeworkMom: Sure you've been at it for three hoursMe: *opens Spiral Knights*Mom: (seven hours later) Are you done your homework yet? It's past midnightMe: Yeah just a secondMe: *the next morning* Hey mr. teacher I couldn't finish my homework last nightTeacher: WhyMe: I was trainingTeacher: You were playing Spiral KnightsMe: How can you tellTeacher: Im secretly your friend on steam and i was in your party for five hours straightMe: subscribe to my channelTeacher: Already doneMe: Jesus christ what have you been doing with your lifeTeacher: Spiral Knights ;DI challenge you to find a better PC open-world dungeon crawler, paid or not. Comment on my Spiral Knights YouTube videos if you find one I should review. (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXN5MB1UIN1aH2FRw-rPV9g)Overall Rating (There's no infinity symbol on the keyboard):  infinity/10subscribe :D

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												A hidden gem among the f2p genre. The unique graphics, great soundtracks, and the slash and hack combat system makes this a fun game alone or with friends. The only problems with the game is the fact that the game is literally never updated anymore after the lead developer Nick left the team. Also, the endgame is horribly boring and the only thing left to do is to look prettier with costumes or go play PvP. The fun in the game is the journey to endgame, not reaching endgame. I highly reccommend to play the missions and arcade with friends otherwise it could get a bit boring.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I love this game. I really do. I've called it 4-swords the mmorpg, because that's what the gameplay feels like. The variety of weapons is fun, and I like how your character doesn't level up- it's all in the gear. The visuals are beautiful and it's not the dreaded "standard fantasy world" setting that so many mmorpgs fall into. the music, too, is fun, and the game presents a decent challenge.However, this game has gone downhill. The grind for items is downright awful, and the economy is tanking fast. The playbase is dwindling, and the devs clearly do not care about this game anymore. I wish it was different, because this game was so fantastic and so fun, but the extreme amounts of grinding on repetitive levels has killed all the fun. With a heavy heart I cannot recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												If you are into MMOs, or are interested in getting into one, definitely give Spiral Knights a try.Many MMOs follow the same format, consisting of endless numbers of "fetch" or "collect" quests, where all you do is grind against monsters, hoping that they will drop the item you need progressively more ridiculous amounts of.In Spiral Knights, there actually is a good amount of variety in the available missions. The story also provides a healthy amount of cutscenes if and text if you are looking for that. Missions typically involve you progressing through a dungeon littered with enemies and different types of square voxels of differing types (ex: wall voxel or explosive voxel). There are sometimes gates that require you to pick up a key (you cannot attack while carrying it) and bring it to the padlock in order to open it. You might also have to pick up a pot object and throw it at another object in order to clear obstacles, allowing for further access into a dungeon.The combat and controls are pretty easy to become familiar with. Left click to attack, right click to use your shield. Holding the attack down allows you to charge up your weapon (a gauge will appear). You may also use the mouse wheel to alternate between weapons. There is a dash/evade mechanic you can execute by holding shift and pressing right click. The dungeons can become fairly challenging if playing solo, however, it is still viable if you are careful and do not rush right into enemy spawns. The rewards from completing missions and item drops are reasonable. The loot automatically is attracted to your character like a magnet, so you do not need to click on dropped items.Aesthetics are nice, the dungeons and enemies are decently detailed. Like many MMOs, there can be a lot of clutter in the interface, especially when you first log into the game and access the game hub - you will need to get used to this orientation if you have not played many MMOs. The minimap can be expanded to cover the center of your screen by pressing B (do not press tab, that brings up the character stats/info panel), however, be advised that the border of the map is a bold blue, making it noticeably difficult to play while keeping the minimap expanded (compared to games like Path of Exile, or Diablo, where the minimap is translucent enough for you to see most things easily.Overall, the game seems pretty fleshed out, with quite a bit to do. Definitely recommend trying it out if you are interested and/or not already playing other MMOs  (or have the extra time to spare).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2012
												Spiral Knights is really fun as you're progressing through the mission system. The gameplay is nice, the controls are simple, and the stat system is understandable. Three Rings puts heavy emphasis on co-op play, and it is certainly far more fun with more people.Problem is, Three Rings updates the game slower than molasses going uphill in January with crutches. The only thing that can keep you hooked to the game is a desire(and the money) to do the Shadow Lairs, or a desire to play PvP and the money to be able to do buttshit in it. The only thing that can diversify equipment is a random Unique Variant system, and if you don't have the luck or money to get the best UVs, you might as well not play PvP at all.Still, Spiral Knights is amazing for a F2P. Just don't get overaddicted to it like I did, because once you hit the endgame, you'll be there with nothing to do for a month.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This game is the very definition of both Pay to Win and Pay to Play.-You can only play for a little bit before your "fuel" runs out, because it takes some sort of resource to enter a dungeon. This "fuel" takes a few hours to recharge. Want to play for longer than you wait to play? BUY BUY BUY!-Those costumes sure do look neat. I bet you're wondering how to get them. Wait, it takes some other resource to obtain? BUY BUY BUY!-Feel like your equipment isn't leveling up fast enough? Feel like you don't have enough cash? BUY BUY BUY!-Say you're tired of a costume, and it could fetch a pretty penny at the auction house. Aw shucks, it's bound to your character? Guess what you have to do in order to remove it. BUY BUY BUY!-Do you want to know how to get that really cool weapon you can use from the beginning, but it has really high stats anyways? BUY BUY BUY!-It's taking forever to gather those resources, isn't it? By your estimate, it'll take you at least a week to craft the armor you want. How do you get the materials faster? BUY BUY BUY!-Want to open up that chest? The only way to do it is to BUY BUY BUY!This game runs on microtransactions, and those microtransactions let you win. Plus, it's so difficult to get to the interesting parts of the game that you're forced to choose between crippled progression and immediate satisfaction. You can spend about two hundred (real life, US) dollars and you'll be able to get to the end game content within a day.Gameplay is very boring, it's all click based, and there's no Skinner Box effect or additional abilities to keep it interesting like Diablo did. The closest they have are these one-use item drops. Fighting hordes of enemies, rather than engaging, can quickly become tedious.The graphics are okay for what they're supposed to be.The enemies are repetitive, and some of their sound effects can become irritating after a while.The level design varies enough to be engaging, until you realize that they re-use many of the assets for later dungeons.The auction house's prices are ridiculously inflated. Just because this happens often in MMO games doesn't mean it should be the norm. The worst part about this isn't really the fact that it's like this, it's the reason the auction house is like this. Everyone just spends their money to get materials and cash in order to get the stuff a normal player would work for. These are almost always things you can craft from items you buy at the auction house, since the drop rate for crafting materials is gimped. Then, since the people who spend real money on this game get to the stuff first, they get to set the price. So not only does the game put you in a position where it's better to pay to win, the people who pay to win also put you in a position where it's better to pay to win.On the plus side, there's a smoking pipe accessory. I got some enjoyment out of smoking my pipe while playing a character who smokes a pipe.In summary:The people behind Spiral Knights have created one of the most profitable free games I've ever witnessed. Please note that a profitable game does not necessarily equate to a good game. I don't mind if they keep doing what they're doing, and I don't intend to stop them. I mean, there's plenty of children and spoiled teenagers around to suck away their parents' money and spit it into this game. They'll grow out of it. But to any adult who plays this, I can only ask that rather than wasting your disposable income on this game, you spend it on a quality one which doesn't exist solely to sponge away your earnings (you did earn it, right?)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Mostly finished.Public nowNow don't get me wrong, Spiral Knights USE to be a good game until they made it a real free to play. It is quite obvious that the developers wanted as much money as they could get, so they added Spark's of life, and those heat things that level up your weapons, and made the elevators free just to remove the good co-op in the game. (No shared coins, can't revive party members) God. Why. I actually enjoyed the co-op and even contributed to the game and bought things with money, that won't be happening anytime soon again, unless they fix this terrible new co-op, and new free to play feature)There are still *some* good things in the game, but it is beaten down by the new features. The art style is great, and well done. The fighting is fun, or use to be fun until they removed reviving. The weapons have their own up's and downs, balancing most out. Some things are set up nicely, but the new features do ruin them. There is an auction house to buy things that you want when you can't get them, but have the crowns to get them. That is really all I can think of.The bad features? Well all of the new features. The "mini" monsters. Those things are devils and will ALWAYS kill you. No reviving, little co-op. Coins aren't shared in levels anymore. Sparks of life which cost energy to buy. No more mist energy. Elevators are free, and addition that came with the new features, which means no more elevator passes (I liked the elevator pass system, changed the game into a non-free to play, but now it is a complete free to play, and you can't get out of it). New heat system where leveling up weapons requires crystals which cost money too. Gaining heat on your weapons was hard enough, and now there is a CHANCE for it to level up when you use crystals (Unless you use a load of them which costs even more money)?! The repetitive arena levels and the missions to get to new tiers are really useless. The old tier system was better where you would have to go through a group of levels, not boring missions, and have the correct armor and weapons.As an old player, I DO NOT recommend this game, it was hard enough before, and now they made it even HARDER.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												You're constantly fighting an uphill struggle in this game, this game had so much potential and only limited itself with the energy system. A lot of people feel like this is easily averted, it is, if you are willing to spend a lot of time either playing the Marketplace or crafting items to get the money in order to get more energy. Everything you do requires energy and that's a big flaw, it's like Farmville, you get many small doses of rewards backed by a refresh timer and it just interupts the flow of everything. Ultimately they want you to spend money to buy energy, or somehow grab enough cash to convert into energy which as I said, mostly requires playing the marketplace, and for those who want a clean way of accomplishment then tough luck! That being said, combat was fun and the dungeon crawling aspects were top notch, for the short while I played this game it was a blast, I loved the item system and I liked the fact that you made everything your own through dedication. still though. Paywalls.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2012
												F2P co-op action-rpg that's fun and easy to play in short bursts, but quickly shows its shallow and repetitive nature. I really like that the battles are real-time, you can defend against or dodge enemy attacks and that player skill and knowledge of elemental strengths/weaknesses become vital later on. Your gear levels up instead of your character by acquiring heat from killing enemies.  It takes Crystal Energy ($) to level up gear among other things, so without a lot of grinding it's hard to stay F2P.  On the bright side the game recently made traveling on the elevators to and within dungeons free. End game has been the same for a long time.  Don't expect new content very frequently. Do expect promotional cash shop "dress up" crap to pop up all the time. All optional of course, but it just shows you it doesn't take long to suck the game's content dry when you can't find people to go on missions with you because they're all standing around town trying on their halos, wings and twinkly auras.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												First, I'd like to say that I've played 507 hours of this game[tinypic.com] in the downloadable client, so please don't take my 1.4 hours on record too seriously.The PVE gets boring and repetitive after a while, given that there are very few missions are worth doing save for advancing in the questline. However, it does last for some time(around a hundred hours) and for that bit is is a delightful experience. If that's all you're going to do, I suggest you play another game.The best part of this game is... dressup. I'm not going to lie. Development on this game for the most part has been centered on creating more and more costumes for players to use, and other things like PVE and general gameplay has been left behind. With that in mind, costumes are now cooler and better looking than ever, and surpass other aspects of this game. This opens up many opportunities for players. Here are some examples of costumes I've been using:1[i.imgsafe.org] 2[i.imgsafe.org]Another great part of this game is the social aspect. Players in this game are often kind, helpful, and interesting individuals. If you get in a large guild of any kind, you could treat this as a medium for general chatting and socializing.Maybe you're wondering what I did in those 400 hours that I didn't spend doing PVE. Well, I was trading. Trading is a fun experience, especially reselling. All of my equipment and costumes came from buying items(specifically 5* sprite food) at half of what it's worth and selling it at market price. I've spent days on end simply just zone chatting various different offers, and while eventually I got bored with it- it was wonderful while it lasted.All in all, I suggest you play this game. Don't let the negative reviews get to you, there is very little harm in trying out a free to play game.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												A delightful, free-to-play game that plays like a combination of Zelda mechanics and Gauntlet gameplay, settings allow for equal enjoyability of single player and multiplayer, and the game never really forces or heckles you for cash. It's very stylish and responsive, with a newly designed mission *every day*, alongside a mechanics-enforcing core Story Mode, and a randomizable Arcade Mode with shifting themes, a variety of settings that give a variety of objective strategies, and of course, is all about stylish customization. Masterfully brilliant, and accessible from casuals to masocore players (Elite difficulty is made with 4 competent players in mind, so playing through that with one? Doable, but good luck!)Some resources may seem obscured by currency barriers, but enough 'crowns' (the coins you collect in the level) can add up to enough, or you can usually get the resources themselves by playing Story Mode chapters. Very infectious soundtrack, as well. Just a pure delight, assuming you have a good broadband connection.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If you have friends who are willing to play this game with you, then ignore this review and play the game.Although I only have very few hours on this game, be assured I had much more before I had steam and I downloaded this game from the internet. It's golden time was in the spring of 2013 when people really enjoyed spending all their mist energy (ancient version of crystal energy which charged throughout the day/night and was used for the elevators in the levels) and then going to haven to trade all their loot. In the summer of 2013 a big update came along which changed the UI and the supply depot (kozma used to sell cobalt-azure stuff instead of everything, very useful) and also introduced the mission system and the forge system. It also made trips to the clockworks free so mist energy was removed from the game. Although many players liked this, most didn't because it meant the game had lost it bare-bones feel by replacing it with missions and CE purchases and grinding which ruined the game. Before this massive update, when starting the game you had to customize your character, do the basic tutorial and cross the chasm into haven, from there you were left to explore the rest of the game with the help of those who already knew. After the update, missions led to the trashy lore with razwog and other crappy characters as opposed to finding out yourself. The missions meant that visiting the clockworks was child's play and took away the dark souls difficulty to getting recon modules and finding out about what the game was about. Before the update, to buy exclusive and special items, you had to either find them yourself from boss tokens or trade at the AH for them, afterwards you could buy them more expensively from the supply depot with used to be home to the azure tree which was only available from kozma and the AH. AH prices boomed and became unpopular due to the supply depot, people could find and beat bosses by using the missions which eventually led to the tier system being demolished (the tier system was a system in the clockworks which prevented new players from farming too much and meant that it was at least possible for the tier 3 player to be able to spend his mist energy on the levels they want to farm). The forge system meant players had to constantly grind and forage the clockworks for pointless rocks which level up items, which led to players getting fed up and buying it for real money as opposed to just looting the clockworks the hard way and levelling up your items as you went along, which meant it was easier to build and buy new items. Lockdown and Bomber was introduced which was pretty pointless except for guildwars and general showing off items, after the clockworks were deemed unusable, people turned to lockdown and bomber which now is 99.99% of the game. The devs gave up after half the community left by the end of the year. No new items were introduced anymore, just the same old specials being rerun after that. Also, pointless costumes being introduced. The lore was ruined, the bare-bones feel was taken away, people didn't need or want to trade anymore and PVP was the only way out. People who couldn't keep up or wouldn't keep up decided to leave along with the devs who bailed on the game with the money they made. By mid 2014 there were only 10% of what used to be the amount of people playing. International servers were empty and 'active' guilds only had 2-3 players. The game as of the end of 2015 is now dead, there are only around 200 people playing at midday which is the peak of people online at the same time. For anyone new or old who doesn't have any friends willing to play SK along with them, leave this game alone, the devs killed it.

content:
Posted: February 21
												A while back I used to play it a lot. This was way before I even had a Steam account. Or maybe I just didn't play it on here. But after a few years, or maybe more, the game has lost what it used to be. Most negative reviews can explain it in detail, but what I am saying here is that many players who played the game before things like missions and pets knew how fun and exciting it actually used to be, as it wasn't about grinding or paying to get items, instead it was more about teamwork and parties going as deep into the dungeon as they could before dying or running out of energy.Sadly the game lost what it used to be, though it's music and art remains to be some of the best I ever had seen in games. If it ever were to be revived in another game, hopefully they would be able to get the original developer working on it again, as if I recall he is what made the whole game feel magical.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Game summary:-you don't level up, your gear do from 1 to 5 stars, after investing stuff to transform it :)-all your gear means a helm, an armor, a weapon (but can carry up to 4), a shield, 2 trinkets and a pet with a collar. In your stash you can have more armors, helms, etc  :)-you start from surface and via elevators you go underground levels (very small areas, like 3 minutes of walking from edge to edge). "Highest" depth was 29 last time I played. That is the end. Then you go out and go again same route or another to earn extra money or just because you are too bored and there is nothing else to do  :)-it has missions. You can redo most of them, meaning clearing some depths again.-very fast your gear will be at maximum level. Then you can gamble your in game money (that can be obtained also with real life cash) to get extra options on your gear, like poison defense low, medium, etc, or maximum - meaning better than smaller versions but still not too much :)   This fun part translates into playing the deepest levels again and again and again untill you have enough money to gamble thirth option on a item. Then you do it again and again and again, becauselast time was a rubbish option and you gamble again to replace it hoping for a maximum :)-after a while, even gambling for options is over, when you did the deepest missions so many times that you know where to wait every monster before it spawns. All your party members, friends and guild mates are also in same situation. Now it's time for the cosmetic investments :) A moustache or a pair of glasses, or maybe a feather or an antenna. You may do this earlyer, investing your money in a glowing necklace instead of a better armor. This way you look cooler while you lie dead on your back  :)-OK, now you have everything. Er... well... you do some more runs from top to deepest level. You earn money... Then... you sell some materials..for more money :). Sometimes devs invent new accesories. They drop from boxes that can be buyed with real money. If you buy the box and drops something you don't like you can sell it in auction for in game money. This way other players can have the thrilling experience of wearing a pipe with a brand new yellow, unlike the green, grey and brown that existed before the summer promotion :)-You start the game. Hm... Nothing new, except the guild leader message to donate more money to the guild to pay rent for guild rooms :)   Your trinket and weapon slots expired, but you buy them again for 1 month each. You do a run with 2 beginners to help them untill they abandon the run and leave you alone at depth 4 :). You try to join a party at biggest boss: Vana, that drops the most expensive tokens. Here you can show off how good is your gear and how impressive you refined your devastating skills. Hi hi :)  Except you can hardly find anyone playing anymore... what happened to the guys?-You start the game... Same old guild message... No guildies online... 1/86 friends online... What to do now? You look at auction, but you have everything. You are bored of all the missions and all levels that you know like the back of your hand. Maybe you do one for old times sake.  It used to be fun before. Exit game disapointed.-Start game. Look around. Do nothing for 5 minutes, because there is nothing to do. You are too bored of killing the same wolfs or zombies that you killed tousands of times. Exit game after 10 minutes withot doing anything.-Start the game... Look around few minutes... Nothing there... Hm... Hm... Exit game.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Game summary:-you don't level up, your gear do from 1 to 5 stars, after investing stuff to transform it :)-all your gear means a helm, an armor, a weapon (but can carry up to 4), a shield, 2 trinkets and a pet with a collar. In your stash you can have more armors, helms, etc  :)-you start from surface and via elevators you go underground levels (very small areas, like 3 minutes of walking from edge to edge). "Highest" depth was 29 last time I played. That is the end. Then you go out and go again same route or another to earn extra money or just because you are too bored and there is nothing else to do  :)-it has missions. You can redo most of them, meaning clearing some depths again.-very fast your gear will be at maximum level. Then you can gamble your in game money (that can be obtained also with real life cash) to get extra options on your gear, like poison defense low, medium, etc, or maximum - meaning better than smaller versions but still not too much :)   This fun part translates into playing the deepest levels again and again and again untill you have enough money to gamble thirth option on a item. Then you do it again and again and again, becauselast time was a rubbish option and you gamble again to replace it hoping for a maximum :)-after a while, even gambling for options is over, when you did the deepest missions so many times that you know where to wait every monster before it spawns. All your party members, friends and guild mates are also in same situation. Now it's time for the cosmetic investments :) A moustache or a pair of glasses, or maybe a feather or an antenna. You may do this earlyer, investing your money in a glowing necklace instead of a better armor. This way you look cooler while you lie dead on your back  :)-OK, now you have everything. Er... well... you do some more runs from top to deepest level. You earn money... Then... you sell some materials..for more money :). Sometimes devs invent new accesories. They drop from boxes that can be buyed with real money. If you buy the box and drops something you don't like you can sell it in auction for in game money. This way other players can have the thrilling experience of wearing a pipe with a brand new yellow, unlike the green, grey and brown that existed before the summer promotion :)-You start the game. Hm... Nothing new, except the guild leader message to donate more money to the guild to pay rent for guild rooms :)   Your trinket and weapon slots expired, but you buy them again for 1 month each. You do a run with 2 beginners to help them untill they abandon the run and leave you alone at depth 4 :). You try to join a party at biggest boss: Vana, that drops the most expensive tokens. Here you can show off how good is your gear and how impressive you refined your devastating skills. Hi hi :)  Except you can hardly find anyone playing anymore... what happened to the guys?-You start the game... Same old guild message... No guildies online... 1/86 friends online... What to do now? You look at auction, but you have everything. You are bored of all the missions and all levels that you know like the back of your hand. Maybe you do one for old times sake.  It used to be fun before. Exit game disapointed.-Start game. Look around. Do nothing for 5 minutes, because there is nothing to do. You are too bored of killing the same wolfs or zombies that you killed tousands of times. Exit game after 10 minutes withot doing anything.-Start the game... Look around few minutes... Nothing there... Hm... Hm... Exit game.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												I recommend this game for the following reasons:Positive:-Great range of monsters to fight.-Difficulty settings are good to re-do missions.-The speed and graphics of the game run smoother than I thought.-Gives you a broad and unique selection when picking your character.-You can create multiple characters (this helps when your bored with your previous ones)-Love the friend system. So easy to go to friends instead of complicatedly finding them.Negative:-Crashing at some points, sometimes when completing a floor on a dungeon and when I click to choose the reward it crashes.-The community isn't the greatest for me. I know this isn't a problem with the game itself, but the community DOES lack in kindness.-Not a good range of weapons in the store. All they do is improve on the weapons that you get on a level (e.g, the Zapper. in the store there is 2 other versions of it and both give more impact on 'Shocking' the enemy. This doesn't really cut it's deal with the money.) When I was new to the game I payed £6.99 for a gun that A. I can't use until rank 8-1 and B. Doesn't do anything different.-Make it clearer about the ranking when buying things from the store. Possibly restrict people from buying the guns or swords etc. until they reach the rank, a warning on the top isn't good enough.In the end, I do recommend this game. Even though I wasted some money, it's a good game to just play with your friends. Not many games have the friending and party systems, love the uniqueness of this game.~Demonic

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a extremly fun 3rd person Hack and Slash game where you play as a race of Cyborgs that Crash on a distant planet. The story like isnt the best but it makes it back up with a amzing Art Design, great soundtrack and a Perfect multiplayer. The players are great and up to this point i havent found any bugs.The Friend sytem really makes it easy to just hop in a mission with your friends and take down to baddies.The monsters in this game are amazing and gives you a wide range of diffrent thingys to battle. One thing i love is your Sprite, the Battle Sprite is a small creature you gain what help fight of monsters, the Sprites all have diffrent powers and help in diffrent ways. You can not olny level up your sprite though, they are loads of cool loot you gain through out the game what really make you character strong, sneaky, fast or even magic. You can go to the auction house and sell or buy gear for great prices.While i am on about prices the game is 100% free to play, yes you can buy this thingy called Energy but there is ways of using in game cash to buy i to so you will never need to fork cash out. The one downfall out the game is that at nearly every point in this game you will be reading a peice of text, one thing i think they should add is voices so we dont need to click through pages upon pages of text.So over all i will rate this game 7/10 becuase there is a few things they need to fix but i really enjoy the missions within the game.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Well, it's not much to be said other than it's not a fun game anymore. After 1100+ hours i realized than it's not worth my time anymore. The developers are just there to milk the cash cow by releasing almost every week a "brand new"...guess what? EXACLY, accessories box. With weapons reskins, costumes and other "dress-up game based" content. When i first started the game, around 3 years ago, it was so addicting, it was hard and it was based on Mist Energy. That Mist Energy was something that you'll get by time in 24 hours reaching 100. Every floor was costing 10 Mist Energy so to wait 24 hours and play for 1 hours ( cuz mist energy ) was rather annoying than fun. But OOO fixed that by removing ME so all the floors are now free. Well, that was the best update in 3 years. After this major update, well...NOTHING. Prize boxes every week with reskins and small bug-fixes. I call that a major lack'o'content. The new Forge System is simply crap, in order to lvl up your 5* weapon you have to grind a freaking month or just lay down the dosh to get it done. The game transformed into "contest between costumes sets" and the worst part is that OOO actually engage you to do that by releasing the stupid costume boxes. The lag will hit you hard due to the server-side client, the PvP is full of ppl that paid hundreds of $$$ for weapons, the game have literally the same level design for 4 years now, the AI is dumb and there is not much of gear content. I mean, in 4 years they released ONE gear update called "Gunner Update" which adds 90% same guns with different elements AND took OOO almost 2 YEARS to release it. Other than that...yep c: NOTHING! The missions are pointless, and for a new guy is sooo hard to level up. I see around 1,5k players daily and i'm sure 1,4 of them are veterans. So yeah...it's not fun to grind one month to lvl up one weapon OOO :) You'll see two types of ppl that recommend this game:1) Rich guys that spend thousands of $$$ for gear.2) Guys with 10 hours in-game.The only good thing about this game is that you can convert the in-game money into real-life money if you're smart enough :) That's why i still like this game. Not playing it more than 2 hours/week doe.I'll give this game maybe 2 years more.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Spiral Knights is free to play cooperative dungeon crawler fantasy MMORPG.The player begins as a simple knight, and jump into action with an ever-changing, randomized world known as the Clockworks. Players can influence the areas they enter by depositing different minerals into the gates before they open. As players level up, they can upgrade their equipment or craft new items.Every Spiral Knight has two attacks: one primary attack with a melee weapon and one special attack. You start with a gun but can later gain access to bombs, and your arsenal is constantly changing as you defeat new enemies and learn to manufacture new weapons.One of Spiral Knights' greatest strengths is its art direction. Enemies are somehow a combination of threatening and adorable, armor upgrades make your Knight look both tough and huggable, and every environment you visit has tons of cool elements that make it interesting and distinct from the others in the game.Spiral Knights is a wonderful game. It is beautifully designed and fun to play and offers hours of interesting combat in a variety of environments.But there's one enormous catch: You have to pay real-life money to play Spiral Knights if you plan to play it for more than an hour at a time. Almost everything you do in Spiral Knights costs Energy. If you want to run a mission it costs 10 Energy, if you want to go to the second level of the dungeon it will be again 10 Energy. You start every day with 100 Energy, which you will quickly consume through normal gameplay.Overall, Spiral Knights is a fun, engaging, pretty game. So if you have nothing else to do, you can check it out.Sounds 6/10Graphics 7/10Gameplay 7/10Atmosphere 6/10

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												First, I'd like to say that I've played 507 hours of this game[tinypic.com] in the downloadable client, so please don't take my 1.4 hours on record too seriously.The PVE gets boring and repetitive after a while, given that there are very few missions are worth doing save for advancing in the questline. However, it does last for some time(around a hundred hours) and for that bit is is a delightful experience. If that's all you're going to do, I suggest you play another game.The best part of this game is... dressup. I'm not going to lie. Development on this game for the most part has been centered on creating more and more costumes for players to use, and other things like PVE and general gameplay has been left behind. With that in mind, costumes are now cooler and better looking than ever, and surpass other aspects of this game. This opens up many opportunities for players. Here are some examples of costumes I've been using:1[i.imgsafe.org] 2[i.imgsafe.org]Another great part of this game is the social aspect. Players in this game are often kind, helpful, and interesting individuals. If you get in a large guild of any kind, you could treat this as a medium for general chatting and socializing.Maybe you're wondering what I did in those 400 hours that I didn't spend doing PVE. Well, I was trading. Trading is a fun experience, especially reselling. All of my equipment and costumes came from buying items(specifically 5* sprite food) at half of what it's worth and selling it at market price. I've spent days on end simply just zone chatting various different offers, and while eventually I got bored with it- it was wonderful while it lasted.All in all, I suggest you play this game. Don't let the negative reviews get to you, there is very little harm in trying out a free to play game.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												This game... this game... Long time i've played it... and if the time hitting 700+ hours didn't show it, i LOVE IT!To begin, let me come out and say yes, i did initially come for the hat...... but then, i found something in it as i got into playing, something... that felt great. I was actually enjoying the whole thing. So much, actually, that i didn't stop when i finally got the hat... which was, by the way, hundreds and hundreds of hours as well as thousands of monsters slain ago.+Pros-The gameplay is quite solid, fun and enjoyable third person hack-and-slash/shooter action in this Role-Playing, multiplayer title, and that gameplay certainly makes it stand out in the sea of MMOs being launched today.-The excentric, anime-like art style by the staff member who one in-game would know as "cherub" is quite the compelling work; with bright, abstract colorations and chibi-like figures all drawn out to flow throughout it's world that breathe an interesting life into the work. -The community is mostly good, and there are some quite friendly people and guilds out there plenty welcoming to new members... but i'd advise steering away from the PvP segment of the community.-The possibilities for how to play are quite expansive-Armor is customizable with accesories and a selection of starter faces (more can be purchased as well)-The market system allows you to buy premium currency at a player controlled rate, and nowadays, item crafting can even be entirely free; allowing everyone to experience every aspect of the game for free-Enter the clockworks: an ever-shifting and entirely random maze of catacombs. Running 29 levels and cycling between up to 8 different maps per area, with those areas coming from a long list divided up among different themes, and with 3 of those themes per gate, the gameplay is exspansive here and it adds much replay value. The levels you travel one time may not be the same the next, and no 2 (of 4 at any given time) gates are alike-Core missions provide a supplementary story arc that is built on by the DLC Operation: Crimson Hammer. It is piecemeal at times, but it is present enough for one to begin to get it-Challenge missions and shadow lairs give a challenge to people who are brave and think they've seen it all-Compatible with Steam trade, allowing you to trade items from other games for items in this one or vice versa-Cons-The PvP system is awful: the standard PvP (lockdown) is overrun with horrible balancing issues that allow certain combos to dominate, and people who pay their way to victory; and the one properly balanced and skill-based multiplayer (Blast Network) is a repackege and remodel of bomberman that noone really plays. If you were hoping to get a place to face up and see who is best, might as well just turn around. PvP is better most anywhere else.-Lag will iron out the experience in this game: If you haven't gone out of map once and found yourself dead and mobbed the next second, you have not truly played Spiral Knights-The balancing team is about as great as EA's testing department-The market mentioned above can be fairly unpredictable, spiking at unexpected times when events come up. This could easily make or break anyone financially-Updates, for whatever reason and regardless of size, never cease to stretch on for ungodly lengths of timeOverall, it is a really nice, really solid game... but with a few issues that could be hammered out to really make it better. It is a standout in the bunch, and any real RPG, Hack-And-Slash, or TPS fanatic should have this somewhere on their hard drive... and that somewhere best not be the trash bin.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If you have friends who are willing to play this game with you, then ignore this review and play the game.Although I only have very few hours on this game, be assured I had much more before I had steam and I downloaded this game from the internet. It's golden time was in the spring of 2013 when people really enjoyed spending all their mist energy (ancient version of crystal energy which charged throughout the day/night and was used for the elevators in the levels) and then going to haven to trade all their loot. In the summer of 2013 a big update came along which changed the UI and the supply depot (kozma used to sell cobalt-azure stuff instead of everything, very useful) and also introduced the mission system and the forge system. It also made trips to the clockworks free so mist energy was removed from the game. Although many players liked this, most didn't because it meant the game had lost it bare-bones feel by replacing it with missions and CE purchases and grinding which ruined the game. Before this massive update, when starting the game you had to customize your character, do the basic tutorial and cross the chasm into haven, from there you were left to explore the rest of the game with the help of those who already knew. After the update, missions led to the trashy lore with razwog and other crappy characters as opposed to finding out yourself. The missions meant that visiting the clockworks was child's play and took away the dark souls difficulty to getting recon modules and finding out about what the game was about. Before the update, to buy exclusive and special items, you had to either find them yourself from boss tokens or trade at the AH for them, afterwards you could buy them more expensively from the supply depot with used to be home to the azure tree which was only available from kozma and the AH. AH prices boomed and became unpopular due to the supply depot, people could find and beat bosses by using the missions which eventually led to the tier system being demolished (the tier system was a system in the clockworks which prevented new players from farming too much and meant that it was at least possible for the tier 3 player to be able to spend his mist energy on the levels they want to farm). The forge system meant players had to constantly grind and forage the clockworks for pointless rocks which level up items, which led to players getting fed up and buying it for real money as opposed to just looting the clockworks the hard way and levelling up your items as you went along, which meant it was easier to build and buy new items. Lockdown and Bomber was introduced which was pretty pointless except for guildwars and general showing off items, after the clockworks were deemed unusable, people turned to lockdown and bomber which now is 99.99% of the game. The devs gave up after half the community left by the end of the year. No new items were introduced anymore, just the same old specials being rerun after that. Also, pointless costumes being introduced. The lore was ruined, the bare-bones feel was taken away, people didn't need or want to trade anymore and PVP was the only way out. People who couldn't keep up or wouldn't keep up decided to leave along with the devs who bailed on the game with the money they made. By mid 2014 there were only 10% of what used to be the amount of people playing. International servers were empty and 'active' guilds only had 2-3 players. The game as of the end of 2015 is now dead, there are only around 200 people playing at midday which is the peak of people online at the same time. For anyone new or old who doesn't have any friends willing to play SK along with them, leave this game alone, the devs killed it.
